questions.text: Which of the following drugs is given by the route shown in the figure?
questions.solution:
Option D: BCG

  • In the case mentioned, the history of night sweats, weight loss and persistent cough suggest the patient has pulmonary tuberculosis. This is confirmed by sputum for acid-fast bacilli and the typical chest x-ray finding of a nodule in the apex of the right lung.
  • BCG vaccine is used for the prevention of tuberculosis.
  • It is given by intradermal route, where the drug is injected into the skin, raising a bleb.
  • Examples of drugs administered through this route are:
    • Rabies vaccine
    • BCG

Option A: Filgrastim

  • Filgrastim is a drug which is used to treat low neutrophil count.
  • It is given by subcutaneous route.

Option B: Insulin

  • Insulin is commonly used for the treatment of diabetic patients.
  • It can be given subcutaneously or intravenously.

Option C: Tetanus toxoid

  • Tetanus toxoid is administered to the patient getting a wound from an infected object.
  • It is given intramuscularly.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the outpatient department with complaints of fever for the past 1 month accompanied by weight loss and cough with purulent sputum. The physician suspects tuberculosis and wants to auscultate the apex of the lungs. To hear the breath sounds better, he needs to locate the Triangle of auscultation. All of the following are borders of the Triangle of auscultation, except?
questions.solution:
Option D: Rhomboid major

The Triangle of auscultation has the following boundaries;

  • Superiorly and medially: Trapezius
  • Inferiorly: Latissimus Dorsi
  • Laterally: Scapula
  • Floor: Serratus anterior, Erector spinae, Deep-Osseous portions of the 6th and 7th ribs, Internal and External intercostal muscles.
  • Typically the Triangle of Auscultation is covered by the Scapula.
  • To better expose the Triangle and listen to respiratory sounds with a stethoscope, patients are asked to fold their arms across their chest, medially rotating the scapulae while bending forward at the trunk, somewhat resembling a fetal position.

Option A: Trapezius

  • The trapezius forms the superior and medial boundary of the Triangle of the auscultation.

Option B: Latissmus dorsi

  • Latissmus Dorsi forms the inferior limit of the Triangle of auscultation.

Option C: Scapula

  • Laterally, the Triangle of auscultation is bounded by Scapula.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male known case of chronic kidney disease presents with the complaint of breathlessness for 2 weeks. On examination: heart rate is 100 beats/min, blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and jugular venous pressure is raised with a prominent x-descent. His chest radiograph is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pericardial effusion

  • Since the chest X-ray, the cardiac borders look bulging, and the cardiothoracic ratio is increased; the finding is that of a water bottle heart/ money bag appearance - pericardial effusion.
  • The point against cor pulmonale is that it is characterized by right ventricular failure with pulmonary artery hypertension. However, the pulmonary artery segment is not bulging in this chest X-ray.

Option B: Cor pulmonale

  • The chest radiograph in chronic cor pulmonale may reveal enlargement of the central pulmonary arteries and oligemic peripheral lung areas. However, the pulmonary artery segment is not bulging in this chest X-ray.

Option C: Broken heart syndrome

  • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is also called Broken Heart Syndrome
  • It occurs due to catecholamine toxicity, intense emotional trauma, or a patient with life-threatening stress, such as the death of a loved one.

Option D: Brugada syndrome

  • Brugada syndrome is an uncommon but potentially fatal cardiac rhythm disorder (arrhythmia), which is occasionally hereditary.
  • Brugada syndrome patients are more susceptible to abnormal cardiac rhythms that start in the lower heart chambers (ventricles).

questions.text: A sixty-five-year-old presents to your clinic with the complaint of decreased vision in both eyes. The loss of vision was gradual, and he has not experienced any pain in his eyes. Examination findings reveal a bilateral cataract. Cataract surgery is scheduled. The patient is informed that the left eye will be operated on first, and the right eye will be done 1 week after that. An intraocular lens (IOL) is placed in the eye during the surgery. Which type of lens is shown below?
questions.solution:
Option D: Multifocal Posterior chamber IOL

  • Image in the question shows a multifocal posterior chamber IOL.
  • An intraocular lens (IOL) is implanted in the eye in place of the crystalline lens that gets opacified in a cataract.
  • An IOL consists of an optic and haptics.
  • Posterior chamber IOL is the most commonly used IOL after cataract surgery.
  • Multifocal IOLs may be refractive or diffractive.
  • Refractive IOLs mainly provide intermediate and distance vision.
  • Diffractive IOLs provide brilliant reading vision and a decent distant vision.
  • There are various rings in the optic zone of a multifocal IOL.
  • This allows the patient to see at various distances according to the multiple focal lengths.
  • Side effects include:
    • Unavoidable halos
    • Glare.

Option A: Crystalens

  • Crystalens is a type of accommodative IOL that is also placed in the posterior chamber.
  • Elastic haptics are present that change the position of the optic when a person tries to accommodate.
  • No rings are present in the optics, helping reduce glare and halos.

Option B: Anterior Chamber IOL

  • A Complicated surgery, with a rupture of the posterior capsule, may necessitate alternative positioning of the IOL.
  • In this scenario, anterior chamber IOLs are used.
  • In the anterior chamber, IOL the haptics supported in the angle.
  • The position of the anterior chamber requires a specific type of lens.
  • Complications include:
    • Uveitis
    • Glaucoma
    • Hyphema

Option C: ICL

  • An Implantable Collamer Lens (ICL) is a Posterior chamber phakic intraocular lens.
  • Posterior chamber phakic intraocular lenses are used as refractive surgery in patients unsuitable for corneal refractive surgery.
  • Has communication ports to allow passage of aqueous from the posterior chamber to the anterior chamber and posterior vault (the gap between ICL and the anterior surface of the crystalline lens).

questions.text: A 40-year old female known case of proximal cholangiocarcinoma underwent percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage as the patient’s bilirubin levels were very high. After the procedure, the patient developed abdominal pain. On further evaluation, the patient was found to have hemobilia due to an iatrogenic trauma to biliary tree. Which of the following statements is the best related to hemobilia?

choices.text: Tumors are the most common cause
The primary treatment of severe hemobilia is surgery
The classic triad is upper abdominal pain, upper gastrointestinal haemorrhage, jaundice
Ultrasonography usually reveals a specific diagnosis

questions.solution:
ANSWER

Option C: The classic triad is upper abdominal pain, upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage, jaundice

  • Hemobilia is bleeding into the biliary tree from abnormal communication between a blood vessel and the bile duct. Causes of hemobilia are iatrogenic trauma, accidental trauma, gall stones, tumours, inflammatory disorders, and vascular disorders.
  • The classic triad is upper abdominal pain, upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage, and jaundice. The symptoms and signs of major haemobilia are melena, hematemesis, biliary colic, and jaundice.

Other options

Option A: Tumors are the most common cause

  • The most common cause of hemobilia is iatrogenic trauma to the liver and biliary tree. Percutaneous liver biopsy results in hemobilia in less than 1% of cases, but percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage procedures have an incidence of 2% to 10%

Option B: The primary treatment of severe hemobilia is surgery

  • Most cases of minor bleeding can be managed conservatively. 
  • Surgery is indicated when conservative therapy and transarterial embolization have failed.

Option D: Ultrasonography usually reveals a specific diagnosis

  • Arterial angiography is now recognized as the test of choice when significant hemobilia is suspected and will reveal the source of bleeding in approximately 90% of cases.
  • Once hemobilia is suspected, the first workup should be upper gastrointestinal endoscopy, but it is diagnostic of hemobilia in only 10% of cases. Ultrasound and CT are other modalities used.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the emergency with a sudden onset of weakness on the right side of her body and the left side of her face. She has hypertension, dyslipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include atorvastatin, lisinopril, and metformin. Examination shows decreased motor tone and power on the right side. On eye examination, she has diplopia on the left lateral gaze. The plantar reflex shows an extensor response on the right side. A CT scan of the head and neck shows a brainstem lesion. What will be the site of the lesion found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Left pons

  • The pons is part of the brainstem located midway between the midbrain and medulla oblongata. The structure of pons is as follows:

  • It carries contralateral corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts and ipsilateral cranial nerve nucleus.
  • Damage to one side of the pons will produce symptoms of ipsilateral cranial nerve damage and contralateral motor weakness.
  • Millard-Gubler syndrome (ventral pontine syndrome):
  • Symptoms result from the functional loss of several anatomical structures of the ventral pons, including the sixth and seventh cranial nerves and fibres of the corticospinal tract.
  • Causes of it include:
  1. Stroke
  2. Demyelination disease
  3. Tumours
  • It affects the following structures:
  1. Facial nucleus
  2. Abducens nucleus
  3. Pyramidal tracts
    • Its symptoms include:
  2. Contralateral weakness of the body
  3. Ipsilateral facial weakness
  4. Diplopia

Option A: Right pons

  • The lesion in the right pons results in
  • Right-sided facial weakness
  • Diplopia on the right lateral gaze
  • Left-sided motor weakness of the body

Option C: Right midbrain

  • The lesion in the midbrain may present as:
  • On the side of the lesion:
  • Eye "down and out" secondary to unopposed action of fourth and sixth cranial nerves, with
  • Dilated and unresponsive pupil due to damage to the third cranial nerve
  • Contralateral to the side of the lesion:
  • Paralysis of the face, arm, and leg (corticobulbar and corticospinal tract)

Option D: Left midbrain

  • Medial left midbrain lesion will present as ipsilateral down and out an eye with contralateral paralysis of the face, arm and legs

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy who is a known case of bronchial asthma comes with a respiratory rate of 48/min, cannot speak 2 words, occasional wheezes, a temperature is 36.8 C and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient has seasonal allergies to ragweed and is also allergic to peanuts. His family history is significant for asthma in his grandfather. You give 3 doses of salbutamol nebulization, and then he started to speak a sentence but oxygen saturation (SaO2) falls to 85%. What is the most likely cause of the drop in oxygen saturation SaO2?

choices.text: V/P mismatch with dead space ventilation

questions.solution:
The most likely cause of the drop in oxygen saturation (SaO2) in this case is V/P (Ventilation/Perfusion) mismatch with dead space ventilation.

Here's an explanation of the options:

  1. Laryngomalacia: Laryngomalacia is a congenital condition characterized by the collapse of the laryngeal structures during inspiration, leading to stridor and breathing difficulties. While it can affect airway patency, it is less likely to cause sudden drops in oxygen saturation in a patient with a known history of asthma.

  2. Alveolar hypoventilation: Alveolar hypoventilation occurs when there is inadequate ventilation of the alveoli, resulting in increased carbon dioxide (CO2) levels and decreased oxygen (O2) levels in the blood. It is not typically associated with a sudden drop in SaO2 in a patient actively receiving treatment for an asthma exacerbation.

  3. V/P Mismatch with Dead Space Ventilation: In patients with asthma, especially during an exacerbation, there can be regions of the lung with inadequate ventilation (V) relative to blood flow (perfusion, P), leading to V/P mismatch. This can result in oxygen not effectively entering the bloodstream, causing a drop in SaO2. Additionally, dead space ventilation, where ventilation occurs but without effective gas exchange, can further contribute to the mismatch and decreased SaO2.

  4. Pneumonia: Pneumonia can cause a drop in oxygen saturation, but it is less likely in this case because the patient's symptoms and history are more consistent with an asthma exacerbation, and the drop in SaO2 occurred after treatment with salbutamol nebulization.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy visits the clinic with abnormal facies. On general examination, he is under-built, under-nourished with short stature, evident icterus, and yellow-tinged fingernails. Head and Neck examination reveal depressed cranial vault, frontal bossing, and maxillary expansion (+). The haemoglobin level is 4.7 g/dl, MCV is 66 fl, and RDW is 21. The peripheral smear reveals anisopoikilocytosis with microcytic hypochromic anaemia and target cells. Which of the following is associated with this patient's underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Hepatosplenomegaly

  • This patient with abnormal facies, severe microcytic anaemia, and target cells most likely has β-Thalassemia major.
  • Hepatosplenomegaly is a prominent feature of this condition.
  • It occurs secondary to extramedullary hematopoiesis taking place in these patients.

Option A: Onset at puberty

  • The onset of β-Thalassemia major occurs particularly in childhood rather than puberty.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

Option B: Irregular need for blood transfusions

  • There is a need for repeated transfusions in these patients, which may lead to a variety of side effects, such as:
    • Transfusion reactions
    • Secondary hemochromatosis

Option C: Mild to moderate anaemia

  • Severe anaemia with a Hb level of 6-7g/dl is seen in patients with thalassemia major.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the outpatient department for a six-week history of constipation, episodic bloody stools, progressive fatigue, and a 6-kg weight loss. Digital rectal examination shows a hard, 1.5cm rectal mass. A biopsy confirms a malignancy. The patient starts the treatment with a combination chemotherapy regimen that includes a drug that is also used in wet age-related macular degeneration treatment. Among the following options, mark the correct statement regarding the drug used.

choices.text: First FDA-approved molecule that specifically targeted angiogenesis

questions.solution:
Option C: First FDA-approved molecule that specifically targeted angiogenesis.

  • The patient, in this case, presents with constipation, bloody stools, fatigue and weight loss.

  • These symptoms show that the patient has carcinoma, which is also proven with a biopsy.

  • The symptoms suggest that the patient has colorectal carcinoma.

  • For colorectal carcinoma, the drug used for treatment is Bevacizumab.

  • It is used to treat neovascular age-related macular degeneration and many advanced malignancies.

  • It is a humanized antibody directed against VEGF-A.

  • First FDA-approved molecule that specifically targeted angiogenesis.

  • As a single agent, it delays the progression of renal-cell cancer

  • Combination with cytotoxic chemotherapy effectively treats lung, colorectal, and breast cancers

Option A: Humanized antibody directed against EGF

  • Bevacizumab is the humanized antibody directed against VEGF-A.

  • For humanized antibodies directed against EGF, nimotuzumab is used.

  • This drug is used in the treatment of malignant epithelial tumours.

Option B: Acts on CD 33

  • Bevacizumab has no role on CD 33.

  • But the drug which acts on CD33 is Gemtuzumab.

  • Functions:

    • Acts on CD 33

    • Used in CD-33 positive AML

Option D: Used in Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia

  • Bevacizumab is used in the treatment of colorectal cancer, lung cancer and breast cancer.

  • It has no role in the treatment of CML.

  • Drugs used in CML are

    • ​​​​​​​Obinutuzumab and Ofatumumab:

      • ​​​​​​​Against CD20

      • Used in Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia

    •  

      ​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency with complaints of palpitations, shortness of breath, chest pain, and nausea. Electrocardiography shows tall tented T waves. Serum electrolytes show potassium = 8.2 mEq/L. Which of the following is the best drug used to manage this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Calcium chloride

Management of hyperkalemia:

  • Calcium is the main treatment choice in the management of hyperkalemia.
  • Whenever the potassium level goes greater than 6.5 mEq/L, then immediate intravenous calcium is given to the patients.
  • Calcium is given in the form of calcium gluconate or calcium chloride.
  • Insulin with glucose is the other treatment option
  • Beta-agonist such as salbutamol is also given
  • Sodium polystyrene sulfonate (Kayexalate)] reduces total body potassium levels 
  • Calcium chloride - Onset of action is <5min and lasts about 30-60 min.
  • Doses should be titrated with constant monitoring of ECG changes during the administration

Option B: Calcium hydroxide

  • Calcium is given in the form of calcium gluconate or calcium chloride.

Option C: Potassium binding resin enema

  • Potassium-binding resin exchanges Na+ for K+.
  • The onset of action after PO ranges from 2-12 h.
  • Calcium gluconate should be the immediate step to make the cardiac membrane resistant to the effect of potassium.

Option D: Calcium carbonate

  • Calcium hydroxide and calcium carbonate have no role in the management of hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought in by his parents in the medical outpatient department with bony aches and pains from the last 2 months. They have also noticed bending of his lower extremities. Family history was significant for similar complaints in his mother. His vitals are heart rate 90/min, Blood pressure 120/80 mmHg, Respiratory rate 14/min, and temperature 98.6°F. Physical examination revealed an enlarged wrist and knee and bowing of both legs. Investigations revealed hypophosphatemia and normal calcitriol level. Considering the possible diagnosis, what is the mode of inheritance of this condition according to the given family pedigree?
questions.solution:
Option C: X-Linked dominant type

  • X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets is an X-linked dominant disorder resulting from renal phosphate wasting, causing growth retardation and severe skeletal abnormalities. Defective phosphate reabsorption is the primary mechanism of this disease.
  • X-linked dominant inheritance, also known as X-linked dominance, is a mode of inheritance in which an X chromosome carries the dominant gene. This means that the gene causing the disorder is on the X chromosome. Only one copy of the allele is sufficient to express the disease if inherited from a diseased parent.
  • The affected father, carrying the x-linked dominant disorder, will pass on the disease to all the daughters but not to any son.
  • If the mother is affected, then sons will have a chance of being affected depending on whether a recessive or dominant X chromosome is passed on.
  • If the son is affected, the mother will always be affected.
  • In the first generation, female is affected by the disease.
  • In the second generation, the son is affected by the same disease.
  • In the third generation, all the daughters are affected, not the sons.
  • The given pedigree chart shows that all daughters of affected males have the disease, while none of their sons has it.
  • This is suggestive of X-Linked dominant inheritance.

 

 

 

Option A: Autosomal recessive type

  • The inheritance pattern in the given pedigree does not account for an autosomal recessive trait.
  • In an autosomal recessive type inheritance pattern, two copies of the gene must be mutated for an individual to express the disease.
  • An affected individual usually has unaffected parents, each of whom carries a single copy of the mutated gene (carriers) and normally does not exhibit disease symptoms.
  • Two carriers have a 25% risk of transferring disease to their offspring.

Option B: Autosomal dominant type

  • The inheritance pattern in the given pedigree does not account for an autosomal recessive trait.
  • Affected parents have a 50% chance of transferring the mutated gene to their child.
  • The mutated genes are located on nonsex chromosomes.

Option D: X-linked recessive type

  • X-linked recessive conditions also result from mutations in genes on the X chromosome.
  • Males are much more frequently affected as compared to females.
  • The sons of an affected father with an X-linked recessive disorder will not be affected (since they receive their father's Y chromosome), but his daughters will be carriers of one copy of the mutated gene.
  • A woman carrying an X-linked recessive disorder (XRXr) has a 50% chance of having daughters who are carriers of one copy of the mutated gene and a 50% chance of having sons who are affected.

questions.text: A 71-year-old male patient presents with decreased appetite and weight loss for the last 8 months. He also complains of occasional fever and night sweats. On examination, hepatosplenomegaly is noted, and petechiae and ecchymosis are present throughout his body. He is diagnosed with a chronic phase of chronic myeloid leukaemia (CML). Which of the following is an expected lab finding in CML?
questions.solution:
Option B: Basophilia

  • Characteristic features of CML in CHRONIC PHASE
    • Massive splenomegaly
    • Hyperleukocytosis
    • Petechiae
    • Weight loss
    • Loss of appetite
  • Characteristic features of CML in ACCELERATED PHASE
    • Bleeding
    • Ecchymosis
    • Opportunistic Infection
  • Characteristic features of CML in BLAST PHASE
    • Fever
    • Bone pain
    • Bone marrow fibrosis

 

 

Option A: Auer rods

  • Auer rods (Auer bodies) are large, crystalline cytoplasmic inclusion bodies sometimes observed in myeloid blast cells during acute myeloid leukaemias, especially acute promyelocytic leukaemia, high-grade myelodysplastic syndromes and myeloproliferative disorders.

Option C: Increased LAP score

  • A high LAP score is seen in patients with leukemoid reactions.
  • Leukemoid reaction is an increase in WBC count, which can mimic leukaemia.

Option D: Bone marrow fibrosis

  • Myelofibrosis is an uncommon type of bone marrow cancer that decreases the production of all blood cells.
  • Bone marrow fibrosis is also seen in the blast phase of CML.

questions.text: Several mechanisms generate the membrane potentials and action potentials in smooth muscle. Based on the few attributes of the visceral smooth muscle given below, which of the following is not shared by skeletal muscle?
questions.solution:
Option B: Contracts in response to stretch

Excitation of visceral smooth muscle by muscle stretch:

  • Spontaneous action potentials are usually generated when the visceral (unitary) smooth muscle is stretched sufficiently.
  • They result from a combination of:
    • The normal slow wave potential
    • Decrease in overall negativity of the membrane potential caused by the stretch itself.
  • This response to stretch allows the gut wall, when excessively stretched, to contract automatically and rhythmically.
  • An example is when the gut is filled with intestinal contents, local automatic contractions often set up>
  • Visceral smooth muscle can contract in response to stretch, and this is one of its important characteristic features, which is not shared by skeletal muscle.

Option A: Contraction is ATP dependent

  • Actin and myosin filaments derived from smooth muscle interact in much the same way they do in skeletal muscle. Further, the contractile process is activated by calcium ions, and adenosine triphosphate (ATP) is degraded to adenosine diphosphate (ADP) to provide the energy for contraction.

Option C: Does not contain actin filaments

  • Actin and myosin-II, present in the muscle fibers, slide on each other to produce a contraction. Like in the skeletal and cardiac muscles, the actin and myosin-II are not arranged in regular arrays; thus, the striations are absent in the smooth muscle.

Option D: High rate of cross-bridge cycling

  • The cross-bridge cycle in smooth muscle is considerably slower than in skeletal muscle, which allows for a higher maximal force of contraction. Both actin and ATP determine smooth muscle contraction.

questions.text: A 64-year-old male came to the OPD complaining of a painless nodule in the lower eyelid for almost a year. The patient has a light complexion. On examination, a nodule with rolled pearly edges with surface ulceration was noted near the medial canthus of the lower eyelid. Which of the following is true about the given condition?

choices.text: The most common type of benign eyelid tumour
More common in the upper eyelid
Treatment is local surgical excision of the tumour along with a 3 mm area of normal skin with primary repair
Radiotherapy and cryotherapy should be given in operable and inoperable cases

questions.solution:
Option C: Treatment is local surgical excision of the tumour along with a 3 mm area of normal skin with primary repair

  • This patient with a painless nodule with rolled pearly edges on the lower eyelid likely has basal cell carcinoma.
  • The standard treatment of basal cell carcinoma is surgical excision with safe margins of surrounding healthy tissues.
  • Mohs micrographic surgery is a method/technique in which the tumour is removed layer by layer.
  • Radiation therapy is preferred in:
    • In older patients or patients who refuse surgery.
    • Patients have large tumours.
    • If the location of the tumour is not accessible.

Option A: Most common type of benign eyelid tumour

  • Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of malignant eyelid tumour.
  • It presents as a non-healing ulcer with a central depression and rolled borders. It is known as a rodent ulcer.

Option B: More common in the upper eyelid

  • Basal cell carcinoma most commonly involves the lower eyelid.
  • It is painless and locally invasive, and it rarely metastasizes.

Option D: Radiotherapy and cryotherapy should be given in operable and inoperable cases

  • Cryotherapy and radiotherapy should be given only in inoperable cases of palliation.
  • Cryotherapy is used for the treatment of lesions which are less than 10mm in area.

questions.text: Calculate the end-diastolic volume in a patient whose ejection fraction of 0.4, a heart rate of 95 bpm, and a cardiac output of 3.5 L/min.
questions.solution:
• Stroke Volume from the cardiac output and heart rate to be calculated first.
  • Cardiac Output (CO) = Stroke Volume (SV) × Heart Rate (HR).
  • Thus, stroke volume = cardiac output/ heart rate = 3500 mL/95 beats/min = 36.8 mL.
  • End-diastolic volume from stroke volume and ejection fraction is then calculated.
  • Ejection Fraction (EF) = Stroke Volume (SV)/ End-Diastolic Volume (EDV).
  • Thus end-diastolic volume = stroke volume/ejection fraction = 36.8 mL/0.4 = 92 mL.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female presents with involuntary, painful muscle contractions in her hands and feet for three days, accompanied by tingling. She has a history of thyroidectomy. Lab tests reveal hypocalcemia. The described muscle activity, when voluntary, mirrors a physiological condition in which muscles achieve maximum tension without subsequent relaxation, similar to post-tetanic potentiation. Which of the following is typically implicated in facilitating this response in muscle tissue?

choices.text: A buildup of calcium in the presynaptic terminal

questions.solution:
Option C: A buildup of calcium in the presynaptic terminal

  • In the clinical scenario above, a woman has presented with involuntary muscular contractions. Her past thyroid surgical history suggests hypoparathyroidism, while her laboratory investigations show hypocalcemia. Hence, she has presented with tetany (carpopedal spasm) due to hypocalcemia. These muscle spasms are much similar to the physiologic tetany in muscles. The only difference is that tetany has involuntary muscular contractions in hypocalcemia, while tetanic contractions are voluntary in normal muscles.

  • When the nerves send a weak signal to contract a muscle, the motor units in the muscle that contains the smallest muscle fibers are stimulated in preference to the larger motor units. As the signal increases in strength, larger motor units also begin to be excited.
  • Gradually, the frequency of muscle contraction also increases, and there comes the point at which a new contraction occurs before the preceding one ends. This second contraction is added partially to the first, increasing the total strength of the contraction. When the frequency reaches an optimum level, the successive contractions fuse, and the muscle tension reaches its peak with no relaxation observed, the action appears to be completely smooth; this is called tetanization. A sustained muscle contraction remains in this stage for some time.
  • Post-tetanic facilitation is the neuronal phenomenon in which a neuron is more easily excited after a brief period of activity. It occurs after tetanic stimulation of the presynaptic neuron. It is due to the buildup the calcium ions in the presynaptic membrane caused by the prior neuronal activity. Subsequent neuronal impulses release neurotransmitters more readily due to this pre-placed calcium from the previous stimulus.

Option A: Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels

  • During the depolarisation stage of the action potential, the membrane becomes suddenly permeable to sodium ions. Voltage-gated sodium channels open up, allowing many positively charged sodium ions to flow into the cell's interior. It causes the normal resting negative potential to change into a positive potential. Hence, these channels play a significant role in the depolarisation and repolarization of the nerve membrane.

 

Option B: Opening of transmitter-gated potassium channels

  • Transmitter-gated or ligand-gated potassium ion channels are activated upon binding a neurotransmitter, hormone, or second messengers to the ion channel. They are involved in fast synaptic transmission in the nervous system. The flow of ions across the membrane will either depolarize or hyperpolarization.

 

Option D: Electrotonic conduction

  • It is the passive flow of a change in electric potential along a nerve or muscle membrane. It occurs in response to insufficient stimulation to trigger an actively propagated action potential but instead generates depolarisation in a small area of the membrane.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presents with sudden blurry vision in his left eye for three days. Examination reveals visual acuity of 20/40 on the right eye and left-sided visual loss on the left eye. The patient's intraocular pressure is normal in both eyes. A head MRI with and without contrast is performed, which shows focal areas of restricted diffusion in the right medial temporal lobe and inferior right basal ganglia with possible involvement of the right lateral geniculate nucleus. Which of the following visual field defects is most likely seen in lateral geniculate body lesions?

choices.text: Contralateral homonymous superior quadrantanopia (Pie in the sky)
Contralateral homonymous inferior quadrantanopia (Pie on the floor).

questions.solution:
Option C: Keyhole visual field defect

  • This patient with sudden onset of blurry vision is most likely suffering from stroke, causing the lesion to the right medial temporal lobe with possible involvement of the right lateral geniculate nucleus.
  •  A lesion to the lateral geniculate body can result in quadruple sectoranopias or keyhole visual field defects.
  • The quadruple sectoranopias are wedge-shaped visual field defects that result from damage to the medial and lateral parts of the lateral geniculate body. It manifests as the involvement of two homonymous segments of each hemifield, as shown in the figure:

Option A: Contralateral homonymous superior quadrantanopia (Pie in the sky)

  • Contralateral homonymous superior quadrantanopia (Pie in the sky) results from a lesion to the Meyer loop (temporal lobe) and not from the lesion to the lateral geniculate body.

Option B: Contralateral homonymous inferior quadrantanopia (Pie on the floor)

  • Contralateral homonymous inferior quadrantanopia (Pie on the floor) results from a lesion to the parietal lobe, not because of the lesion to the lateral geniculate body.

Option D: Homonymous hemianopia

  • Homonymous hemianopia results from lesions to the optic tract.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the gynaecologist for a routine check-up. She has normal menstrual cycles. She is on the 21st day of her menstrual cycle. The patient is vitally stable. General physical examination reveals no abnormalities. She undergoes vaginal cytology on the 21st day of her menstrual cycle. Which of the following is the normal maturation index expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: 0/70/30

  • 0/70/30 indicates a higher no of intermediate cells, suggesting a progesterone effect in the post-ovulatory phase.
  • Basics: Estrogen promotes, while progesterone inhibits squamous cell maturation.
  • The lateral vaginal wall cells can be sampled by scraping them with a spatula and then plating them on a slide.
  • Samples are often obtained simultaneously with a pap smear.
  • The vagina is sampled at the middle third of the lateral vaginal wall. This is used for detecting hormonal effects in menopausal and postmenopausal women, though this will have a particular value in all stages of a woman's life.
  • This is indicated for the assessment of ovarian function.
  • During puberty & reproductive, menopausal & postmenopausal years.
  • Assessment of ovarian function in menstrual disorders.
  • It can also be used for diagnosing ovulation.
  • Maturation index (MI): The vaginal epithelium has basal, parabasal, intermediate and superficial cells. One hundred exfoliated cells are counted, and the MI is defined as the ratio of parabasal to intermediate to superficial cells of the vaginal epithelium.
  • These cells are presented as a 3-part ratio with the para basal cells starting 1st, intermediate cells 2nd & superficial cells 3rd. For e.g.: MI = 80 /20 / 0 Indicates :80 % - Parabasal cells 20 % - Intermediate cells 0 % - Superficial cells
  • An increase in estrogen level enlarges the parabasal cells to become intermediate cells, which will continue to enlarge & mature into keratinized superficial cells.
  • The superficial cells are most abundant during the proliferating phase. These cells are polygonal with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. There will be more deposition of glycogen in the vaginal epithelium.
  • The high estrogenic effect in a vaginal smear is recognized by a clean background & increased eosinophilic & karyopyknotic indices (Given below).
  • High progesterone levels promote the proliferation of intermediate squamous epithelium. These cells are polygonal in shape -with abundant bluish cytoplasm & seen during the secretory phase.
  • Parabasal cells are immature squamous cells that are round to oval. The nucleus is relatively large.
  • Hence, in a lateral vaginal wall smear, if the cells show:
  • Shift to left – Atrophic effect.
  • Shift to the right – Increased estrogen effect.
  • More mid-zone cells – Progesterone effect
  • With increasing estrogen, the MI is 0/10/90
  • With increasing progesterone, the ratio is 0/90/10
  • With increasing androgen, it is 20/80/0
  • In the pre-ovulatory phase, it is 0/40/60
  • In post-ovulatory phase, it is 0/70/30
  • During menopause, it is 0/80/20
  • Late menopause 100/0/0
  • Eosinophilic index (EI): Ratio of eosinophilic cells to basophilic cells. This is given in a ratio. Parabasal cells are not counted.
  • Karyopyknotic index (KI): Ratio of superficial cells to intermediate cells.

Option A:5/5/95

  • 5/5/95 is suggestive of high superficial cells, the suggestive estrogen effect.

Option B:80/20/0

  • 80/20/0 is suggestive of left shift; high parabasal cells suggest atrophy.

Option D:0/40/60

  • 0/40/60: also suggests right shift, suggestive of estrogen effect.

questions.text: Which of the following component is necessary to be present in the expression vector but not in the cloning vector?
questions.solution:
As, in expression vector, the DNA of interest is expressed as RNA and proteins, so, the promoter which is needed for transcription and Shine-Dalgarno sequence (ribosomal entry site) which is needed for translation initiation has to be present in this vector. Without these two, the protein cannot be synthesized.

Whereas cloning vector are not used for protein synthesis, so, no transcription or translation need to be done, so promoter and ribosomal entry site are not necessarily added in these vectors.

All the other three components mentioned in question are present in both vector as they are required for initiation of replication (option a), inserting the gene of interest (option b) and selection of recombinant vector (option c) which is requirement for both kind of vectors.

questions.text: A 48-year-old alcoholic male who is a known case of cirrhosis presents to the Emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain, swelling, nausea, vomiting, and other difficulties. On examination, there was redness on the palms of the hands, yellowish discolouration of skin and sclera, and spider-like blood vessels on the skin. USG showed severe Ascites despite compliance with dietary sodium restrictions and administration of maximum doses of 400mg of spironolactone and 160 mg of furosemide per day. What will be the next best management for the given condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: TIPS

The clinical scenario given is Refractory ascites.

Refractory ascites can be managed by:

  • Trans-jugular intra-hepatic peritoneal shunt (TIPS)
  • Serial large volume paracentesis (LVP) with albumin.
  • TIPS > LVP in reducing the re-accumulation of ascites but is associated with an increased frequency of hepatic encephalopathy

Diagnostic criteria for refractory ascites

  1. Lack of response to maximal doses of diuretic for at least 1 week
  2. Diuretic-induced complications in the absence of other precipitating factors
  3. Early recurrence of ascites within 4 weeks of fluid mobilization.
  4. Persistent ascites despite sodium restriction
  5. Mean weight loss <0.8 kg over 4 days
  6. Urinary sodium excretion is less than sodium intake

Ascites management

  1. Salt-restricted diet/ Salt intake: up to < 2 mg/day
  2. Diuretics: Spironolactone: 400-600 mg
  3. Loop diuretics: Furosemide: 120- 160 mg/day

Option A: AV shunt

  • The arterio-venous shunts are short vessel segments with a large inner diameter and a very thick muscular wall.
  • The arteriovenous shunt (AVS) is the most commonly used vascular access in patients receiving regular hemodialysis. The AVS may have a significant hemodynamic impact on patients with heart failure.

Option C: Frusemide with Low volume paracentesis

  • Standard therapy for ascites includes a combination of dietary sodium restriction, oral spironolactone and furosemide, with large-volume paracentesis (LVP) if needed.

​​​​​​​Option D: Distal splenorenal shunt

  • The distal splenorenal shunt is performed in patients with portal venous thrombosis.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with a red raised progressive rash associated with burning and itching for 7 days, a fever of 2 days, and a severe global headache of 3 days. The rash (image below) initially started over the inner aspect of his left arm, and gradually over the next 2–3 days, similar-looking rashes appeared to involve his trunk, left thigh, neck, and left leg. Which of the following features is most appropriate regarding the condition of this patient?

choices.text: Erythema migrans is seen only in complicated cases
It is a tick-borne illness which is rarely seen in the west

questions.solution:
Option C: It involves a poly-articular arthritis

  • The image depicts Erythematous annular plaque with a central blister on the back of the left leg, as seen in Lyme disease.
  • Stage 1: Erythema migrans characterise stage 1 infection. About 1 week after the tick bite (range, 3-30 days; median 7-10 days), a flat or slightly raised red lesion appears at the site, commonly seen in areas such as the groin, thigh, or axilla.
  • Stage 2, early disseminated infection: Within days to weeks of the initial infection, secondary skin lesions that are not associated with a tick bite develop in about 50% of patients.
    • Malaise, fatigue, fever, headache, neck pain, and generalised achiness are common with skin lesions.
    • Cardiac involvement includes myopericarditis, with atrial or ventricular arrhythmias and heart block.
    • Neurologic manifestations include both the central and peripheral nervous systems. The most common central nervous system manifestation is aseptic meningitis. The most common peripheral manifestation is cranial neuropathy, i.e., facial palsy.
  • Stage 3, late persistent infection, occurs months to years after the initial infection. The classic manifestation of the late disease is monoarticular or oligoarticular arthritis, most commonly affecting the knee or other large weight-bearing joints.

Option A: It is caused by Borrelia recurrentis

  • Lyme disease is caused by Borrelia burgdorferi.
  • Borrelia recurrentis causes a fever known as Tick Borne Relapsing Fever (TBRF)

Option B: Erythema migrans is seen only in complicated cases

  • Stage 1 infection is characterised by erythema migrans, a flat or slightly raised red lesion that appears at the site and is commonly seen in areas such as the groin, thigh, or axilla.
  • It appears after about 1 week of the tick bite.

Option D: It is a tick-borne illness which is rarely seen in the west

  • It is caused by Ixodes scapularis or black-legged or deer ticks and is most common in western countries.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with his wife, complaining that her husband has not "been himself lately." He sees visuals and hears voices, makes up scenarios that never happened, and has lost weight. On gross examination, the physician can appreciate the muscle wasting. The physician diagnoses him as having a deficiency of a particular vitamin. The physician can trace the origin of his symptoms to all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Option B: Homocystinuria

  • This patient with audio-visual hallucinations, psychosis, confabulations, and muscle wasting; most likely suffers from Beriberi, which occurs secondary to a deficiency of vitamin B1 (thiamine).
  • In comparison, Homocystinuria most commonly occurs secondary to the deficiency of enzyme cystathionine synthase.
  • It is characterized by individuals having:
    • Marfanoid features
    • Fair complexion
    • Ectopia lentis
    • Progressive intellectual disability
    • Behavioral disorders
    • Thromboembolism and osteoporosis can occur as complications.
  • Symptom improvement in these patients has been documented on supplementation with vitamin B6, vitamin B9, and vitamin B12.

Option A: Food faddism

  • It is generally used to describe a particular food or group eaten excessively in the routine diet or eliminated to cure one specific disease.
  • A person believing this may exclude thiamine-containing food in their diet and consequently may get thiamine deficiency.

Option C: Chronic alcoholism

  • It can cause thiamine deficiency as alcohol interferes with the absorption of thiamine.
  • Wernicke encephalopathy is caused by thiamine deficiency presenting as ataxia, ophthalmoplegia, and confusion. Symptoms are due to atrophy of the mammillary bodies.
  • It is advised to administer thiamine before dextrose in patients with alcohol overuse disorder or malnutrition to reduce the risk of Wernicke encephalopathy.

Option D: Chronic loop diuretics use

  • Thiamine deficiency in patients with chronic loop diuretic use is due to increased urine volume and urinary flow rate.
  • Furosemide may directly interfere with thiamine reuptake at the cellular level.
  • Heart failure patients on chronic loop diuretic therapy may be advised to take thiamine supplementation.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male presents to the clinic complaining of gum swelling and bleeding for the past few weeks. On examination, hepatosplenomegaly is noted. A bone marrow biopsy shows greater than 20% of blast cells. The gums finding of the patient is given below:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: AML

  • The gums infiltration is usually seen in AML.

AML:

  • Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) is a tumour of hematopoietic progenitors caused by acquired oncogenic mutations that impede differentiation, leading to the accumulation of immature myeloid blasts in the marrow.
  • Replacing the marrow with blasts produces marrow failure and complications related to anaemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia. AML occurs at all ages, but the incidence rises throughout life, peaking after 60 years of age.
  • Most patients present within weeks or a few months of symptoms with complaints related to anaemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia, most notably fatigue, fever, and spontaneous mucosal and cutaneous bleeding.
  • Thrombocytopenia results in abnormal bleeding, which often is prominent.
  • Cutaneous petechiae and ecchymoses, serosal haemorrhages into the linings of the body cavities and viscera, and mucosal haemorrhages into the gingivae and urinary tract are common.
  • Procoagulants and fibrinolytic factors released by leukemic cells, especially in AML with the t(15;17), exacerbate the bleeding tendency. Infections are frequent, particularly in the oral cavity, skin, lungs, kidneys, urinary bladder, and colon, and are often caused by opportunists such as fungi, Pseudomonas, and commensals.
  • Signs and symptoms related to the involvement of tissues other than the marrow are usually less striking in AML than in ALL, but tumours with monocytic differentiation often infiltrate the skin (leukaemia cutis) and the gingiva; this probably reflects the normal tendency of monocytes to extravasate into tissues. Central nervous system spread is less common than in ALL.
  • AML occasionally presents as a localized soft tissue mass known as myeloblastoma, myeloid sarcoma, or chloroma.
  • Without systemic treatment, such tumours inevitably progress to full-blown AML over time.
  • The overall prognosis is guarded, as AML is a difficult disease; about 60% of patients achieve complete remission with chemotherapy, but only 15% to 30% remain free of disease for 5 years.
  • However, the outcome varies markedly among different molecular subtypes.

Option A: ALL

  • ALL can present with hepatosplenomegaly and pancytopenia.
  • However, gums infiltration is not seen in ALL.
  • Moreover, CNS and mediastinal involvement is the feature of ALL.

Option C: CML

  • CML usually presents with hepatosplenomegaly.
  • Gums infiltration and more than 20% blast cells signify acute leukaemia, not chronic.
  • CML cases are usually detected when a very high leukocyte count is found during the laboratory examination.

Option D: CLL

  • CLL often presents with asymptomatic elevation in WBCs count.
  • Smudge cells are characteristic of CLL.
  • Moreover, CLL is not characterized by gum infiltration.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male was diagnosed with dengue. The number of dengue cases in Delhi from 2000 - 2015 is best represented by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option B: Line chart

  • The line chart is a frequency polygon presenting variations by line; shows the trend of an event over a period of time.

Option A: Histogram

  • The histogram is a graphical presentation of continuous quantitative data.

Option C: Scatter diagram

  • Scatter/Dot Diagram is also known as a Correlation diagram.
  • It is used to depict a correlation (relationship) between 2 quantitative variables.

Option D: Bar chart

  • A bar chart is for visual comparison of the magnitude of different frequencies in discrete data.
  • It is the most versatile of all statistical diagrams.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man was brought to the emergency in an Ophisthotonus posture. When his wife was interviewed, the doctor was informed that he was a chronic alcoholic and had suffered from erectile dysfunction. The couple was told about the medicinal effects of one of the following plant derivatives. The couple had decided to treat him with the powdered form of the seed for the same. The man had become anxious and restless after its consumption. He had also experienced twitching of some muscles before becoming rigid in the Ophisthoptonus posture. Which one could have caused the above-mentioned symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option B: Strychnos Nux Vomica

  • The convulsions are seen in Strychnos Nux Vomica and are most marked in anti-gravity muscles so that the body typically arches in hyperextension (opisthotonos).
  • Convulsions are produced due to direct action on the reflex centers of the spinal cord and affect all the muscles at a time. These are at first clonic, but eventually, become tonic.
  • During the convulsions, the face is cyanosed and has anxious look, eyes are staring, eyeballs are prominent, and pupils are dilated.

Option A: Cocaine

  • Signs and symptoms of cocaine use include excitability, weight loss, insomnia, irritability, and paranoia. Snorting cocaine may cause a runny nose or nosebleeds. Burns on the lips and fingers and a nagging cough indicate a person has been smoking crack.
  • Appearance: Dilated pupils, Runny nose (snorting), Nosebleeds (snorting), Track marks (injecting), Burned lips or fingers (smoking).
  • Magnan's symptom or cocaine bugs is characteristic of Chronic cocaine poisoning, in which there is a feeling as if grains of sand are lying under the skin or some small insects are creeping on the skin giving rise to an itching sensation (formication, tactile hallucination).

Option C: Codeine

  • Opiates include Heroin, morphine, codeine, methadone, and pethidine. Codeine is a prodrug of morphine mainly used to treat pain, coughing, and diarrhea.
  • Some signs of Codeine abuse include: Drowsiness, Slurred speech, Short attention span, Impaired judgment, Dilated pupils, Lack of coordination, and Apathetic behavior.

Option D: Curare

  • Curare is found in various species of strychnos. Curarine is the active principle. Its action is entirely peripheral and at the myoneural junction, and blocks the postsynaptic nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in muscles, thus causing a flaccid paralysis of skeletal muscles.
  • It causes gradual paralysis of limbs followed by paralysis of respiratory vertigo, mydriasis, blurred vision, and hypotension due to the liberated histamine

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy came to your hospital with complaints of severe abdominal pain. On examination, several new bruises were all over the body. He gives a history of being bullied and punched in the abdomen multiple times forcefully by his classmate. His blood pressure is 140/100 mmHg, and his pulse rate is 102 per minute. The patient is afebrile. Which of the following should be the next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: CT scan of abdomen

  • This patient, with multiple new bruises on the abdomen due to multiple forceful punches, is a case of blunt abdominal injury.
  • Other causes of blunt abdominal trauma are bicycle injuries, injuries sustained during sports activities, or road traffic accidents.
  • It is the most commonly used and better investigation for abdominal trauma.
  • It is useful in blunt, penetrating trauma, pancreatic, spleen, liver, duodenal, and retroperitoneal injuries.
  • Smaller injuries and early haemoperitoneum are better detected.
  • It is noninvasive, highly specific, and highly accurate, with low false positive/ low false negative results. 

Option A: E-FAST

  • Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma (E-FAST)
  • It is an ultrasound type of investigation used if the patient is unstable (systolic BP less than 90 mmHg).
  • It is very useful in viewing the following areas: the right upper quadrant, perisplenic space in the left lower quadrant, pelvis, subcostal or cardiac view, and the parietal or visceral pleural movements.

Option B: Abdominal ultrasound

  • In blunt abdominal injury, the CT scan is the most sensitive and specific test than abdominal ultrasound.

Option D: Peritoneal lavage

  • Intraperitoneal lavage is performed if the patient is unstable (Systolic BP less than 90 mmHg) and the EFAST is not available.
  • Peritoneal lavage can be done when there is a high suspicion of intraperitoneal bleeding.

questions.text: An 18-year-old college student presented to the outpatient department with a complaint of pain and paraesthesia on the right arm. The hands were cold and clammy. She also complained of weakness in her hand while writing. On examination, blood pressure was 120/80 mmHg, and the pulse was 82 beats per minute. There was no history of cyanosis. She was fully vaccinated. Adson’s test was  positive. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Cervical rib

  • Pain and paraesthesia of the arm in a young patient are suggestive of thoracic outlet syndrome. Adson test further confirms the presence of a cervical rib.
  • The cervical rib is a supernumerary rib that arises from the seventh cervical vertebrae. They are present in <1% of the population (70% female.)
  • Most cases are asymptomatic. However, in rare cases, they may cause problems contributing to thoracic outlet syndrome because of pressure on the lower trunk of the brachial plexus or subclavian artery.
  • Compression of the brachial plexus may be identified by the weakness of the muscles of the hand. Compression of the subclavian artery is often diagnosed by a positive adson’s test.
  • Adson’s Test:
    • Locate the radial pulse with the patient sitting or standing.
    • Feel the pulse as you abduct, extend, and externally rotate the patient’s arm.
    • Once in a position, instruct the patient to take a deep breath and hold it and rotate the head towards the tested arm.
    • The test is positive if the pulse is reduced or lost.
    • A positive test indicates a compromise of the subclavian artery.
  • If symptoms are severe, then an excision of the cervical rib is done. Other measures include physiotherapy and electrotherapy.

 

Option A: Peripheral vascular disease

  • Peripheral arterial disease in the legs, also known as a peripheral vascular disease is caused by atheroma in the walls of the arteries leading to insufficient blood flow to the muscles and other tissues.
  • The spectrum of clinical presentation can be classified into three categories:
    • Asymptomatic
    • Intermittent claudication
    • Critical limb ischemia

Option B: Varicose veins

  • Varicose veins are dilated, tortuous, subcutaneous veins, often palpable, >3mm in diameter, measured in an upright position with demonstrable reflux reverse blood flow.
  • Varicose veins present as swelling of the ankle or leg, unsightly appearance, itching and throbbing, reticular threaded veins, and Atrophie Blanche.
  • Varicose veins are managed by graduated compression stockings, sclerotherapy, and laser ablation.

Option D: AV fistula

  • An AV fistula is an irregular connection between an artery and a vein. Blood flows directly from the artery into the vein bypassing capillaries.
  • The signs and symptoms include purplish, bulging veins, swelling, fatigue, and decreased blood pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following best characterizes the use of nitisinone in a patient diagnosed with tyrosinemia type 1?
questions.solution:
Option D: Substrate Reduction Therapy

  • Tyrosinemia type-1 is an inherited autosomal recessive genetic condition. It is caused by mutations in the Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (FAH) gene responsible for synthesizing the FAH enzyme.
  • The deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of fumarylacetoacetate & tyrosine metabolites which get converted to toxic succinylacetone and succinylacetoacetate in the liver, kidney, and CNS, thus leading to manifestations of the disease.
  • Nitisinone is used as a substrate reduction agent, which reduces the amount of substrate converted to toxic metabolites.
  • Nitisinone acts as a 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase inhibitor, thus reducing the conversion of hydroxyphenylpyruvate to homogentisic acid. This consequently results in reduced substrate production (fumarylacetoacetate & maleylacetoacetate) and the culprit metabolite - succinylacetone.

  • Nitisinone is the approved drug used to manage hereditary tyrosinemia type-l. It is used in conjunction with a diet low in amino acids.

Option A: Enzyme Activation Therapy

  • Enzyme activation can be accelerated through biochemical modification of the enzyme (i.e., phosphorylation) or through low molecular weight positive modulators, it is called enzyme activation therapy. 
  • Nitisinone has nothing to do with the enhancement of enzymatic activity.
  • It is the function of CYP-450, it interacts with many of the drugs and reactions including C-hydroxylation, heteroatom oxygenation, heteroatom release (dealkylation), and epoxide formation.

Option B: Enzyme Replacement Therapy

  • Enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) is a medical treatment characterized by the provision of enzymes to patients who suffer from chronic conditions resulting from enzyme deficiencies or malfunction, e.g Cerezyme® (imiglucerase) for Gaucher disease.
  • Nitisinone’s function is only to inhibit the functioning of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase rather than replace it or enhance its function.

Option C: Substrate Addition Therapy

  • There is no such treatment such as Substrate addition therapy.

questions.text: The therapist asks the contamination phobia patient to follow behind him and touch everything he touches. Throughout the process, the therapist speaks to the patient quietly and politely. The technique must be repeated twice a day by the patient. Which of the following term best describes this technique?
questions.solution:
Option B: Modeling

This is an example of participant modeling in which the patient learns by observing and imitating the therapist.

  • Modeling is a method used in certain cognitive-behavioral psychotherapy techniques whereby the client learns by imitation alone, without any specific verbal direction by the therapist, and a general process in which persons serve as models for others, exhibiting the behavior to be imitated by others.
  • This process is most discussed concerning children in developmental psychology.

Option A: Flooding

  • Flooding is a type of behavioral therapy in which maximum stimuli are given in the first response

Option C: Positive reinforcement

  • Positive reinforcement increases the frequency of behavior because of positive consequences.

Option D: Aversion therapy

Aversion therapy-

  • It uses classical Conditioning
  • Helpful in the treatment of unwanted behaviors such as paraphilias

questions.text: A 40-year-old female complaints of muscle weakness, new growth of facial hair, and coarseness of voice. Physical examination revealed purple striae on the abdominal wall and a palpable abdominal mass. A CT scan of the abdomen revealed a heterogeneous adrenal mass of 7cm with indistinct borders and central necrosis. Which of the following is true about the given condition?

choices.text: Most commonly associated with Cushing syndrome

questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above

  • This female presenting with the signs of virilization (new facial hair and coarseness of voice), purple striae, and a heterogenous adrenal mass on abdominal CT scan most likely has adrenocortical carcinoma.
  • ADRENOCORTICAL CARCINOMA (ACC)
    • Rare tumor – incidence is 1 or 2 per million population only.
    • Bimodal age distribution with disease peaks before the age of five and in the fourth to fifth decade of life
    • More aggressive in adults compared to children
    • Women are more common to develop ACC than men - (female-to-male ratio ~ 1.5 to 2.5:1)
    • >50% are functional
    • Cushing’s syndrome is most commonly seen, followed by virilization
    • Radiographic evaluation is done primarily with CT, which typically reveals a heterogeneous mass with irregular or indistinct borders, central necrosis, and invasion of adjacent structures
    • Size of the adrenal mass is the single most important criterion to help diagnose malignancy
    • Metastases to the liver, lung, and lymph nodes may be found
    • Treatment requires radical resection, which is achieved by an open approach
    • Primary chemotherapeutic agent of choice – mitotane (adrenolytic drug that directly suppresses the adrenal cortex)
    • Prognosis is usually poor, even in patients with early-stage adrenocortical tumors.

(Red arrow indicates adrenocortical tumor)

Option A: Rare tumor

  • The incidence of adrenocortical cancer is only 1 or 2 per million.

Option B: More than half are functional

  • Approximately 60% of adrenocortical cancers secrete sufficient hormones to produce symptoms.

Option C: Most commonly associated with Cushing syndrome

  • Approximately 45% of adrenocortical cancers present with Cushing syndrome.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for a surgical procedure. The surgeon wants to perform the surgery through the NOTES procedure. The device shown in the image is a Master and Slave Robotic System used to perform NOTES surgery. In this procedure, the entry point is through which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
Option C: Mouth

  • In NOTES surgery, the peritoneal cavity is accessed via a natural orifice. So the entry point from the given options is the mouth.

Option A: Abdomen

  • The Abdomen does not have a natural orifice; a hole must be made to access the peritoneum.

Option B: Umbilicus

  • There is no natural opening through the umbilicus, so the device cannot be used.

Option D: Axilla

  • The axilla has no orifice to access the cavity.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man had undergone a craniopharyngioma resection five days back. On postoperative Day 6, the patient experienced spikes of fever and a worsening GCS, for which he received an empirical course of antibiotics. A sudden and further drop in the patient’s GCS two days later (from E3V1M5 to E1V2M5) prompted an emergency CT, and the image is shown below. What is the most likely Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Tension pneumocephalus

  • Tension pneumocephalus is a neurosurgical emergency that occurs when subdural air causes a mass effect over the underlying brain parenchyma, often from a ball-valve mechanism causing one-way entry of air into the subdural space.

  • Initially, subdural air compresses the frontal lobes resulting in the peaking sign being present, before the frontal lobes become separated in a characteristic appearance, aptly termed the Mount Fuji sign.

  • An additional reported sign of tension pneumocephalus is the presence of multiple tiny air bubbles in the subarachnoid space. This has been referred to as the air bubble sign.

  • These features are not pathognomonic for tension pneumocephalus and can be seen in patients with normal intracranial pressures. Regardless of the exact pattern of intracranial gas, clinical deterioration is a crucial indicator for surgical intervention.

Option A: Fahr’s disease

  • Fahr syndrome, also known as bilateral striatopallidodentate calcinosis, is characterized by abnormal vascular calcium deposition, particularly in the basal ganglia, cerebellar dentate nuclei, and white matter, with subsequent atrophy.

  • It can be either primary (usually autosomal dominant) or secondary to many underlying illnesses or metabolic disturbances.

CT

  • Calcification is extensive and has a relatively typical distribution 3:

  • Basal ganglia and thalami

    • Symmetric involvement of caudate, lentiform nucleus, thalamus, and dentate nuclei

    • Globus pallidus affected first

    • Subcortical white matter

  • Bilateral calcification of the basal ganglia on neuroimaging or other brain regions, although in isolated cases, patients from families with FIBGC may not present such findings.

Option B: Acute bleed

  • Cerebellar hemorrhages are a common form of intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) and usually occur due to poorly controlled long-standing hypertension, although other causes also exist.

  • When due to chronic hypertension, the stigmata of chronic hypertensive encephalopathy are often present (see: cerebral microhemorrhage).

  • There are many cerebellar hemorrhage causes; this article focuses on primary cerebellar hemorrhages.
    hemorrhage | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org" class="n3VNCb KAlRDb" data-noaft="1" height="139" jsaction="load:XAeZkd;" jsname="HiaYvf" src="https://prod-images-static.radiopaedia.org/images/7330/22801a555da18b0db90674093dcf3a_gallery.jpeg" style="margin: 0px;" width="122" />

Option C:  Chronic bleed

  • Clinical presentation depends on the hemorrhage size. Small cerebellar hemorrhages can present with typical "posterior circulation symptoms" of vertigo, ataxia, nausea, vomiting, and headache.

  • These can be sudden onset and occur during exercise or stress situations.

  • More extensive hemorrhages can present with reduced consciousness.
    subdural haematoma... | Download Scientific Diagram" class="n3VNCb KAlRDb" data-noaft="1" height="159" jsaction="load:XAeZkd;" jsname="HiaYvf" src="https://www.researchgate.net/publication/319281561/figure/fig1/AS:531530646646784@1503738189236/A-Axial-slide-of-a-brain-CT-scan-showing-a-chronic-subdural-haematoma-white-arrow-13.png" style="margin: 0px;" width="269" />

questions.text:
Identify the given sign shown in the chest radiograph:



Which of the following is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option C: Left upper lobe collapse

Luftsichel sign:

  • The luftsichel sign is seen in some cases of left upper lobe collapse.
  • It refers to the frontal chest radiographic appearance due to hyperinflation of the superior segment of the left lower lobe, interposing itself between the mediastinum and the collapsed left upper lobe. 
  • It is derived from the German words “luft”, meaning air, and “Sichel”, meaning sickle, and describes an ‘air crescent’ which may be seen between the aortic arch and the medial border of the collapsed lung.
  • Seen in right lung herniation, lung cancer and pneumomediastinum

Option A: Right upper lobe collapse

  • The luftsichel sign is seen in the left upper lobe collapse, not in the right upper lobe collapse.

Option B: Right middle lobe collapse

  • The above image indicates an important sign of left upper lobe collapse.
  • Lateral projection demonstrates a triangular opacity projecting over the cardiac shadow. The horizontal fissure cannot be identified.

Option D: Left lower lobe collapse

  • Left lower lobe collapse does not give a luftsichel sign.

questions.text:
One of the special steps of the harvesting phase of glycolysis is shown below:



In which of the following cells does this notable step occur?
questions.solution:
Option A: RBCs

  • This is RL shunt, i.e., Rapaport Lubbering shunt/ cycle, which occurs only in RBCs
  • Out of all the glucose entering the RBCs, 10% goes through RL shunt.
  • In RL shunt, substrate level phosphorylation (SLP) step by phosphoglycerate kinase enzyme does not occur. So, the net gain of ATP is zero.
  • RL shunt is essential to produce 2,3-bisphosphoglycerate (2,3 BPG)
  • This compound is required in RBCs to release oxygen from HbA at the tissue level.

Option B: Liver

  • Normal glycolysis occurs in the liver under all conditions. In fasting conditions, glycolysis is slowed down, and energy is used for gluconeogenesis
  • 2,3 BPG has no role in cells other than RBCs

Option C: Muscles

  • Under aerobic conditions or routine work, the muscle cells do perform normal glycolysis with pyruvate as the end product
  • Under anaerobic conditions or strenuous work, muscle cells produce lactate as the end product of glycolysis.

Option D: Brain

  • The brain primarily performs normal glycolysis with pyruvate as an end-product.
  • However, in case of injury or trauma, the brain does produce some lactate by anaerobic glycolysis

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the physician with complaints of joint pain and stiffness that began 6 months ago and has progressively worsened. Her symptoms are worse in the morning and improve with activity. Past medical history includes hypertension controlled with amlodipine and valsartan. On examination, there is redness and swelling of the peripheral joints. Additionally, hyperextension of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints and flexion of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints is seen.. Which of the following drugs would be contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Rofecoxib

  • The patient presents with typical findings of rheumatoid arthritis, i.e., the swan neck deformity of the hand and joint pain that improves with activity.
  • Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disease that causes inflammation of the joint.
  • The clinical feature of rheumatoid arthritis includes joint pain, which is worse in the morning and usually regresses as the day progress.
  • In this disease, usually more than 2 types of joints are involved.
  • Even though NSAIDs are used for pain management in RA.
  • Rofecoxib, a selective COX-2 inhibitor, was withdrawn from the market due to its increased risk of serious cardiovascular events such as heart attack and stroke.

Option B: Prednisolone

  • A glucocorticoid with anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressant action, it is widely used as an adjunct for treating RA.
  • Prednisolone should be started at 30mg daily, gradually reducing in 5mg increments every 2 weeks until therapy is withdrawn after 12 weeks.

Option C: Methotrexate 

  • MTX is recommended as the best initial treatment for patients with RA
  • It inhibits folic acid reductase preventing the formation of tetrahydrofolate, which is necessary for DNA synthesis. Given along with folic acid to reduce side effects.
  • The starting dose is 15mg/week PO, which can be increased up to 25mg/week over 2-4weeks.

Option D: Ibuprofen

  • It is a non-selective reversible inhibitor of COX-1 and COX-2 enzymes. Ibuprofen is a weak anti-inflammatory agent and doesn't slow the disease progression in RA. It is mostly used to manage pain and symptoms.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with headache, diaphoresis, flushing, palpitations,. He had a brother who had died of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid. Which of the following investigations would be required to diagnose this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Fractionated plasma metanephrines

  • MEN-2 syndrome has been diagnosed. The patient has symptoms of pheochromocytoma, so levels of fractionated plasma metanephrine should be evaluated.
  • Pheochromocytoma: 
    • It is a tumor of the enterochromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.
    • It affects men and women equally, and the incidence is in the age 40 to 50 years.
    • The patient presents with a classic triad of headache, diaphoresis, and palpitations.
    • Hypertension is present in 90% of cases.
    • The main hormone secreted by adrenal pheochromocytomas - Epinephrine. The main hormone secreted by extra-adrenal pheochromocytomas - Norepinephrine ( as they lack phenylethanolamine N-methyltransferase )

Option A: Chest X-ray

  • Pheochromocytoma is a disease of the adrenal gland where excessive catecholamine synthesis due to the tumor activity causes symptoms of hypertension, headache, palpitations, and diaphoresis. As part of the MEN syndrome, where pheochromocytoma occurs alongside medullary thyroid cancer, a chest X-ray is not needed for diagnosis.

Option B: Measurement of 5-HIAA

  • The excessive synthesis of serotonin causes serotonin syndrome. Such patients present with flushing skin, diarrhea, vomiting, sweating, shivering, muscle twitching, involuntary contractions, muscle spasms, and rigidity. This patient has no such symptoms.
  • The end product of serotonin metabolism is 5-HIAA, which is used to diagnose serotonin syndrome.

Option D: Intravenous pyelography

  • Intravenous pyelography is an x-ray exam that uses an injection of contrast material to evaluate the kidneys, ureter, and urinary bladder to help diagnose blood in the urine or pain in the kidneys
  • This patient has symptoms of pheochromocytoma and requires evaluation of the adrenal glands and not of the kidneys.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has come to the outpatient department, reporting a firm swelling in his right scrotum and a dull ache in his lower groin. During the physical examination, a mass was found in his testicles. Immunohistochemistry tests showed that the placental alkaline phosphatase marker was positive. All of the vital signs are within normal range. Which of the following is associated with the placental alkaline phosphatase marker?
questions.solution:
Testicular cancer is the most common cancer in men age 20 to 40 years. Testicular tumours may be germ cell tumours or those that arise from stromal cells (Leydig or Sertoli cells)

Germ cell tumours can be classified as either seminomatous or non-seminomatous.

Seminoma constitutes more than 50% of all testicular tumours. Most seminomas do not produce tumour markers but the presence of syncytiotrophoblastic giant cells in a minority of cases accounts for modest elevations of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG). Seminomas never produce alpha fetoprotein (AFP) . Immunohistochemistry is usually positive for placental alkaline phosphates (PLAP); negative for CD30, AFP and epithelial membrane antigen (EMA)

Nonseminomatous germ cell tumours can be divided into the following histologic types:

  • Embryonal carcinoma: highly malignant tumours that occasionally invade cord structures. It is the most undifferentiated type of germ cell tumour and is thought to be pluripotent. On immunohistochemical staining, embryonal carcinoma can be positive for cytokeratin, CD30,PLAP,AFP and hCG. Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) concentration in the serum is an important prognostic factor in metastatic embryonal carcinoma that is marker negative
  • Yolk sac tumour: tumours with this component secrete alpha-fetoprotein (AFP). Immunostaining is diffusely positive for AFP and may also be positive for cytokeratin, SALL4, glipican-3, PLAP and CD117
  • Choriocarcinoma: They strongly express human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG). This is a highly malignant tumour that metastasises early via both the lymphatics and the bloodstream. It is composed of both cytotrophoblasts and syncytiotrophoblasts
  • Teratoma: These tumours contain more than one cell type with components derived form ectoderm, endoderm and mesoderm. They do not produce elevated AFP or hCG. Patients with elevated serum AFP and /or hCG should be assumed to have a non-teratoma germ cell tumour component unless the elevation can be otherwise explained

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented in the outpatient department with the complaint of recent onset of rash that involved his upper arms. The patient was otherwise healthy, with no known allergies, medication or chemical exposure. The physical examination revealed multiple hypopigmented, slightly scaly patches on both arms. The culture was isolated, but the microbiologist could not get any results on regular SDA media. Which of the following fungi is difficult to isolate on Regular SDA media?
questions.solution:
Option D: Malassezia furfur

  • Malassezia furfur causes superficial mycoses limited only to the stratum corneum.
  • Malassezia furfur is a lipophilic, yeast-like fungus.
  • This fungus causes Pityriasis Versicolor, which is more prevalent in the tropics.
  • Malassezia furfur cannot be detected in the conventional culture media because the yeast requires fatty acids for growth.
  • Lipid-rich culture media are effective for Malassezia furfur cultivation.
  • Malassezia furfur can be cultured in Sabouraud’s dextrose agar overlayed with a layer of olive oil.
  • On incubation at 37 degrees Celcius, the fungus produces creamy or fried egg colonies within 5 to 7 days.

 

 Option A: Candida

  • Candida is diploid, gram-positive fungus.
  • It is a dimorphic fungus.
  • Candida can readily be grown on Sabouraud's dextrose agar or other ordinary bacteriological culture media.
  • Colonies of Candida are creamy white, smooth and with a yeasty odour.

Candida on SDA: creamy, pasty colonies. (Image below)

 

Option B: Dermatophytes

  • Dermatophytes are keratinophilic fungi.
  • Dermatophytes infect keratinized structures, i.e., skin, hair, and nails.
  • They are classified into three genera:
  • Microsporum
  • Trichophyton
  • Epidermophyton
  • Dermatophytes can be grown by inoculating the specimen on Sabouraud’s dextrose agar.
  • Sometimes, antibiotics are added to avoid bacterial contamination of the culture.

Dermatophytes on SDA: Images below

Trichophyton:

 

Microsporum:

 

 

Epidermophyton:

 

 

Option C: Cryptococcus

  • Cryptococcus is a soil saprophyte.
  • It is found abundantly in the faeces of pigeons and other birds.
  • Infection is usually acquired through inhalation and may manifest as:
  • Pulmonary cryptococcosis
  • Disseminated infection
  • Cryptococcal meningitis
  • The fungus can be grown readily on Sabouraud’s dextrose agar.
  • Smooth, mucoid, cream-coloured colonies are seen on Sabouraud's dextrose agar culture medium

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the ENT outpatient department due to a left-sided neck lump for 6 months. The lump is hard and non-painful. It is associated with left-sided hearing loss and nasal regurgitation of food. He has had a medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for 10 years. He has smoked 3 packs per day of tobacco for 25 years. Which of the following is most likely to be associated with this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Option C: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)

 

 

  • The Chinese population has a higher susceptibility to nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • Epstein-Barr (EB) virus is closely related to nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • EB virus has two important antigens: Viral capsid antigen (VCA) and early antigen (EA).
  • IgA antibodies of EA are highly specific for nasopharyngeal cancer but have a sensitivity of only 70–80%, while IgA antibodies of VCA are more sensitive but less specific.
