  • IgA antibodies against both EA and VCA should be used to screen patients for nasopharyngeal cancer.
  • Environmental factors include polluted air, tobacco smoke, opium, nitrosamine from dry salted fish, and smoke from incense and wood.
  • Clinical features include nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, denasal speech, conductive hearing loss, and serous or suppurative otitis media due to eustachian tube blockage.
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma can be proliferative, ulcerative, or infiltrative.
  • Tumors extending into the surroundings involve CN II, III, IV, V, VI, IX, and X.
  • The cervical nodal enlargement usually occurs between the jaw angle and the mastoid.
  • Distant metastasis is to the bone, lung, liver, and other sites.
  • Investigations include endoscopic evaluation and biopsy. Imaging studies such as CT scans and MRI of the nasopharynx show the primary growth, erosion of skull base and clivus, and extensions into the parapharyngeal, retropharyngeal and intracranial space.
  • An audiogram establishes the diagnosis of serous otitis media.
  • Treatment is based on the stage of carcinoma. Stage I and II are treated with radiotherapy. Stages III and IV require chemoradiation.

Option A:  Cytomegalovirus (CMV)

It is an incorrect option because:

  • CMV can cause permanent hearing loss congenitally.
  • Infections causing hearing loss include congenital conditions such as rubella and cytomegalovirus (CMV) and childhood infections such as mumps, measles, meningitis, and chronic otitis media.
  • CMV is associated with lymphomas.

Option B: Human papillomavirus (HPV)

It is an incorrect option because:

  • HPV is related to cancers of the oropharynx.
  • It is not associated with nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

Option D: Helicobacter pylori (H. Pylori)

It is an incorrect option because:

  • H. Pylori is usually associated with GI malignancies and transformation.
  • It is not associated with nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male presents to the pediatric clinic with complaints of the passage of dark-coloured urine with reduced urine output for two days. Physical examination shows signs of pallor, jaundice, and a distended abdomen. He is tachycardic and tachypneic on vital monitoring. Investigations show anaemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated blood urea nitrogen and serum creatinine. Urinalysis shows hemoglobinuria and proteinuria. The peripheral blood smear shows the presence of helmet cells. Which of the following will be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option A: Haemolytic uremic syndrome: HUS is characterized by the triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (evidenced by symptoms like dark-colored urine, pallor, and jaundice), thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), and acute kidney injury (elevated blood urea nitrogen and serum creatinine). Urinalysis showing hemoglobinuria and proteinuria is consistent with kidney involvement. The presence of helmet cells on the peripheral blood smear further supports the diagnosis. HUS is often associated with E. coli O157:H7 infections or other causes of Shiga toxin production

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Polysplenia syndrome: Polysplenia syndrome is a rare congenital condition characterized by multiple small spleens, not typically associated with the symptoms and findings described in the case.

Option C: Spherocytosis: Hereditary spherocytosis is a congenital hemolytic anemia caused by defects in red blood cell membrane proteins. While it can cause anemia and jaundice, it is not typically associated with the acute kidney injury and thrombocytopenia seen in HUS.

Option D:  Acanthocytosis: 

  • Acanthocytosis refers to the presence of abnormally shaped red blood cells (acanthocytes) and is associated with conditions like neuroacanthocytosis syndromes. It is not typically associated with the constellation of symptoms seen in HUS.

Given the clinical presentation, laboratory findings, and peripheral blood smear results, Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) is the most likely diagnosis. Prompt medical attention and management are crucial in HUS, as it can lead to serious complications, particularly kidney injury.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents to the pulmonology ward with a complaint of cough with sputum, fever and chills from the last 3 days. The attending pulmonologist examines him and sends his sputum specimen for culture. The specimen is cultured on 5% blood agar by a microbiologist. The culture shows the presence of α-hemolytic colonies on the next day. After the further processing of this organism, what is most likely it will yield?

choices.text: Gram-positive cocci in short chains, catalase-negative and bile resistant
Gram-positive cocci in pairs, catalase-negative and bile soluble
Gram-positive cocci in clusters, catalase positive and coagulase positive
Gram-negative coccobacilli, catalase positive and oxidase positive

questions.solution:
Option B: Gram-positive cocci in pairs, catalase-negative and bile soluble

  • The further processing of this organism is most likely to yield Gram-positive cocci in pairs, catalase-negative and bile soluble.
  • α-hemolytic colonies are shown by Streptococcus pneumoniae and Viridians Streptococci.
  • A sputum sample is taken for diagnosis of upper and lower respiratory infections.
  • Out of these, respiratory infection is caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae and hence is the probable organism.

Streptococcus pneumoniae:

  • Gram-positive cocci in pairs ,Catalase negative and bile soluble
  • Form α-hemolytic colonies (Greenish colonies) on blood agar
  • Optochin sensitive (See image).
  • Responsible for the majority of community-acquired pneumonia.

S. aureus

  • Gram-positive cocci in clusters (See image),catalase positive
  • coagulase positive, Beta hemolytic

Brucella

  • Gram-negative coccobacilli, catalase positive and oxidase positive
  • Blood culture is done, not sputum culture

Option A: Gram-positive cocci in short chains, catalase-negative and bile resistance

  • Viridians Streptococci - Gram-positive cocci in short chains, Catalase negative and bile resistant
  • Viridians Streptococci are part of normal oral flora.
  • Cause of late-onset prosthetic valve endocarditis and subacute bacterial endocarditis.

Option C: Gram-positive cocci in clusters, catalase positive and coagulase positive

  • S. aureus - Gram-positive cocci in clusters , catalase positive , coagulase positive
  • Beta hemolytic

Option D: Gram-negative coccobacilli, catalase positive and oxidase positive

  • Brucella -Gram-negative coccobacilli , catalase positive and oxidase positive
  • Blood culture is done, not sputum culture

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the physician with complaints of stiff and painful muscles, jaw cramping and trouble swallowing for eight days. He further explains that he has jerky movements in his muscles. He has on and off fever. On processing the sample and staining, the microscopy showed drum stick appearance spores. The mechanism of action of the toxin produced by the pathogen involved in this condition is:
questions.solution:
Option A: Inhibition of GABA release

  • This is a case of tetanus in which the patient presents with complaints of stiff and painful muscles, jaw cramping and trouble swallowing.
  • The mechanism of action of toxins is the Inhibition of GABA release.
  • Tetanospasmin produced by Clostridium tetani is responsible for the above clinical condition.

Clostridium tetani produce

  • Tetanolysin: heat labile, oxygen labile hemolysin. It plays no role in pathogenesis.

  • Tetanospasmin or tetanus toxin (TT): neurotoxin responsible for the pathogenesis of tetanus:
  • It is oxygen stable but heats labile; coded by the plasmid.
  • Mechanism of action: Toxin acts pre-synaptically at the inhibitory neuron terminals and prevents the release of the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA and glycine → leading to spastic muscle contraction.

Clinical features:

  • Lock Jaw (Trismus)

  • Opisthotonus Posture (Bad prognosis)
  • ↑ Deep tendon reflexes
  • Strychnine poisoning has a similar mechanism, except that it acts post-synaptically.

Option B: Inhibition of cAMP

  • Tetanospasmin inhibits the GABA release.

  • It doesn't inhibit cAMP.

Option C: Inactivation of Ach receptors

  • BT (Botulinum Toxin) blocks the release of acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction, which leads to flaccid paralysis.

Option D: Inhibition of cGMP

  • In this disease, the toxin acts presynaptically at the inhibitory neuron terminals and prevents the release of GABA. Thus, it doesn't inhibit cGMP.

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic smoker presents to the physician's clinic with complaints of hoarseness and foreign body sensation in the neck for the past few weeks. The laryngoscopic examination revealed the findings, as seen in the image below. Which of the following will be the most common site of distant metastasis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Lung

Laryngeal carcinoma:

  • Laryngeal carcinoma is the commonest head and neck malignancy comprising 30%-40% of all cases, the vast majority being squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Most commonly present with hoarseness of voice; less commonly with a neck mass, dysphagia, stridor, or hemoptysis.
  • Around 80% of tumors are glottic from the vocal cords, 15% are supraglottic, arising from the epiglottis, false cords, or aryepiglottic folds, and 5% are subglottic.
  • Local spread is along tissue planes, while the lymphatic spread is at the free edge of the glottis.
  • The most common site of loco-regional metastasis from laryngeal carcinoma is lymph nodes.
  • The most common site of distant metastasis from laryngeal carcinoma is the lungs.
  • The most common site of laryngeal carcinoma is the glottis.
  • The most common type of laryngeal carcinoma is squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Laryngeal cancer metastases are most typically noted in the loco-regional cervical lymph nodes. Distant metastases are seen mostly in the lungs (66%), bone (22%), liver (10%), mediastinum, and bone marrow.

Option A: Liver

  • Distant metastasis occurs in the lungs, liver, and bone; however, the most common site of distant metastasis is the lungs.

Option C: Brain

  • Distant metastasis occurs in the lungs, liver, bones, and brain; however, the most common site of distant metastasis is the lungs.

Option D: Bone

  • Distant metastasis occurs in the lungs, liver, and bone; however, the most common site of distant metastasis is the lungs.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male presents to the ENT outpatient department with a hoarse voice and episodes of cough with bleeding for two weeks. He also has had a poor build and weight loss for the last 6 months. His temperature is 101 °F, his blood pressure is 126/76 mmHg, his pulse is 56 bpm, and his respiratory rate is 21/min. A laryngoscopic examination is done, and multiple ulcerations are seen on vocal folds, as shown below:



Which of the following is not associated with the above condition?

choices.text: Hyperemia of the vocal cord with impairment of adduction is the first sign.
Vocal cords show mouse nibbled appearance

questions.solution:
Option B: Hoarseness is the earliest symptom

  • Tuberculosis laryngitis is commonly associated with pulmonary Tuberculosis.
  • Weakness of voice with periods of aphonia is the earliest symptom.
  • Other symptoms include hoarseness, cough, dysphagia, odynophagia, and referred otalgia.
  • The first sign on laryngeal examination shows hyperemia of the vocal cord with impairment of adduction.
  • Characteristic feature includes vocal cords showing shallow ulcers with undermined edges, also known as mouse nibbled appearance.
  • Pseudoedema of the epiglottis called Turban epiglottis can be seen.
  • Swelling in the inter-arytenoid region gives a mammillated appearance.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed using chest X-ray and sputum for AFB.
  • Treatment is antitubercular treatment.

Option A: Commonly associated with pulmonary Tuberculosis

This is false because:

  • Tuberculosis laryngitis is commonly associated with pulmonary TB.

Option C: Hyperemia of the vocal cord with impairment of adduction is the first sign.

This is false because:

  • Hyperemia of the vocal cord with impairment of adduction is the first sign of Tuberculosis laryngitis.

Option D: Vocal cords show mouse nibbled appearance

This is false because:

  • Vocal cords show mouse nibbled appearance in Tuberculosis laryngitis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man comes to the emergency department complaining of pain and swelling in his left wrist for the last 2 hours. The pain started when he fell on his outstretched hand while playing cricket. Physical examination reveals a tender swelling of the left wrist with a limited range of motion. An x-ray of the left wrist is performed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis according to the x-ray shown below?
questions.solution:
Option D: Colles fracture

  • In the x-rays above, there is a fracture of the distal radius.
  • In the left-most x-ray, there is a significant dorsal deviation of the fractured distal segment of the radius that is indicative of Colles fracture.

Colles fracture:

  • Cause: The most common cause of it is a fall on an outstretched hand with a dorsiflexed wrist.
  • In Colles fracture, there is a fracture of the distal 2 cm of the radius.
  • The distal fragment is displaced dorsally.
  • As a result, there is a posterior angulation in the forearm just proximal to the wrist, which gives its name "dinner fork deformity."
  • There is a good blood supply to the distal region of the radius, so the union of bone is normally good.
  • Diagnosis: It is usually made with the help of an x-ray.
  • Treatment:
  • Conservative: Closed reduction with a cast. The cast is usually removed at 6 weeks.
  • Indication for surgery: Open fracture, significantly displaced, and neurovascular damage.

Option A: Scaphoid fracture

  • The scaphoid fracture on x-ray looks like this:

  • In scaphoid fractures, there is a high risk of avascular necrosis of the proximal segment of the bone.

Option B: Hutchinson fracture

  • In Hutchinson fracture, there is an avulsion fracture of the styloid process of the radius.

Option C: Smith fracture

  • In the Smith fracture, the fractured distal segment of the radius is displaced vulgarly, 
  • It is caused by a fall on the palmar-flexed wrist.

questions.text: Which of the following promotes rouleaux formation?
questions.solution:
Option B: Fibrinogen

  • The rouleaux formation is caused by increased cathodal proteins, such as immunoglobulins and fibrinogen.

Rouleaux formation:

  • When in circulation, the negative charge on the RBC membrane (or zeta potential) does not allow RBCs to clump.
  • When blood is made to stand in a vertical tube, the asymmetric macromolecules in the plasma overcome the zeta potential to form the rouleaux and settle down the RBC clumps.
  • Fibrinogen and gamma-globulins are examples of such asymmetric macromolecules.
  • Plasma albumin retards the rouleaux formation. Hence, there is a rise in ESR in nephrotic syndrome, where the albumin levels fall.
  • Biconcave shape of RBC: Both sides of the cell's surface curve inward like the interior of a sphere. This shape aids in a red blood cell's ability to maneuver through tiny blood vessels to deliver oxygen to organs and tissues.

Option A: Zeta potential on RBC membrane

  • When blood is made to stand in a vertical tube, the asymmetric macromolecules in the plasma overcome the zeta potential to form the rouleaux and settle down the RBC clumps.

Option C: Albumin

  • Plasma albumin retards the rouleaux formation. Hence, there is a rise in ESR in nephrotic syndrome, where the albumin levels fall.

Option D: Biconcave shape of RBC

  • The red blood cells are anucleate erythrocytes, biconcave, donut-shaped in appearance, more spaced to take gases like O2, CO2, and flexible so that they can pass even through tiny blood vessels easily.

questions.text: A 30-year-old welder has been admitted with complaints of shortness of breath for the last 73 hours. Features look like Parkinson's disease and symptoms resemble that of malaria. The zinc level was elevated. His colleagues informed him that they had all experienced these symptoms early in their careers but were now free of symptoms. Which statement among the following is not true regarding the diagnosis?

choices.text: It is not due to Manganese
Preventive measures such as working in well-ventilated areas and using appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) can help reduce the risk of metal fume fever.
The syndrome resembles a flu-like illness which starts 6 to 8 hours after exposure of fumes, with fever, chills, cough, dyspnoea, cyanosis, myalgia, salivation sweating and tachycardia.
Symptoms subside in 36 hours after stoppage of exposure

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Option A - It is not due to Manganese:

  • Metal fume fever, also known as "welder's fever" or "brass founders' ague," is an occupational health condition caused by the inhalation of metal fumes, particularly those containing zinc. However, it is not typically associated with manganese exposure.

Incorrect choices:

Option B - Preventive measures such as working in well-ventilated areas and using appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) can help reduce the risk of metal fume fever: Working in well-ventilated areas and wearing appropriate PPE, such as respirators, can help reduce the risk of exposure to metal fumes.

Option C - The syndrome resembles a flu-like illness which starts 6 to 8 hours after exposure of fumes, with fever, chills, cough, dyspnoea, cyanosis, myalgia, salivation sweating and tachycardia: Metal fume fever typically presents with flu-like symptoms which usually occur within a few hours after exposure to metal fumes.

Option D - Symptoms subside in 36 hours after stoppage of exposure: The symptoms of metal fume fever usually resolve within a day or so after exposure to the metal fumes is discontinued.

questions.text: Village health nutrition has the purpose to improve access to maternal, newborn, and child health and nutrition services at the village level. When is Village health nutrition day (VHND) observed?
questions.solution:
Option B: Every month

  • Village health nutrition day (VHND) is observed ‘Once every month’ in every village.
  • It is organized by the Anganwadi center.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with dyspepsia, heartburn, and abdominal discomfort, experiencing postprandial nausea, and denies shortness of breath or chest pain. Advised lifestyle changes and a prokinetic drug. Which drug targets serotonin receptors?
questions.solution:
Option D: Mosapride

  • Dyspepsia, heartburn, abdominal discomfort and nausea suggest that the patient has gastro-oesophageal reflux disease. Prokinetics were given to enhance gut motility.
  • Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease is the most common disease characterized by heartburn and regurgitation.
  • Treatment of GERD is based primarily on the following;
    • Lifestyle modifications (walking, intake of short meals at frequent intervals, avoidance of over-the-counter use of painkillers, decreased intake of beverages and caffeine)
    • H2 receptor antagonists and proton pump inhibitors.
  • Mosapride is a selective 5-hydroxytryptamine type 4 (5 – HT4) agonist.
  • It has been used in patients with upper gastrointestinal disorders by shortening gastric emptying.
  • Mosapride causes enhancement of oesophagal motor function and acceleration of gastric emptying.
  • Proton pump inhibitors result in delayed gastric emptying, which was normalized by the use of mosapride.
  • Mosapride, unlike tegaserod, is a safe drug as it does not cause QT prolongation.

Option A: Chlorpromazine

  • Chlorpromazine is a typical antipsychotic drug, also known as a first-generation antipsychotic.
  • Its antipsychotic effect is due to blockade at the D2 receptor in the mesolimbic pathway.
  • The anti-emetic effect of chlorpromazine results from the blockade of histamine H1, dopamine D2 and muscarinic M1 receptors in the vomiting centre in the medulla.

Option B: Metoclopramide

  • Metoclopramide promotes gut motility by the following mechanisms;
    • Inhibition of presynaptic and postsynaptic D2 receptors
    • Stimulation of presynaptic excitatory 5-HT4 receptors
    • Inhibition of presynaptic muscarinic receptors
  • Metoclopramide is currently the only medication approved for the treatment of gastroparesis.

Option C: Domperidone

  • Domperidone is a D2 receptor antagonist that increases acetylcholine release and stimulates gastrointestinal motility.
  • It cannot cross the blood-brain barrier.
  • It is less efficacious than metoclopramide but does not have extrapyramidal and hyperprolactinemic side effects.

questions.text: Which of the following parts of the axillary artery gives the branch for anastomosis around the 'surgical' neck of the humerus region?
questions.solution:
Option C: 3rd part of axillary artery

  • Anastomosis is a connection between two vessels.
  • It provides an alternative source for blood flow.
  • The main advantage of anastomosis is that when one source is blocked or compromised, the other source or other artery compensates.
  • Arteries forming anastomosis around the surgical neck of the humerus are:

Anterior circumflex humeral arteries

Posterior circumflex humeral arteries

  • Both are branches of 3rd part of the axillary artery.

Option A: 1st part of axillary artery

  • The first part of the Axillary Artery is not involved in anastomosis (only 3rd part is involved).

Option B: 2nd part of axillary artery

  • The second part of the Axillary Artery is not involved in anastomosis.

Option D: Subclavian artery

  • The subclavian artery doesn't provide any branch for anastomosis around the surgical neck of the humerus.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of hyperpigmentation and fever for 2 days. The doctor prescribed him medication. A few days later, he again presented with fever and hyperpigmentation, which showed a typical pattern of the double rise of temperature in 24 hours. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Kala-azar

  • This is a case of kala-azar in which the patient presents with complaints of fever and hyperpigmentation of the skin.
  • A double rise in temperature in 24 hours is seen in the case of Kala-azar.
  • L. donovani, infection of the classic kala-azar ("black sickness") or dumdum fever type, occurs in many parts of Asia, Africa, and Southeast Asia.
  • Vector: Phlebotomus
  • Infective Form→ Promastigote
  • Kala-Azar Fever: In the early stages of the disease, there is a mild irregular fever becoming intermittent at a later stage, and in 20% of cases, pyrexia shows a double rise in 24 hrs.
  • Bone marrow involvement leads to:
    • Anaemia, leucopenia, thrombocytopenia
    • Hypergammaglobulinemia
    • Fever and hyperpigmentation + hepatosplenomegaly seen
    • In HIV +ve → hepatosplenomegaly is absent (atypical presentation)

Option B: Malaria

  • The classic symptom of malaria: is a cyclical occurrence of sudden coldness followed by shivering and then fever and sweating.
  • Tertian fever: occurring every two days in P. vivax and P. ovale infections
  • Quartan fever: every three days for P. malariae.
  • P. falciparum infection can cause recurrent fever every 36–48 hours or a less pronounced and almost continuous fever.

Option C: Tuberculosis

  • Tuberculosis is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • The Patient with T.B. clinically presents with symptoms of fever, productive cough, and weight loss.

Option D: Hodgkin’s lymphoma

  • Hodgkin's lymphoma: Pel-Ebstein fever pattern
  • Pel-Ebstein fever pattern: episodic fever at various times of day and in various intervals, typically consisting of a three to ten-day period of fever, followed by a three to ten-day period of apyrexia.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to the emergency department in an unconscious state. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 185/110 mm Hg. A head CT scan without contrast reveals a hemorrhagic stroke in the lower pons, leaving the upper pons intact. Which of the following specific findings could be present in this patient?

choices.text: No change in pattern of breathing

questions.solution:
Option B: Rapid, shallow breathing

  • Upper pons has a pneumotaxic centre, which sends signals to the respiratory centre in the medulla.
  • The pneumotaxic centre contains neurons that are responsible for inspiration as well as expiration.
  • It is regulated by afferent pulmonary vagal fibres and apneustic centre in the lower pons.
  • Damage to the apneustic centre in the lower pons leads to unregulated and excessive discharge from the pneumotaxic centre.
  • This causes rapid and shallow breathing in a patient with damaged lower pons.

Option A: Apneusis

  • Apneustic centre is present in the lower pons, which is responsible for prolonging the inspiratory phase of respiration.
  • Apneusis is a respiratory system regulation disorder characterized by an excessively prolonged inspiratory phase.
  • Damage to the upper pons causes the unregulated discharge of neurons from the apneustic centre in the lower pons.
  • This leads to prolonged inspiration and causes respiration to be slow and deep.

Option C: Irregular gasping type of breathing

  • Irregular gasping type of breathing is characterized by involuntary respirations caused by low oxygen levels in the blood.
  • The brainstem is activated in this type of breathing.
  • Damage to pons will not result in a gasping type of breathing.

Option D: No change in the pattern of breathing

  • The breathing pattern is regulated by the coordinated action of the medulla and pons.
  • Damage to any one of these will always result in a change in the breathing pattern.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female is scheduled to undergo a rotator cuff repair. Her medical history is significant for severe asthma and gastroesophageal reflux disease, both of which are only moderately well controlled. She has no medication allergies but is allergic to eggs and soy. If performing general anaesthesia with an endotracheal tube on this patient, which of the following induction agents would be ideal?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ketamine

  • Ketamine is an ideal agent for anaesthetic induction in this patient due to its strong bronchodilator properties and a minimal amount of respiratory depression.

Option A: Propofol

  • Propofol effectively blunts the airway reflex response to laryngoscopy and is often used as an induction agent in stable asthmatic patients despite it not being a bronchodilator. However, the drug is carried in an egg or soy protein emulsion. Therefore, it can cause bronchospasm in asthmatic patients who have egg or soy allergies.

Option B: Thiopental

  • Thiopental is a barbiturate, a class of drugs which does not depress the airway reflex response to laryngoscopy that may lead to bronchospasm in asthmatic patients.

Option D: Desflurane

  • Desflurane is an inhaled anaesthetic that has significant airway-irritating properties. Therefore, it can cause bronchospasm in asthmatics.

questions.text: A 7-month-old male has been brought to the emergency department unconscious.  On examination, the baby does not have a pulse. His blood pressure is not recordable. Which of the following is the least likely included in the ACLS guideline?

choices.text: Compressions: ventilation ratio is 15:2 when more than one rescuer is present in an infant
The ratio of chest compression to rescue breaths is 30:2 for a single rescuer
The depth of compression should be more than or equal to one-third of the anteroposterior diameter of the chest

questions.solution:
Option B: Brachial pulse check every 2 minutes

  • The Carotid artery, instead of the brachial artery, should be checked
  • CPR:
    • In children, the more common cause of cardiac arrest is asphyxia rather than ventricular.
    • Even though asphyxia is the more common cause, pediatric Resuscitation starts with chest compressions rather than rescue breaths as in adults for simplicity in training.
    • This is because the cycle of 30 chest compressions before rescue breathing delays ventilation for only 15 to 20 seconds.
    • During cardiopulmonary Resuscitation of infants and children, the ratio of chest compression to rescue breaths is 30:2 for a single rescuer and 15:2 if 2 or more rescuers are present.
    • The initial energy for defibrillation is at 2 J/kg for both monophasic and biphasic waveforms. It can be increased to 4 J/kg if a second shock is delivered. In adults, the ratio is 30:2, irrespective of the number of rescuers.
    • In infants and children, the compression depth should be more than or equal to one-third of the anteroposterior diameter of the chest, which is about 5 cm in children and 4 cm in infants.
    • The compression rate should be 100-120/ minute.
    • Allow complete chest recoil after each compression.
    • Minimize interruptions in compressions (10 seconds or less).
    • Rotate the compressor every 2 minutes or earlier if fatigued.
    • Avoid excessive ventilation.
    • When a pulse check is performed for a victim >1 year of age, the carotid artery is the preferred artery to palpate. However, the femoral artery may be used as an alternative.
    • Pulses persist in these arteries even when hypotension and poor perfusion cause peripheral pulses to disappear.
    • To locate the carotid artery, maintain a head tilt with one hand on the victim’s forehead and locate the trachea with 2 or 3 fingers.
    • Slide these 2 or 3 fingers into the groove between the trachea and the muscles at the side of the neck, where the carotid pulse can be felt. Use only gentle pressure so that you do not compress the artery. The artery on the side of the neck toward you is typically most readily palpated.

 

    • For an infant, it is easiest to check for a pulse using the brachial artery. To locate the brachial artery, place 2 or 3 fingers on the inside of the upper arm between the shoulder and elbow.
    • Press the fingers gently for less than 10 seconds to feel a pulse.
    • Pushing too firmly may occlude the infant’s pulse.
    • The carotid pulse is felt for not more than 10 sec.
    • Healthcare providers should perform a pulse check in conjunction with an assessment for signs of circulation.
    • If you are not confident that circulation is present, begin chest compressions immediately.

Option A: Compressions: ventilation ratio is 15:2 when more than one rescuer is present in an infant

  • Compression: A ventilation ratio of 15:2 is recommended when more than one rescuer is present.

Option C: The ratio of chest compression to rescue breaths is 30:2 for a single rescuer

  • For a single rescuer chest compression to rescue breath ratio is 30:2

Option D: The depth of compression should be more than or equal to one-third of the anteroposterior diameter of the chest

  • According to ACLS guidelines, the depth of the compressions should be equal to or more than one-third of the anteroposterior diameter.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida, 38 weeks pregnant, presented to the labour room in active labour. She is a case of a ventricular septal defect which was corrected. What are the most appropriate anaesthetic considerations for this patient?

choices.text: Elective cesarean section with spinal anesthesia and invasive monitoring

questions.solution:
Option A: No special consideration

  • An epidural should be used to treat mild to severe heart problems.
  • No specific concerns exist for a corrected ventricular septal defect with no residual flaws.
  • Pregnant women with Eisenmenger syndrome require invasive cardiovascular monitoring, and in severe heart disease, general anaesthesia is necessary.
  • A spinal anaesthetic is preferable over other procedures for an elective caesarean section.

Option B: Invasive monitoring and general anaesthesia

  • Disadvantages of general anaesthesia include the following:
    • Pulmonary aspiration of stomach contents
    • Difficult or unsuccessful intubation
    • Drug exposure to the foetus

Option C: General anaesthesia always

  • In some emergencies, general anaesthesia is preferable, such as;
    • Massive bruising (placenta previa or accreta, abruption placentae, or uterine rupture)
    • Coagulopathy
    • Instability of the heart
    • Fetal distress syndrome
    • Maternal trauma

Option D: Elective cesarean section with spinal anaesthesia and invasive monitoring

  • The benefits of spinal anaesthesia over general anaesthesia include:
    • Less newborn exposure to potentially depressing medications;
    • Lower risk of maternal pulmonary aspiration
    • An awake mother throughout childbirth
    • Spinal opioids can be administered for postoperative pain management.
  • The following are the advantages of spinal anaesthesia over epidural anaesthesia:
    • A quick and predictable
    • Complete block (lower failure rate)
    • The lower danger of systemic toxicity or high spinal owing to inadvertent intravascular or intrathecal infusion seen with epidural anaesthesia
    • More cost-effective

questions.text: Which of the following is the component of the Weaning criteria of ventilation?
questions.solution:
Option B: Tidal Volume: 6 ml/kg

  • Weaning criteria is a set of more universally acceptable minimums for criteria that indicate further weaning and/or PPV removal readiness.
  • It comprises certain clinical, ventilatory, oxygenation and pulmonary measures.
  • Among the given options, a tidal volume of 6 ml/kg fits the weaning criteria and is, therefore, the correct answer.

Option A: Vital capacity: >15 mL/kg

  • As per weaning criteria, a Vital capacity: >10 mL/kg is a requirement in trying to wean the patient off.

Option C: Minute ventilation: <12 L/min

  • As per weaning criteria, Minute ventilation: <10 L/min is a requirement trying to wean the patient off.

Option D: Rapid shallow breathing index: <120

  • As per weaning criteria, a Rapid shallow breathing index: <100 is a requirement trying to wean the patient off.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the clinic with the complaint of abdominal pain for the past 2 years. She states that she frequently has cramps and lower abdominal pain that lasts for a few days and is usually at the same time every month. She has not attained menarche yet, and she attained breast and pubic hair development at 12. On examination, she has a moderately tender suprapubic mass. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Imperforated hymen

  • This patient's symptoms of cyclical abdominal pain and amenorrhea suggest imperforate hymen.
  • The hymen is an embryological membrane formed by the fusion of the paramesonephric ducts and urogenital sinus.
  • Degeneration of epithelial cells leads to perforation of the central part of the hymen.
  • Failure of the hymen to perforate results in a condition called the imperforate hymen.
  • It presents with amenorrhea due to failure to menstruate.
  • Blood retention during menses stretches the vagina causing hematocolpus, which can result in an abdominal mass and be visualised as a bulging membrane at the vaginal opening.
  • Extension of the retained blood to the uterus is called hematometra.
  • Recurrent cyclical abdominal or pelvic pain occurs in the lower abdomen and vagina. This condition is called cryptomenorrhea.
  • The imperforate hymen may also lead to bowel and bladder issues.
  • The below image shows the retention of menstrual blood, which can lead to hematocolpus, hematometra and hematosalpix, which is an extension of menstrual blood to the fallopian tubes.

 

 

  • It is easily treated with a minor surgical procedure.

 

Option A: Asherman's syndrome

  • It is a condition where scar tissues, called intrauterine adhesions, form inside the uterus or cervix.
  • It occurs due to trauma to the uterine lining.
  • These adhesions obliterate the endometrial cavity and cause secondary amenorrhea.

 

Option B: Testicular feminising syndrome

  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome is due to a defect in the androgen receptor.
  • It is characterised by female external genitalia, with undeveloped vagina, scant or absent axillary and pubic hair.

 

Option D: Uterine agenesis

  • It is due to embryonic growth failure resulting in the underdevelopment of the uterus and vagina. External genitalia is normal.
  • It is a cause of primary amenorrhea.
  • Due to the absence of a uterus, affected individuals do not menstruate.
  • They have normal breast development and axillary and pubic hair growth.

questions.text: Which hormone is responsible for the mid-cycle rise in body temperature in females?
questions.solution:
Option D: Progesterone

Basal body temperature

  • Biphasic changes in BBT are characteristic of the ovulatory cycle.
  • Mediated by alterations in progesterone levels.
  • It regulates the menstrual cycle.
  • It rises after ovulation and peaks in 5-9 days after the luteal phase.
  • If fertilization doesn't occur, the corpus luteum rupture and decreases the progesterone level.
  • The progesterone secretion following ovulation causes a temperature rise of about 0.5 to 1°F over the baseline of 97°F to 98.8°F that is recorded during the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle.
  • Ovulation is assumed after three days of raised temperatures.
  • FSH is responsible for the stimulation and growth of the ovarian follicle.

Option A: FSH

  • FSH is responsible for the stimulation and growth of the ovarian follicle and negative feedback inhibition of estrogen.
  • It has no action on body temperature.

Option B: LH

  • LH is responsible for the final maturation of the follicle and ovulation.
  • LH surge and peak are followed by ovulation.
  • It is not responsible for the change in body temperature.

​​​​​​​Option C: Estradiol

  • Estradiol is responsible for making endometrium proliferative and making cervical mucous thin and slippery.
  • The change in body temperature is related to the progesterone hormone, not estradiol.

questions.text: A 30-year-old P2L2 woman with previous 2 vaginal deliveries presents for a routine pap smear. She complains of occasional mucoid vaginal discharge and no other significant complaints. On per speculum examination, the cervical os is expected to appear:
questions.solution:
Option B : Transverse

  • Before childbirth, the external cervical os is a small, regular, oval opening.
  • After childbirth, the orifice is converted into a transverse slit that is divided such that there are the so-called anterior and posterior lips of the cervix.
  • The cervical os is small and round, typical for a nulliparous woman.
  • The os will have a fish-mouth shape after one or more pregnancies.

Option A: Regular, oval

  1. A regular oval cervical os is seen prior to childbirth.

Option C: longitudinal

  • Cervical os is not longitudinal.

Option D: Irregular, pinpoint

  •  An irregular cervix may be abnormal and may require evaluation by colposcopy. Pinpoint os is usually not seen in parous women.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with the complaint of heavy menstrual bleeding. Her pelvic examination is unremarkable, and her recent pelvic scan shows no pelvic pathology. An office endometrial aspiration shows simple endometrial hyperplasia with atypia. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Option A: Hysterectomy

  • The incidence of endometrial cancers in a case of simple hyperplasia with atypia is 8 %.
  • In a 48-year-old woman, the treatment must be a hysterectomy.
  • Conservative treatment with follow-up may be tried in younger women with incomplete families, and a hysterectomy is done as soon as the childbearing function of the uterus is not required.
  • The incidence of occurrence of endometrial cancer in the case of endometrial hyperplasia is as follows
Simple hyperplasia with out Atypia is 1%
Complex hyperplasia with out Atypia 3%
Simple hyperplasia with Atypia 8%
Complex hyperplasia with Atypia 29%
  • In case of endometrial hyperplasia without atypia: Progesterone therapy should be given, even if the risk of malignancy is less.
  • In endometrial hyperplasia with atypia: Total hysterectomy is the best management option.

Option B: Medroxyprogesterone acetate

  • Medroxyprogesterone acetate in high doses can be used in women without atypia for uterine conservation.

Option C: Levonorgesterel IUCD

  • Levonorgestrel Intrauterine contraceptive device (LNG-IUCD) is also a progesterone-releasing IUCD with the same function as oral progesterone and may be given in women with hyperplasia without atypia.

Option D: Observation

  • Observation only is insufficient here as the risk of malignancy is high enough to warrant intervention.

questions.text: A pregnant woman, currently at 34 weeks of gestation, arrives at the obstetric clinic reporting a sudden gush of fluid from the vagina, resulting in soaking of her clothes. The woman has no abdominal pain, and she does not perceive any contractions. What would be the most appropriate initial clinical examination to determine the cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
Option C: Speculum examination

  • Premature rupture of membranes (PROM) is defined as rupture of the amniotic sac before the onset of labour. The premature rupture of membranes before 37 weeks of gestation is called preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM)
  • This patient’s vaginal leaking at 34 weeks most likely suggests PPROM
  • On per speculum examination - a gush of fluid is an obvious diagnostic test for PROM.
  • If the leak is small or insignificant, it may not be possible to visualise it.
  • Some investigations which are known to help to differentiate liquor from vaginal infections are:
  1. Nitrazine paper test
  2. Fern Test
  3. Indigocarmine dye test

Option A: Digital examination

  • Digital examination assesses the cervix for dilatation, effacement, and position during labour. It does not visualise the discharge.

Option B: USG examination

  • An ultrasound may demonstrate decreased liquor in case of vaginal leaking, but oligohydramnios can be due to various other reasons.

Option D: Urine examination

  • Urine examination may rule out urinary infection as a cause of PROM but does not diagnose leaking. This patient has no complaints of increased urinary frequency, urgency, or dysuria, making urinary tract infections unlikely.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the fertility clinic for preconception counselling. She has epilepsy and wants to know about its risk in pregnancy and for her baby. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding epilepsy in pregnancy?

choices.text: The rate of congenital malformation is not significantly increased in the offspring of women with epilepsy not on anticonvulsant therapy
Seizure frequency increases in approximately 70% of women
Breastfeeding is safe with most anticonvulsants
Folic acid supplementation may reduce the risk of neural tube defects

questions.solution:
Option B: Seizure frequency increases in approximately 70% of women

  • Although seizure frequency in pregnant epileptic women increases due to subtherapeutic levels of anticonvulsants, only 20-30% of pregnant women are affected, not 70%.
  • Epilepsy management in pregnancy requires special considerations.
  • Epilepsy leads to an increased frequency of seizures because of 2 reasons:
    • lower seizure threshold
    • subtherapeutic anticonvulsant levels
  • Lowest dose monotherapy is the goal. Multidrug therapy increases the risk of malformations. It is preferable to increase the dose if needed than to add another drug.
  • Phenytoin, phenobarbital and valproate are known teratogens with known fetal malformation risk. Lamotrigine and levetiracetam have the lowest risk of malformation.
  • Breastfeeding is safe with most anticonvulsants.
  • Complications of epilepsy in pregnancy are:
    • spontaneous abortions
    • APH and PPH
    • hypertensive disorders
    • preterm birth
    • IUGR
    • cesarean delivery

Option A: The rate of congenital malformation is not significantly increased in the offspring of women with epilepsy, not on anticonvulsant therapy

  • Anticonvulsants have teratogenic effect. Fetal malformations during pregnancy are more likely due to anticonvulsants than epilepsy itself.

Option C: Breastfeeding is safe with most anticonvulsants

  • It is safe to breastfeed infants while the mother is taking anticonvulsants. It poses no risk to the baby in most cases.

Option D: Folic acid supplementation may reduce the risk of neural tube defects

  • All pregnant women are given folic acid supplements to reduce the baby’s risk of neural tube defects.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain, abdominal distention, and vomiting. Upon examination, she is found to have alopecia with exclamation mark hair. She also has crepitus in the epigastrium. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Trichobezoar 

  • Concretions of hair, which are commonly observed in long-haired girls or women who deny eating their own hair and are discovered in a significant number of these individuals. 
  • Symptoms may include occasional gastric perforation and obstruction of the small bowel, in addition to the discomfort caused by stomach ulcers and the feeling of fullness induced by obstruction of the gastric outlet.
  • It is more likely that surgical operations will be required for the management of trichobezoars. 
  • This disorder is referred to as "Rapunzel Syndrome" in the medical field, and it is characterized by the presence of stomach trichobezoars along with a lengthy extension of hairs that extends into the duodenum. 

Option B: Carcinoma pyloric antrum 

  • The alopecia and other clinical findings are not suggestive of carcinoma pyloric antrum. 

Option C: Intestinal tuberculosis 

  • The alopecia and other clinical findings are not suggestive of intestinal tuberculosis. 

Option D: Rectus sheath hematoma 

  • The alopecia and other clinical findings are not suggestive of rectus sheath hematoma.

questions.text: A 35-year-old non-pregnant female presents to a surgical outpatient department with complaints of fever, anorexia, pelvic pain, diarrhea, and passage of mucus in the stools. Physical examination is generally unremarkable except for mild pelvic tenderness and bulging of the anterior rectal wall on digital rectal examination. An ultrasound of the pelvis reveals a pus-filled collection in the rectouterine pouch. What is the best next step in the management of this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Colpotomy

  • The scenario is a classic example of a pelvic abscess in the rectouterine pouch.
    • If the pelvic abscess does not naturally drain into the rectum, it must be deliberately drained by an approach through the posterior fornix. 
    • Colpotomy involves an incision in the vaginal wall to gain access to the posterior fornix. Once reached, an ultrasound or CT-guided drainage of the pelvic abscess is done.
    • Naturally, pelvic abscess drains into the rectum. The patient completely recovers, but if it doesn't drain that way, it's essential to deliberately drain it percutaneously (transabdominal, trans-gluteal, transrectal, or transvaginal). A catheter is placed with the abscess cavity to ensure good residual or new pus formation drainage.
    • If this fails somehow, then surgical exploration and drainage are indicated.

 

Option A: Laparotomy

  • Laparotomy and drainage of the abscess are indicated if antibiotics and percutaneous efforts to drain the abscess have failed.

 

Option C: External Incision and Drainage

  • When the abscess is located in the pouch of Douglas, the best plan is to deliberate drainage of the abscess through the posterior fornix via a vagina incision called colpotomy.

Option D: Antibiotics

  • Antibiotics are guided as per the pus culture and sensitivity report.
  • Empiric antibiotics are started as soon as a pelvic abscess is suspected, but it remains ineffective in most cases, thus necessitating rectal or per-vaginal drainage of the abscess.

questions.text:
A 2-week-old male child is brought to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal distension, incessant crying, and failure to take feeds. 

What does the marked white arrow in the x-ray show?
questions.solution:
Option B: Necrotizing enterocolitis

PNEUMATOSIS INTESTINALIS

  • This patient's symptoms of abdominal pain, reduced oral intake, and abdominal distension, together with the radiological findings of air in the bowel wall, are indicative of necrotizing enterocolitis.
  • An uncommon condition presenting as multiple gas-filled cysts of the gastrointestinal tract
  • Located in the subserosa, submucosa, and rarely, muscularis layer.
  • Most common site: Jejunum > ileocecal region > colon (Can occur anywhere)
  • Pneumatosis in neonates is usually associated with necrotizing enterocolitis
  • In gross appearance, the cysts resemble cystic lymphangiomas or hydatid cysts
  • On the histologic section, the involved portion has a honeycomb appearance
  • On plain films, pneumatosis intestinalis appears as radiolucent areas within the bowel wall, as shown by the arrow.
  • The radiolucency may be linear or curvilinear or appear as grape-like clusters or tiny bubbles.

Option A: Ileal perforation

  • Small bowel (SB) perforation is an acute pathological condition resulting from a discontinuity of the small bowel wall secondary to trauma, typhoid fever, and congenital conditions in this age group with subsequent leakage of intestinal gas and contents into the peritoneal cavity.
  • Abdominal x-ray shows free air under the diaphragm.
  • The x-ray shown in the question shows air in the bowel wall and not under the diaphragm.

Option C: Meconium ileus

  • Meconium ileus refers to a neonatal bowel obstruction of the distal ileum due to an abnormally thick and impacted meconium.
  • It is usually a manifestation of cystic fibrosis.
  • Plain radiographs are non-specific and may show dilated bowel loops proximal to the impaction. Classically, there is a paucity or absence of air-fluid levels and a "bubbly" appearance of the distended intestinal loops on radiographs.

Option D: Colonic aganglionosis

  • Hirschsprung disease is characterized by aganglionosis (absence of ganglion cells) in the distal colon and rectum.
  • X-ray findings are primarily those of a bowel obstruction. The affected bowel is of smaller calibre; thus, depending on the length of the segment affected, a variable amount of colonic distension is present.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to burns to the chest, arms and legs. Her blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, her pulse is 80/min, and her respiratory rate 18/minute. On physical examination, the patient appears in pain with full awareness. She has deep second degree burns to the chest, arms, and forearms. When can we expect the patient to have re-epithelialization of the burn wound?
questions.solution:
Option B: 4 weeks

Second-degree (partial thickness) burns:

  • This patient has deep second-degree burns in which the re-epithelialization occurs in 4 weeks.
  • The burn site appears red, blistered and may be swollen and painful.
  • Classified into superficial and deep
Superficial second-degree burns Deep second-degree burns
  • In superficial second-degree burns, the burn depth goes no deeper than the papillary dermis
  • Superficial second-degree burns spontaneously epithelialize from retained epidermal structures in the rete ridges, hair follicles and sweat glands in 1 to 2 weeks
  • Deep second-degree burns into the reticular dermis appear pale and mottled, do not blanch to touch but remain painful to pinprick
  • These burns heal in 2 to 5 weeks by re-epithelialization from hair follicles and sweat gland keratinocytes, often with severe scarring as a result of the loss of dermis
  • Early wound closure after burns is important in terms of survival and long-term outcomes.
  • It reduces the risk of infection and fluid loss.

Option A: 1 week

  • Superficial second-degree burns can epithelialize in 1 week. However, this patient has a deep second-degree burn that does not epithelialize in 1 week.

Option C: 8 weeks

  • The deep second-degree burn does not heal in 8 weeks; delayed healing can occur due to poor wound care.

Option D: 12 weeks

  • Second-degree burns re-epithelialize in 2-5 weeks, not in 12 weeks.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient complains of prolonged bleeding from an ulcer over the right lower limb.  The daily dressings with non-adherent paraffin gas patients have been performed since then, but the ulcer did not heal. Hence, he undergoes debridement and Thiersch grafting of the right leg ulcer under spinal anesthesia. Which of the following is the advantage of the type of graft used in this patient?

choices.text: The graft can not be taken from the upper arm, flexor aspect of the forearm, and abdominal wall
The is not affected by the hematoma

questions.solution:
Option A: Large-size graft can be taken

  • This patient with a chronic non-healing ulcer underwent debridement and Thiersch grafting.
  • Skin reconstruction can be performed using flaps and grafts. A graft is a tissue that contains just the skin without a blood supply.
  • The Thiersch graft is characterised by a partial-thickness skin graft used to re-epithelialize portions of the affected skin.
  • This highly effective technique allows a significantly shorter postoperative recovery time.
  • The advantage of Thiersch grafting is that large-size grafts can be taken.
  • The following table summarises the types of various skin grafts and their advantages and disadvantages:

Type of Graft

Advantages

Disadvantages

Thin Split

Thickness

  • Best Survival
  • Heals Rapidly
  • Least resembles original skin.
  • Least resistance to trauma.
  • Poor Sensation
  • Maximal Secondary Contraction 

Thick Split

Thickness

 
  • More qualifies of normal skin.
  • Less Contraction
  • Looks better
  • Fair Sensation

 
  • Lower graft survival
  • Slower healing.

 

Full Thickness

 
  • Most resembles normal skin.
  • Minimal Secondary contraction
  • Resistant to trauma
  • Good Sensation
  • Aesthetically pleasing
  • Poorest survival.
  • Donor site must be closed surgically.
  • Donor sites are limited.

 

Option B: Consists of the epidermis only.

  • This statement is incorrect, as a Thiersch graft consists of the epidermis and a variable portion of the dermis.

Option C: The graft can be taken from the upper arm, flexor aspect of the forearm, and abdominal wall

  • This statement is incorrect as a Thiersch graft can be taken from the upper arm, flexor aspect of the forearm, and abdominal wall

Option D: The is not affected by the hematoma

  • This statement is incorrect, as hematoma (or seroma), infection, and movement (shear) are among the most common causes of skin graft failure.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the surgical emergency department with acute abdominal pain for the past 2 hours. He is immediately taken up for emergency laparotomy. Resection of the bowel with ileostomy is done. Examination of the specimen reveals a segmental disease with aphthous ulcers and non-caseating granulomas with Langerhans giant cells. What diagnostic modality is most commonly used to diagnose the above clinical condition?
questions.solution:
Option A:

CT enteroclysis

  • It is the primary diagnostic tool but not most commonly used for diagnosing Crohn's disease.

 

​​​​​Option B:

Colonoscopy

  • The given clinical condition is Crohn’s disease.
  • Colonoscopy reveals focal ulceration adjacent to areas of normal mucosa, giving a cobblestone appearance.

Option C: Capsule endoscopy

  • Capsule endoscopy is not used for diagnosing Crohn's disease.

Option D: CECT

  • CECT is not used for diagnosing Crohn's disease.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presented to the physician's clinic with a complaint of thin whitish vaginal discharge for the past week. On physical examination, the discharge is seen and  vaginal discharge sample is collected, and the examination findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the disease caused by the organism seen around the vaginal cells in the image?
questions.solution:
Option B: Bacterial vaginosis

The patient, as mentioned above, has bacterial vaginosis (BV), with the examination of vaginal discharge showing clue cells.

  • The image depicts a clue cell on microscopy, which are pathognomic of bacterial vaginosis. The clue cells show numerous bacteria obscuring the borders of vaginal epithelial cells, giving them a stippled appearance.
  • Numerous studies show an association of BV with significant adverse sequelae.
  • Women with BV are at increased risk for pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), postabortal PID, postoperative cuff infections after hysterectomy, and abnormal cervical cytology. Pregnant women with BV risk premature rupture of the membranes, preterm labour and delivery, chorioamnionitis, and postcesarean endometritis.
  • In women with BV undergoing surgical abortion or hysterectomy, perioperative treatment with metronidazole eliminates this increased risk.
  • It is diagnosed based on the following findings:
  1. Microscopy of vaginal secretions: Reveal clue cells, and leukocytes are conspicuously absent.
  2. Adding KOH to the vaginal secretions (the “whiff” test) releases a fishy, amine-like odour.
  3. Alternative diagnostic tests include pH (> 4.5) and amines test card, detection of G. vaginalis ribosomal RNA, or Gram stain.

 

Option A: Herpes simplex

 

  • The virus infects viable epidermal cells leading to erythema and abscess formation. With cell death and cell wall lysis, blister formation occurs. The covering then disrupts, leaving a usually painful ulcer. Soon these lesions develop crusting and heal.
  • Burning and severe pain accompany initial vesicular lesions. This patient has no such symptoms.
  • Herpes simplex does not form clue cells. The PCR test of the skin lesions is the test of choice. The Tzank test includes a smear of skin vesicles showing multinucleated giant cells. Viral culture shows intranuclear eosinophilic Cowdry A inclusions, as shown in the image above.

 

Option C: Chancroid

  • The chancroid presents initially with an erythematous papule that becomes pustular and ulcerates within 48 hours. Edges of these painful ulcers are usually irregular, with erythematous non-indurated margins. The ulcer bases are usually red and granular, covered with purulent material. Furthermore, they develop unilateral and bilateral tender inguinal lymphadenopathy.
  • Diagnosis is made by growth on special media and identification of gram-negative, non-motile rods.

 

Option D: Syphillis

  • Syphilis is caused by spirochetes identified by dark-field examination or direct fluorescent antibody testing of the lesion exudate. Other serology tests include Rapid plasma reagin (RPR) and fluorescent treponemal antibody-absorption (FTA-ABS).
  • The clue cells are not seen in syphilis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female, gravida 2 para 1, presents to the labour room due to heavy vaginal bleeding for 2 hours at 30 weeks of gestation. The patient reports no uterine contractions or pain. Her blood pressure is 80/60mmHg.Transabdominal ultrasound reveals a central placenta previa. Multiple transfusions of cross-matched blood are given to resuscitate the patient before she undergoes a caesarean section to deliver the fetus. Which of the following is the most likely future complication for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Amenorrhea

  • The patient is most likely to suffer from Sheehan's syndrome due to extensive haemorrhage.
  • The pituitary gland is increased in size and vascularity, especially in the third trimester of pregnancy.
  • It is, therefore, prone to ischemia and necrosis in case of excessive blood loss during pregnancy or postpartum.
  • Patients with Sheehan’s syndrome are characterized by varying degrees of anterior pituitary hormone deficiency.
  • Diabetes insipidus with or without anterior pituitary deficiency has been described following massive obstetrical haemorrhage and prolonged shock.
  • The classical presentation is characterized by failure of initiation of lactation, amenorrhea, breast atrophy, loss of pubic and axillary hair, hypothyroidism, and adrenal cortical insufficiency with amenorrhea.

Option A: Menorrhagia

  • Menorrhagia is characterized by bleeding lasting more than seven days or heavy bleeding.
  • Postpartum bleeding typically lasts for about 4-6 weeks.
  • Amenorrhea is a feature of Sheehan’s syndrome instead of menorrhagia.

Option B: Galactorrhea

  • Galactorrhea is a normal milky discharge from breasts unrelated to the normal milk production of lactation.
  • It can occur due to persistent nipple stimulation or due to pituitary tumours.
  • Lactation is a normally expected finding after delivery of the baby.
  • Lack of initiation of lactation is seen in Sheehan's syndrome

Option D: Cushing disease

  • Cushing disease is excessive production of ACTH from the anterior pituitary due to a pituitary tumour.
  • It leads to excessive cortisol produced by the adrenal cortex, manifesting as raised blood pressure, obesity, glucose intolerance, or diabetes mellitus.
  • It is not a manifestation of Sheehan’s syndrome.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the fertility clinic for infertility evaluation. She has been unable to conceive for 3 years. She and her partner are sexually active and do not use contraception. Analysis of her husband's semen showed normal sperm counts. The treating doctor checks her FSH on day 3 and repeats it on day 10 after 5 days of Clomiphene citrate (100mg). The values noted were 20 IU/L and 35 IU/L, respectively. The most probable cause of infertility in this patient is?
questions.solution:
Option D: Low ovarian reserve

  • A decline in normal functioning oocytes by either a reduced number or impaired development.
  • A normal consequence of age, but it can also be caused by an underlying disorder (e.g. endometriosis).
  • The Clomiphene citrate challenge test is conducted here, which is used to assess a woman's ovarian reserve.
    • On day 3 → Check serum FSH
    • On day 5 – day 9 → Give 100mcg Clomiphene citrate (CC)
    • On day 10 → Check serum FSH
    • A high FSH value on day 3, which increases further on day 10, indicates poor reserve (Normal values <10 IU/L).

Markers for low ovarian reserve

  • AMH: The best marker for ovarian reserve is the AMH.
    • Released from small antral and pre- antral follicles
    • <0.5 ng = Poor reserve
    • 1ng = Borderline reserve
    • ≥ 3.3 ng = high reserve, a risk factor for OHSS in stimulated cycles
  • High day 2 FSH (most commonly performed test)
  • Low inhibin B
  • Low antral follicle count: total number of antral follicles in both ovaries

Option A: Lack of LH surge

  • LH surge occurs prior to ovulation, since no LH levels are mentioned here, a lack of LH surge cannot be commented upton.

Option B: PCOD

  • It is the most common endocrine disorder in women.
  • It is characterised by hyperandrogenism (which primarily manifests as hirsutism, acne and virilisation), anovulation and the presence of polycystic ovaries.
  • Diagnosis involves a complete history and physical examination.
  • This is a cause of anovulatory infertility and not of diminished ovarian reserve

Option C: Luteal phase defect

  • It is a disorder due to abnormal corpus luteum function, resulting in insufficient progesterone production.
  • Its symptoms are
  1. Spotting between periods.
  2. Difficulty in conceiving.
  3. Miscarriages.
  4. Bloating.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented to the clinic with a history of nasal obstruction for the last 2 months. It was associated with a headache and a loss of sense of smell. There is no history of epistaxis. The physician ordered an X-ray, and the following findings were seen. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Antrochoanal Polyp

  • This 16-year-old girl with nasal obstruction, headache, loss of sense of smell, and a mass seen in the nasopharynx has signs of a nasopharyngeal pathology.
  • This pathology can include antrochoanal polyps, juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, and adenoid hypertrophy.
  • This 16-year-old has no history of epistaxis, and the presence of Dodd's sign (crescent sign) on the X-ray is most consistent with a diagnosis of an antrochoanal polyp.
    • Dodd's or crescent sign is the presence of an air column between the nasopharyngeal mass and the posterior pharyngeal wall, seen in antrochoanal polyps.
    • The presence of this air column signifies that the mass did not originate from the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is absent in nasal angiofibromas since these masses originate from the posterior pharyngeal wall; hence Dodd's sign is absent.

Option B: Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma

  • It most commonly presents as epistaxis in adolescent males.
  • It is seen almost exclusively in males aged between 10–20 years. It may also be less likely to be seen in older people and females.
  • The most common manifestation of the disease is epistaxis. It is spontaneous and recurrent and causes marked anaemia due to repeated blood loss.
  • It can also present with progressive nasal obstruction and hypo-nasal speech. It is due to the mass being in the nasopharyngeal space.
  • It can obstruct the eustachian tube leading to otitis media with effusion and conductive hearing loss.
  • The tumour is sessile, lobulated, or smooth and obstructs one or both choanae. It is pink or purple. It has a firm consistency, but digital palpation of the mass is contraindicated until the time of operation due to the risk of spontaneous bleeding.
  • Other clinical features include the broadening of the nasal bridge, proptosis, swelling of the cheeks and infratemporal fossa, and involvement of second, third, fourth, and fifth cranial nerves. These features depend on the extent of the tumour.
  • Computed tomography (CT) scan of the head with contrast enhancement is now the investigation of choice. It is done to know the extent of the tumour and any bony destruction or displacements of the nasal bones. Anterior bowing of the maxillary sinus's posterior wall often called an antral sign, or Holman-Miller sign, is pathognomonic of angiofibroma.

Option C: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma:

  • It is mostly seen in the fifth to seventh decades of life but may involve younger age groups.
  • It most commonly presents in an old male with nasal obstruction and a palpable lymph node in the neck.
  • It is not uncommon to see the cancer of the nasopharynx in the twenties and thirties. Males are three times more prone than females.

Option D: Adenoid hypertrophy:

  • It most commonly presents in children with complaints of obstructive sleep apnea.
  • Dodd’s sign is absent in adenoid hypertrophy.

questions.text: A previously healthy, active 18-month-old child presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and foul-smelling discharge for 3 months. The mother does not complaint of any fever. The child does not have any significant medical history. The child's examination is otherwise unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Foreign body

  • It is a dictum that "If a child presents with unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge, the foreign body must be excluded".
  • A foreign body in the nose in a child presents with unilateral fetid (foul smelling) nasal discharge, epistaxis (mild), and unilateral nasal obstruction.
  • Unilateral blood-stained discharge in a child is seen in rhinolith, nasal diphtheria, nasal myiasis, and acute or chronic unilateral sinusitis.
  • These foreign objects are removed using forceps or a suction tube.

Option B: Rhinophyma

  • Rhinophyma or potato tumor is a slow-growing benign tumor due to hypertrophy of the sebaceous glands of the tip of the nose, often seen in cases of long-standing acne rosacea.
  • It presents as a pink, lobulated mass over the nose with superficial vascular dilation; it mostly affects men past middle age.
  • The patient seeks advice because of the unsightly appearance of the tumor or obstruction to breathing and vision due to the large size of the tumor.

Option C: Rhinosporidiosis

  • Rhinosporidiosis is a fungal infection of the upper respiratory tract.
  • In the early stages, the patient may complain of nasal discharge, which is often blood-tinged and nasal stuffiness.
  • Sometimes, frank epistaxis is the only presenting complaint.

Option D: Angiofibroma

  • It is a benign tumor of the mucosa of the nose.
  • Angiofibroma has a history of profuse recurrent epistaxis, progressive nasal obstruction, and denasal speech.

questions.text: A 1-day-old male baby was admitted to NICU after being delivered vaginally to a multiparous diabetic woman at home by a midwife. He had a weak cry, flaccid muscle tone, and a pulse of 98 bpm. He was immediately resuscitated for his poor APGAR score. The doctor examined him thoroughly for his physical and neuromuscular maturity. Which of the following tests is done to assess the passive tone of shoulder flexors in the Ballard score?
questions.solution:
Option A: Scarf sign

  • Scarf sign helps in assessing the neuromuscular maturity of a neonate. This manoeuvre is used to test the passive tone of the flexors of the shoulder girdle. The neonate lies supine, and the examiner brings the neonate's arm across the upper chest until the baby resists it. The point on the chest is noted to which the elbow is moved easily, and the score is noted according to the landmark.

  • ENBS (Expanded New Ballard Score) is a commonly used technique to assess the gestational age of a neonate by using physical and neuromuscular criteria of maturity.
  • Preterm babies are usually in a state of physiological hypotonia that increases throughout the fetal growth period.
  • The neuromuscular criteria include posture, square window, arm recoil, popliteal angle, scarf sign, and heel-to-ear sign.
  • Likewise, physical maturity scoring is done by assessing skin, lanugo, plantar surface, breast, eye/ear, and genitals.

Option B: Square Window

  • A square window sign helps in the assessment of the flexibility of the wrist of a neonate.
  • The examiner gently applies pressure on the dorsum of the hand while the fingers are straightened, forming an angle between the palm and forearm of the baby.
  • The wrist has the least flexibility at the younger gestational age meaning a more premature baby would have a lesser angle.

Option C: Arm recoil

  • This manoeuvre tests the passive flexor tone of the biceps muscle by measuring the recoil angle after a brief extension of the upper arm.
  • The baby lies supine, and the examiner places his one hand beneath the baby's elbow. He flexes the elbow briefly and then extends it before releasing it. The recoil angle is noted to which the forearm springs back to flexion.
  • The extremely premature neonate does not undergo any recoil.

Option D: Heel-to-ear

  • This manoeuvre helps to assess the passive flexor tone of the pelvic girdle.
  • It tests the passive or resistance to the extension of posterior hip flexor muscles
  • The examiner brings the neonate’s foot towards the ipsilateral ear.
  • In extremely premature neonates, the resistance to extension of posterior hip flexors is felt when the heel is at or near the ear.

questions.text: A 16-month-old baby boy is brought to the pediatric OPD with a complaint of eating mud, chalk, and other non-nutritive things for the last two months. The mother says no matter how much they try giving him good food at regular intervals throughout the day, he does not stop eating mud. What abnormality does this child have?
questions.solution:
Option C: Pica

  • The above case is most probably of ‘Pica.'
  • Pica is the persistent eating of non-nutritive, non-food substances over a period of at least one month, such as plaster, charcoal, paint and soil.
  • It provides emotional relief.
  • Pica is commonly seen in children and pregnant ladies.
  • Associated with malnutrition, iron deficiency anaemia, emotional trauma and developmental disabilities.
  • There is an increased risk of lead poisoning and parasitic infestations.
  • Treatment is by behavioural modification, deworming, iron supplementation, and screening for lead poisoning.

Option A: Bruxism

  • Bruxism (teeth grinding) causes muscular or temporomandibular joint pain, dental occlusion.

Option B: Thumb sucking

  • Its persistence beyond five years may be associated with sequelae like paronychia, anterior open bite, and dental malalignment; management includes using positive and negative reinforcements.

Option D: Breath-holding spells

  • Results from the immaturity of ANS
  • Begins around 6-18 months
  • Triggers- injury, anger, frustration
  • Starts with crying & progresses to apnea, syncope, tonic posturing
  • Management of breath-holding spells is parental reassurance. Atropine is sometimes used.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with a sore throat and swelling of the neck. On examination of the throat, the following was seen: The child is never immunized. What is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
Option D: Corynebacterium diphtheriae

  • This child sees a membrane over the tonsil, with neck swelling suggestive of diphtheria.

  • Diphtheria typically follows an incubation period of 2-5 days.

  • Infection is slower in onset with less local discomfort, often resembling a typical viral upper respiratory infection (URI)

  • Localized or coalescing pseudomembrane in diphtheria extends beyond the tonsils onto the soft palate and is dirty grey in colour.

  • It is characterized by forming a dense, grey debris layer composed of dead cells, fibrin, RBCs, WBCs, and organisms.

  • It is adherent, and its removal leaves a bleeding surface.

  • Urine may show albumin.

  • The smear and culture of the throat swab will reveal corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Option A: Streptococcus pyogenes

  • The picture shown above is a pseudomembrane which is diagnostic of diphtheria.

  • Streptococcus pyogenes do not form the pseudomembrane. 

  • It causes pharyngitis without a membrane.

  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option B: Mycobacterium tuberculosis

  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis does not form the pseudomembrane, and it causes tuberculosis.

  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option C: Staphylococcus aureus

  • Staphylococcus are bacteria commonly found living on many skin surfaces. Including the nose and the lining of the mouth and throat.

  • However, if a patient has pharyngitis, the culprit is most likely not a staphylococcus infection.

questions.text: A pregnant lady had  complaints of mild cervical lymphadenopathy in the first trimester. She was prescribed Spiramycin, but she was non-compliant. The baby was born with hydrocephalus and intracerebral calcification. Which of these is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Option B: Toxoplasmosis

  • The presence of cervical lymphadenopathy, treatment with Spiramycin, and neonatal manifestation in the form of hydrocephalus and intracerebral calcification all point to a diagnosis of congenital toxoplasmosis.

Option A: Rubella

  • Rubella is associated with cataracts, deafness (Sensorineural hearing loss), congenital heart disease (Patent ductus arteriosus)

Option C: Cytomegalovirus (CMV)

  • Cytomegalovirus infection is associated with intrauterine growth retardation, microcephaly, hepatosplenomegaly, prolonged neonatal jaundice, and generalized blue–purple macules at birth.

Option D: Varicella zoster

  • Cicatrizing skin lesions, hypoplasia of all limbs, and chorioretinitis are all features of Congenital Varicella Syndrome.

questions.text: A certain syndicate has acquired the rights to excavate a part of a forest area for the construction of a factory. During the excavation, the remains of a couple of bodies have been recovered. It has been sent to the forensic lab for the determination of its identity. The forensic team would use all of the following formulae to determine the sex of the bone. Which among them is not the right method?

choices.text: Sciatic notch index - Width of notch/ Depth of notch x 100
Washburn ischiopubic index - Pubic length/ Ischial length x 100
Corporobasal index - Length of 1st sacral vertebra/ Length of base of sacrum x 100
Sternal index - Manubrial length/ Body length x 100

questions.solution:
Corporobasal index - Length of 1st sacral vertebra/ Length of base of sacrum x 100 is WRONG as In the FORMULA BREADTH is used.

Vital Indices for Sex Determination from Bones

Name of the index Formulae Males Females
Sciatic notch index Width of notch/ Depth of notch x 100 4-5 5-6
Washburn ischiopubic index Pubic length/ Ischial length x 100 73-94 91-115
Corporobasal index of sacrum Breadth of 1st sacral vertebra/ Breadth of base of sacrum x 100 45 40.5
Sternal index Manubrial length/ Body length x 100 46.2 54.3

questions.text: A 30-year-old man and his parents have been arrested under IPC 314 after the death of the man's 26-year-old wife. What offence are they being charged for?

choices.text: Death of the patient caused by intent to cause miscarriage
Death of the child during intent to cause miscarriage

questions.solution:
Option B: Death of the patient caused by intent to cause miscarriage

  • Sec. 314 IPC: if a pregnant woman dies from an act intended to cause miscarriage, the offender is liable to be punished with rigorous imprisonment which shall not be less than ten years and also a fine of up to two lakh rupees.

Option A: Causing miscarriage without consent

  • Sec. 313 IPC: If the miscarriage is caused without the consent of the woman, imprisonment may be up to ten years.

Option C: Causing miscarriage with consent

  • Sec. 312 IPC: Whoever voluntarily causes criminal abortion is liable for imprisonment up to three years and/or a fine, and if the woman is quick with the child the imprisonment may extend up to 7 years.
  • It is necessary that the woman should be pregnant and that abortion should be carried out with her consent.
  • Both the person causing the abortion and the woman are liable for punishment.

 Option D: Death of the child during intent to cause miscarriage

  •  Sec. 316 IPC: Causing the death of a quick unborn child by any act amounts to culpable homicide, and the punishment may extend up to ten years imprisonment.

questions.text: The body of the 27-year-old female tourist, who had been missing for a week, has been recovered from near a waterfall. The forensic team has begun its investigation to determine the cause of death. Among the findings, the team has documented the presence of Masque Ecchymotique, which indicates the possible cause of death as?
questions.solution:
Option C: Traumatic asphyxia

  • The presence of Masque Ecchymotique, indicates traumatic asphyxia.
