Option A: Ligature strangulation

  • The ligature mark is transverse, complete below the thyroid & cartilage (mostly).
  • The ligature mark of hanging due to the slip knot is situated above the thyroid cartilage.

Option B: Manual strangulation 

  • Constriction of the neck by hands/ fingers manually is known as manual strangulation.

Option D: Burking

  • It is a combination of Homicidal smothering + Traumatic asphyxia.
  • One person sits on the chest of the victim, while another person covers the mouth & nostrils of the victim.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented to the emergency with a complaint of increasing fatigue and shortness of breath on mild-moderate exertion for 2 days. On physical examination, the neck veins are distended, elevated JVP and breath sounds are normal bilaterally. An urgent chest x-ray is done, as shown below. Based on the image given below, what is the correct diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Constrictive pericarditis

  • Acute pericarditis is the inflammation of the pericardium.
  • Constrictive pericarditis occurs when the healing of an acute fibrinous or serofibrinous pericarditis or the resorption of a chronic pericardial effusion is followed by obliteration of the pericardial cavity with the formation of granulation tissue.
  • It will undergo gradual contraction and formation of a firm scar encasing the heart, which may be calcified.
  • As a result, the ventricles cannot fill because of the limitations imposed by the rigid, thickened pericardium.
  • Ventricular filling is unimpeded during early diastole but is reduced abruptly when the elastic limit of the pericardium is reached, and there is a reduction in the ventricular end-diastolic and stroke volumes in both ventricles.
  • The end-diastolic pressures in both ventricles and the mean pressures in the atria, pulmonary veins, and systemic veins are all elevated to similar levels.

  • There is an "Egg in Cup" Appearance on imaging as shown above. The red arrows show the calcified pericardium, and the white arrows demarcate the pericardial effusion. In the chest x-ray given above, the green arrow demarcates the calcified fibrous pericardium.
  • The patient presents with weakness, fatigue, weight gain, increased abdominal girth, discomfort, and edema. There is exertional dyspnea, orthopnea, distended cervical veins with a drop in venous pressure during inspiration (Kussmaul’s sign), and prominent “x” and “y” descents in the JVP.

Option A: Pneumothorax

  • Pneumothorax is the presence of gas (air) in the pleural space.
  • As a result, there is an increased blackening of the affected lung field as shown by the arrow, decreased breath sounds, and hyper-resonant percussion notes.
  • Chest pain, dyspnea, uneven chest expansion.
  • Decrease tactile fremitus.
  • Critical cases are treated by intercostal tube placement to remove air.

Option B: Pneumomediastinum

  • Pneumomediastinum is defined as air in the mediastinal space. It may be associated with pathologic extra-alveolar gas in other sites, including the thoracic cavity, pericardium, subcutaneous soft tissue, peritoneum, and retroperitoneum.
  • It usually results from traumatic injury that disrupts mucosal barriers such as those in the esophagus or tracheobronchial tree.
  • Chest x-ray showing lucencies around the cardiac border is consistent with pneumomediastinum.
  • It is also made of subcutaneous and intermuscular emphysema in the bilateral shoulder region.

Option C: Normal CXR

  • The below give X ray is normal chest xray.

questions.text: A statistical study was conducted by a group of community medicine students. Power of study can be increased by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option B: Decreasing beta error

  • The power of a statistical test can be increased by:
    • Increasing the number of subjects in a trial (sample size).
    • Reducing beta error (probability of Type II error).
    • Increasing sensitivity.

Other options are incorrect

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl previously diagnosed with Noonan Syndrome presented to the pediatric clinic with complaints of vomiting and diarrhoea for the past 4 days. She is given treatment for acute gastroenteritis. On physical examination, she has short stature, a webbed neck, cubitus valgus and anti-mongoloid eyes. She is unable to understand and follow the command. A systolic ejection murmur is heard in the pulmonary area on auscultation of the heart. Now the paediatrician has suspicion of Turner syndrome. Which of the following is the main differentiating feature between the two syndromes?
questions.solution:
Option D: Intellectual disability

  • There is no intellectual disability present in Turner syndrome.
  • Patients with Noonan Syndrome have marked intellectual disabilities.

Option A: Webbed Neck

  • Pterygium Colli is a congenital skin fold that runs along the sides of the neck down to the shoulders.
  • Its deformity causes a webbed neck
  • It is present in both Nonaan Syndrome and Turner Syndrome.

Option B: Short Stature

  • There are various causes of short stature in children.
  • Correlation with other features can help in accurate diagnosis.
  • It is present in both Nonaan Syndrome and Turner Syndrome.

Option C: Cubitus Valgus

  • When your arms are held at your sides and your palms are facing forward, your forearm and hands should normally be about 5 to 15 degrees away from your body.
  • It is the normal "carrying angle" of the elbow.
  • When there is an increase in the carrying angle of the elbow, causing the arms to stick out too much from the body, it is called an excessive carrying angle or cubitus valgus.
  • It is present in both Nonaan Syndrome and Turner Syndrome.

questions.text: An 18-year-old patient presents in the emergency department with complaint of pain and fullness in the ear. The patient has also noticed that his hearing has reduced over the last 2 years and presented with the following otoscopic finding. Similar findings can also be seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Option B: Secretory otitis media

Sequelae of chronic secretory otitis media:

  • The above given is a case of secretory otitis media.
  • Pain, ear fullness, and decreased hearing from 2 years are suggestive.
  • Atrophic tympanic membrane and atelectasis of the middle ear. In prolonged effusions, the fibrous layer of the tympanic membrane is dissolved. It becomes thin and atrophic and retracts into the middle ear.

Ossicular necrosis:

  • Most commonly, the long process of incus gets necrosed. Sometimes, stapes superstructure also gets necrosed. This increases the conductive hearing loss to more than 50 dB.

Tympanosclerosis:

  • Hyalinized collagen with chalky deposits may be seen in the tympanic membrane, around the ossicles, or their joints, leading to their fixation.

Retraction pockets and cholesteatoma:

  • Thin atrophic part of pars tensa may get invaginated to form retraction pockets or cholesteatoma. Similar pockets may be seen in the attic region.
  • Cholesterol granuloma: This is due to stasis of the middle ear and mastoid secretions.

Otoscopic findings:

  • The tympanic membrane is often dull and opaque, with a loss of light reflex.
  • It may appear yellow, grey, or bluish in color. A thin leash of blood vessels may be seen along the handle of the malleus or at the periphery of the tympanic membrane and differs from marked congestion of acute suppurative otitis media.
  • The tympanic membrane may show varying degrees of retraction.
  • Sometimes, it may appear full or slightly bulging in its posterior part due to effusion.
  • Fluid level and air bubbles may be seen when fluid is thin and the tympanic membrane transparent.
  • Mobility of the tympanic membrane is restricted.

Option A: Tympanosclerosis

  • It causes scar formation on the tympanic membrane.
  • The tympanic membrane appears like a chalky white drum.
  • It is caused by severe middle ear infections such as otitis media.

Option C: Otosclerosis

  • It is the overgrowth of the footplate of the stapes bone.
  • It causes tinnitus and vertigo.
  • The tympanic membrane appears like a pink drum.

Option D: Myringitis bullosa

  • It causes painful reddish blisters along the tympanic membrane in the ear.
  • Viruses cause it.
  • Streptococcus pneumonia is the most common bacteria causing this disease.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male presents to the clinic with the complaint of pruritic lesions on the foot. He is a farmer. He states that the lesions are itchy. On examination, the serpiginous pattern of the skin lesion, as shown in the image below, is noted:



In which of the following diseases can these lesions be seen?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cutaneous larva migrans

  • Serpiginous/serpent-like skin lesions are seen in Cutaneous larva migrans (CLM).
  • CLM is caused by various animal hookworm species (e.g., Ancylostoma braziliense), and the parasite is acquired from direct skin contact with soil contaminated by dog or cat feces.
  • The parasitic infection usually begins with an inflamed papule, often located between the toes, where the hookworm species (e.g., Ancylostoma braziliense) larvae enter the skin.
  • Serpentine or linear single-track lines later mark the course of the larvae as they migrate through the epidermis of the trunk and lower extremities.
  • Symptoms begin to appear within the first two weeks of the patient’s return from a tropical or endemic country, and the erythematous lines can enlarge as much as 1 to 2 cm per day.

Option A: Incontinentia pigmenti

  • Linear lesions along blaschkoid lines.

Option C: Psoriasis

  • It is a papulosquamous lesion.
  • Lesions can be erythematous and scaly.
  • Papulopustular lesions are also seen.
  • Affects extensor surfaces of the body

Option D: lichen Planus

  • It is a papulosquamous lesion.
  • Lesions are papular, pink, and plane in the lichen planus.

questions.text:
A 8-year-old boy comes to the ER after 7 days of vomiting and diarrhea, advised 'Plan B' for dehydration. Returns 5 days later with muscle weakness and cramps due to poor compliance. Physical exam normal, CT scan clear. ECG shows changes. Which electrolyte abnormalities cause these ECG changes?



Which of the following electrolyte abnormalities produce these changes in an ECG?
questions.solution:
Option C: Hypokalemia

  • The patient’s history and ECG findings are consistent with hypokalemia.
  • Gastrointestinal (GI) losses are children's most common cause of hypokalemia.
    • In particular, diarrheal potassium content (20 to 50 mEq/L) is relatively high compared with other body fluids.
    • In contrast, upper GI losses (e.g., vomiting, nasogastric drainage) are minimal as the potassium content is relatively low (5 to 10 mEq/L). However, the loss of gastric secretions results in metabolic alkalosis, leading to increased urinary potassium losses.
    • Hypokalemia can be suspected early on an ECG with the following findings. 
      • U-wave fusion and T-wave give a T-U wave misdiagnosed as the prolonged QT interval.
      • Larger and wider P-wave and prolonged PR interval
      • ST-segment depression and T-waves flattening/inversion

Option A: Hyponatremia

  • GI fluid and electrolyte loss cause hypovolemic hypernatremia; however, hyponatremia does not cause any changes on ECG.

Option B: Hypernatremia

  • GI fluid and electrolyte loss cause hypovolemic hypernatremia; however, hypernatremia does not cause any changes on ECG.

Option D: Hyperkalemia

  • Hyperkalemia is associated with
    • Prolonged PR interval and QRS duration increases
    • Flat P-waves
    • ST-elevation in leads V1-V2
    • Widening of QRS complex - sinus wave

questions.text:
A 32-year-old male presents with weakness on the left side of the face, inability to close his left eye, drooping of the mouth, and drooling of saliva. There is no wrinkling on the left side of the forehead. The rest of the examination findings are shown below.



The structure damaged in the given condition is responsible for all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Option C: Parotid gland secretion

  • The condition given here is Bell's palsy, i.e., lower motor neuron lesion of the Facial Nerve.
  • Parasympathetic innervation of the parotid gland begins with the glossopharyngeal nerve, which synapses in the otic ganglion. The otic ganglion then provides parasympathetic fibers to the parotid gland through an auriculotemporal nerve. This parasympathetic pathway controls the secretions of the parotid gland.
  • On the other hand, the auriculotemporal nerve provides sensory innervation to the gland, whereas the great auricular nerve provides sensory innervation to the fascia.

Option A: Taste sensation of anterior 2/3rd tongue

  • Taste from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue is carried by the chorda tympani nerve, a branch of the facial nerve to the nucleus tractus solitarius.

Option B: Lacrimal gland secretion

  • The facial nerve controls the secretions of the lacrimal gland through the greater petrosal Nerve.

Option D: Platysma contraction

  • The platysma is supplied by one of the five terminal branches of the facial nerve called the cervical nerve. Therefore, contractions of platysma will be affected by Bell's Palsy.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male presents to the outpatient clinic for his routine annual visit. The patient has complained of an abnormal gait for 2 weeks. On physical examination, the patient's pelvis dips on the right side with his right foot in the air and left foot on the ground. A photo of the patient's gait is shown below. Weakness of which of the following muscles is responsible for this patient’s presentation?



Weakness of which of the following muscles is responsible for this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
Option D: Both B & C

 

  • Normal two-legged stance: the center of gravity is midway between the two feet.
  • Normal single-legged stance: Center of gravity shifts towards the affected side.
  • To allow this to occur efficiently, the pelvis is effectively pulled up on the unsupported side, and the center of gravity is shifted directly over the standing foot. Clinical examination reveals this by localizing and placing a finger on each anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS). As the patient stands on one leg, the finger on the ASIS of the unsupported leg will rise.
  • This is a normal response and would be recorded as Trendelenburg negative.
  • This patient presents with a lurching or waddling gait.
  • In this gait, the patient lurches to the affected side, and the pelvis drops to the opposite side.
  • It is due to the paralysis of the hip abductors, gluteus medius, and minimus.
  • With bilateral paralysis, the pelvis drops to the unsupported side with each alternating step.
  • The gait is described as a "duck-like waddle (Waddling gait), Sailors or Trendelenburg gait.
  • Causes include polio (involving L5), injury to the superior gluteal nerve, fracture of the femoral neck, coxa vara, and developmental dysplasia of the hip.
  • Treatment includes correction of the underlying cause, physical therapy, and biofeedback.

Option A: Gluteus maximus

  • Gluteus maximus paralysis is seen in polio.
  • Paralysis of the gluteus maximus causes a crouching gait, which presents as extensive ankle dorsiflexion with knee and hip flexion.
  • Waddling gait is because of paralysis of hip abductors.

Option B: Gluteus medius

  • This patient is walking with a lurching gait or duck waddling gait
  • Both gluteus medius and minimus must be involved in developing a waddling gait.
  • In gluteus medius paralysis, the body overcompensates by using the back muscles.

Option C: Gluteus minimus

  • This patient is walking lurching gait or duck waddling gait
  • Both gluteus medius and minimus must be involved to produce a waddling gait.
  • Paralysis of gluteus minimus alone will not result in a waddling gait.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child with diarrhea for 2 days presents in a drowsy state. His mother complains that he has not taken any feed since morning and is less responsive to her. On examination, there is tachycardia and tachypnea. He has a very slow skin tone, sunken eyes, and a depressed fontanel. How is the skin pinch said to be very slow?
questions.solution:
Option A: >2 seconds

  • A skin pinch test is done to assess the severity of dehydration in patients with diarrhoea.
  • Pinching the skin on the dorsum of the hand or the abdomen- shows skin turgor and a degree of dehydration.
  • If the skin goes back quickly, this indicates normal hydration.
  • If the skin goes back slowly (<2 sec but not immediately), this is moderate dehydration, and if the skin goes back very slowly (>2 sec), there is severe dehydration.
  • If the skin on the thigh, calf, or forearm is pinched in normal subjects, it returns to its normal state when the pinch is released. This elastic property of the skin is called turgor.

Option B: <2 seconds

  • A skin pinch of less than 2 seconds indicates moderate dehydration.
  • The mentioned findings in this scenario are of moderate dehydration.

Option C: <1 seconds

  • Skin pinch that recoils immediately is categorized as normal.
  • The elastic recoil depends on the level of interstitial volume.

Option D: >5 seconds

  • This is also a very slow skin pinch as the time of flattening back is more than 2 seconds.
  • The patient will require immediate intra-venous rehydration with such a finding.

questions.text: Which spinal segments originate from the nerve marked in the neck region shown below?
questions.solution:
Option A: C2, C3

  • The nerve marked in the image above is the Great Auricular nerve.
  • The great auricular nerve is a part of the cervical plexus and originates from C2 and C3.
  • The great auricular nerve emerges behind the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid, pierces the cervical fascia, and ascends towards the parotid gland.
  • The great auricular nerve divides into two terminal branches: the anterior and posterior.
  • The anterior branch innervates the skin over the parotid gland.
  • The posterior branch innervates the skin over the mastoid process and the posterior surface of the auricle.
  • It also supplies the ear lobule and the conchae.
  • Other nerves having root value of origin from C2 and C3 are
    • Lesser occipital nerve
    • Transverse cervical nerve
    • Greater auricular nerve

Option B: C3, C4

  • Sensory fibers from the lower two segments (C3 - C4) course through the supraclavicular nerves.
  • Motor branches from C3, C4, and C5 unite to form the phrenic nerve.

Option C: C1, C2

  • C1 and C2 (occasionally C3) make up the ansa cervicalis.
  • It has two roots, the superior and the inferior root.
    • The superior root is formed from spinal nerve C1 of the cervical plexus. These nerve fibers travel in the hypoglossal nerve before separating in the carotid triangle to form the superior root.
    • Fibers form the inferior root from spinal nerves C2 and occasionally C3. The inferior root gives off branches to the inferior belly of the omohyoid muscle and the lower parts of the sternothyroid and sternohyoid muscles.

Option D: C4, C5

  • Fibers from the C3, C4, and C5 of the cervical plexus give rise to the phrenic nerve.
  • The phrenic nerve arises from the deep branches of the cervical plexus and not from the superficial branches of the cervical plexus, as shown in the picture.
    • The phrenic nerve supplies motor fibers to the diaphragm.
    • The phrenic nerve also provides sensory innervation to the diaphragm, mediastinal pleura, pericardium, and peritoneum.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressively worsening fatigue and headache for 6 months and occasional upper abdominal pain. He does not drink alcohol and does not smoke. His diet has mostly consisted of potatoes and eggs since his wife passed away 1 year ago. His pulse is 92/min, and his blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival and mucosal pallor. Abdominal and rectal examination shows no abnormalities

The peripheral blood smear of the patient is illustrated in the image below:



Which of the following is the likely aetiology responsible for the clinical manifestation of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Iron deficiency anaemia

  • This patient has iron deficiency anaemia (IDA), the most common cause of anaemia.
  • As his diet did not contain iron rich food .
  • Peripheral blood smear in patients with IDA shows microcytic, hypochromic erythrocytes as seen in this case, though cells can initially be normocytic.
  • IDA often develops in young women because blood loss during menstruation decreases the body's iron stores.
  • Iron studies typically show decreased serum ferritin concentration, decreased transferrin saturation, and elevated total iron binding capacity.
  • The treatment is oral iron replacement therapy.

Option A: Anaemia of chronic disease.

  • Microcytic, hypochromic erythrocytes are not a characteristic feature of anaemia of chronic disease.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

Option B: Aplastic anaemia.

  • Microcytic, hypochromic erythrocytes are not a characteristic feature of Aplastic anaemia.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

Option C: Hereditary spherocytosis

  • Microcytic, hypochromic erythrocytes are not a characteristic feature of Hereditary spherocytosis.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

questions.text: A 53-year-old male presents to his family physician for physical insurance. During the history taking, the doctor came to know that his father had diabetes and died because of congestive heart failure. The patient was told that his father had "bronze diabetes." The patient complains only of arthralgias and vague fatigue. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. The investigation of the patient revealed high levels of serum iron and ferritin. The doctor is concerned that the patient might be at risk of hereditary hemochromatosis. Which of the following tests would the doctor order to confirm his suspicion?
questions.solution:
Option D: Transferrin saturation

  • This is a case of hemochromatosis in which the patient presents to the physician for physical insurance.
  • The patient has complaints of arthralgias and vague fatigue. The investigation of the patient revealed high levels of serum iron and ferritin, which raises the suspicion of hemochromatosis.
  • The screening test recommended for hemochromatosis is serum transferrin saturation.
  • Molecular testing can be performed to look for mutations in the HFE gene on chromosome 6.
  • Its early detection and occasional phlebotomy can prevent multi-organ failure caused by iron accumulation in tissues.

Option A: Antimitochondrial antibodies

  • Antimitochondrial antibodies have no role in the diagnosis of hemochromatosis.
  • It is helpful in the diagnosis of primary biliary cirrhosis.

Option B: Ceruloplasmin

  • Ceruloplasmin is a protein in the liver that stores and carries copper.
  • Ceruloplasmin levels are decreased in Wilson's disease.

Option C: Heterophil antibodies

  • Heterophil antibodies are produced against poorly defined antigens.
  • The testing for heterophil antibodies has a high sensitivity for primary acute EBV infection.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer presents with a four-day history of fever and chest pain. The cardiac catheter examination shows a significantly reduced ejection fraction with normal coronary blood flow; a myocardial biopsy is taken, and a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test for Coxsackie virus is positive for this patient's myocardium is likely to show an increase in which of the following inflammatory cells?
questions.solution:
Option B: Lymphocytes

  • This patient with viral myocarditis shows an increase in lymphocytes in the affected heart muscle.
  • Naive lymphocytes are found with (APC) antigen-presenting cells (macrophages and dendritic cells) in secondary lymphatic organs.
  • Active myocarditis is characterized by an interstitial inflammatory infiltrate associated with degenerating or apoptotic myocytes; larger zones of myocyte drop-out or necrosis with interstitial oedema may reflect vascular injury with secondary ischemic damage.
  • A diffuse, mononuclear, predominantly lymphocytic infiltrate most common. Although endomyocardial biopsies can be diagnostic, they can be spuriously negative because inflammation of the myocardium is patchy.
  • An important host response to viruses consists of cytotoxic T lymphocytes specific for viral proteins, which induce apoptosis of infected cells in an attempt to eliminate reservoirs of infection. During this process, there can be significant tissue damage.
  • The same T-cell–mediated mechanism is responsible for cell death in tumours and cellular rejection of transplants.

Option A: Eosinophils

  • Eosinophils are abundant in immune reactions medi­ated by IgE and in parasitic infections. 
  • Their recruitment is driven by adhesion molecules similar to those used by neutrophils and by specific chemokines (e.g., eotaxin) derived from leukocytes and epithelial cells.
  • Eosinophils have granules that contain a major basic protein, a highly cationic protein that is toxic to parasites but also causes lysis of mammalian epithelial cells.
  • This is why eosinophils are of benefit in controlling parasitic infections, yet they also contribute to tissue damage in immune reactions such as allergies.

Option C: Macrophages

  • The dominant cells in most chronic inflammatory reactions are macrophages, which contribute to the reaction by secreting cytokines and growth factors that act on various cells, destroying foreign invaders and tissues, and by activating other cells, notably T lymphocytes.
  • Macrophages are professional phagocytes that act as filters for particulate matter, microbes, and senescent cells. 
  • They also function as effector cells that eliminate microbes in cellular and humoral immune responses. But they serve many other roles in inflammation and repair.

Option D: Mast cells

  • Mast cells are granulated cells that contain receptors for IgE on the cell surface.
  • Involved in type I hypersensitivity reactions.
  • Mediate local tissue allergic reactions and contain basophilic granules.
  • They originate from the same precursor as basophils but are not the same cell type.
  • Can bind the Fc portion of IgE to the membrane and are activated by tissue trauma, C3a and C5a, surface IgE cross-linking by antigen (IgE receptor aggregation) and their degranulation release of histamine, heparin, tryptase, and eosinophil chemotactic factors.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the hospital for a follow-up examination. Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) and received an allogeneic bone marrow transplant 3 weeks ago. She complains of a skin rash and diarrhoea for three days. Liver function tests show an increase in AST and ALT levels. A skin biopsy reveals a sparse lymphocytic infiltrate in the dermis and epidermis and apoptotic cells in the basal cell layer of the epidermis. Which of the following cells is the primary cause of this patient's skin rash and diarrhoea?
questions.solution:
Option A: Donor lymphocytes

  • This patient’s presentation with rash and diarrhoea after three weeks of bone marrow transplant is most likely due to graft-versus-host disease (GVHD)
  • GVHD is characterised by the following:
    • Diarrhoea
      • The diarrhoea is usually secretory and is often associated with cramping abdominal pain and vomiting.
      • It is not related to eating and occurs at night
    • Dermatitis
      • It is often a painful maculopapular rash.
    • Jaundice
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • It can occur weeks to months after an organ transplant.
  • When lymphocytes in the transplanted tissue recognize and react to the recipient’s cells, GVHD develops.
  • GVHD might ensue when an immunocompromised patient is transfused with blood containing HLA-incompatible cells.

Option B: Donor plasma cells

  • Donor plasma cells are not involved in the clinical manifestations of GVHD.
  • It is the donor’s T cells that cause this.

Option C: Fixed tissue macrophages

  • Fixed tissue macrophages in the recipient can be involved in antigen presentation in acute and chronic rejection of grafts.
  • However, they are not involved in GVHD.

Option D: Recipient lymphocytes

  • Recipient lymphocytes cause acute and chronic rejection of the graft.
  • It occurs due to cell-mediated immunity and recipient T lymphocyte reaction against donor major histocompatibility complexes (MHCs).

questions.text: A 62-year-old female with a history of diabetes mellitus type II for 15 years and end-stage renal disease for 1 year undergoes a kidney transplant in a tertiary care hospital. After three weeks, she complains of fever and pain in the graft region. Further assessment reveals diminished urine output. Laboratory evaluation shows markedly raised creatinine and blood urea nitrogen. On a kidney biopsy, which of the following pathologic findings should be expected?

choices.text: Arterial intimal thickening and vascular stenosis
Interstitial infiltrates of lymphocytes and macrophages

questions.solution:
Option C: Interstitial infiltrates of lymphocytes and macrophages

  • The patient presents with fever and pain in the graft region along with the sudden deterioration of renal function three weeks after a history of renal transplant. These features are most suggestive of acute graft rejection.
  • Graft rejection is a common complication that develops after the transplantation of the organs from donor to recipient.
  • Acute graft rejection typically develops within weeks to months after the transplantation of the organ.
  • The confirmatory diagnostic test for acute rejection is the biopsy and subsequent histopathological examination of the transplanted organ. The biopsy specimen evaluation also helps in determining if the transplant rejection is primarily due to a cellular response or due to a humoral response. This helps to guide the subsequent treatment strategy.

  • The pathological findings of acute transplant rejection of transplanted kidneys include an interstitial infiltrate of lymphocytes and macrophages.

  • The following diagram reveals an intense lymphoid infiltrate after acute transplant rejection of the donor’s kidney:

Option A: Arterial intimal thickening and vascular stenosis

  • Thickening of arterial intima and vascular stenosis, along with the absence of dense interstitial lymphocyte infiltrate, is not consistent with acute transplant rejection of the donor’s kidney.
  • A dominant involvement of arteriosclerosis is suggestive of chronic transplant rejection, which typically develops in months to years.

Option B: Interstitial fibrosis and tubular atrophy

  • The histopathological presentation of acute transplant rejection is dominated by dense infiltration of lymphocytic infiltrates in the interstitium rather than atrophy and fibrosis, which usually develop in the cases of chronic transplant rejection.

Option D: Neutrophilic vasculitis and fibrinoid necrosis

  • A histopathological presentation that shows neutrophilic vasculitis, thrombosis of graft vessels, and fibrinoid necrosis suggest a hyperacute rejection instead of an acute rejection.
  • Hyperacute rejection occurs immediately following transplantation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman complains of recent easy fatigability, bruising, and recurrent throat infections. Physical examination reveals numerous petechiae over her body and mouth. Abnormal laboratory findings include haemoglobin of 6 g/dL, WBC of 1,500/mL, and platelets of 20,000/mL. The bone marrow is hypocellular and displays increased fat. What is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Aplastic anaemia

  • Aplastic anaemia is characterised by fatigue, malaise, Pallor, Purpura, petechiae, mucosal bleeding, and Infection.
  • Given features suggests the diagnosis of Aplastic anaemia [anaemia, leukopenia (primarily granulocytopenia)& thrombocytopenia]
  • Aplastic anaemia is a disorder of pluripotent stem cells causing bone marrow failure resulting in hypocellular bone marrow & pancytopenia
  • Treatment includes:
    • Cessation of the causative agent
    • Bone marrow stimulants (e.g., GM-CSF, eltrombopag)
    • Immunosuppressive therapy
    • Consider hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) in young patients

 

Option B: Iron-deficiency anaemia

  • Iron deficiency anaemia can be caused by inadequate intake, decreased absorption, increased demand, or increased iron loss.
  • Symptoms are nonspecific and include fatigue, pallor, lethargy, hair loss, brittle nails, and pica. 
  •  A low ferritin level is diagnostic for iron deficiency. 
  • Iron deficiency anaemia is treated with oral or parenteral iron supplementation. 
  •  Iron deficiency anaemia is not characterised by the hypoplastic bone marrow.   
  • Findings of bone marrow biopsy show decreased or absent stainable iron stores

Option C: Megaloblastic anaemia

  • Megaloblastic anaemia: impaired DNA synthesis or repair (e.g., Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency)
  • Megaloblastic anaemia is treated with oral or parenteral iron supplementation.
  • Peripheral smear shows hypersegmented neutrophils

Option D: Acute Leukaemia

  • A group of conditions characterised by an increase in premature leukocytes that are subsequently released into the bloodstream
  • Acute leukaemias are characterised by the proliferation of immature, nonfunctional WBCs (blasts) in the bone marrow, which impairs hematopoiesis. This leads to pancytopenia.
  • Bone marrow does not show hypocellularity or increased fat.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department complaining of tingling in her hands and feet for 1 day with rapidly progressing severe muscle cramps, laryngeal stridor, and convulsions. Moreover, she has undergone a total thyroidectomy 2 days earlier for papillary thyroid carcinoma. Which laboratory findings would be expected in this patient before initiating treatment?

choices.text: Decreased serum calcium and decreased PTH
Decreased serum calcium and increased PTH
Increased serum calcium and decreased PTH
Increased serum calcium and increased PTH

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: Decreased serum calcium and increased PTH: This combination is typical of hypoparathyroidism. However, the symptoms described in the case, including laryngeal stridor and convulsions, indicate severe hypocalcemia, which would not be accompanied by increased PTH levels.

Decreased serum calcium and increased PTH, which indicates hypoparathyroidism due to the removal or damage of the parathyroid glands during the thyroidectomy. This condition requires prompt treatment with intravenous calcium and vitamin D supplements to raise the calcium levels and stabilize the patient.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Decreased serum calcium and decreased PTH: This option suggests hypoparathyroidism, which fits the clinical scenario. However, the patient would not have decreased serum calcium and decreased PTH concurrently.

Option C: Increased serum calcium and decreased PTH: This combination is not consistent with the clinical presentation or the underlying pathology. Increased calcium levels would not cause hypoparathyroidism (decreased PTH).

Option D: Increased serum calcium and increased PTH: This combination would suggest hyperparathyroidism, a condition characterized by high calcium levels and increased PTH secretion. It does not align with the symptoms and clinical scenario described in the case.

questions.text: A 34-years-old male presents to the physician with complaints of small painless nodules on his penis for 5 days. He further explains that later, the nodules burst and created open, fleshy, oozing lesions, becoming a beefy red ulcer in the genital region. He is a sexual history and is HIV positive. He is vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. Which of the following organism is involved in the patient's current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option A: Klebsiella granulomatis

  • This is a case of donovanosis in which the patient presents with complaints of small painless nodules on his penis for 5 days. Later, the nodules burst and created open, fleshy, oozing lesions, becoming a beefy red ulcer in the genital region.
  • The causative organism is Klebsiella granulomatis.
  • Small, painless nodules appear after about 10–40 days of contact with the bacteria.
  • Later, the nodules burst, creating open, fleshy, oozing lesions.
  • The lesions occur at the region of contact typically found on the shaft of the penis, the labia, or the perineum.
  • No other option above presents with a "beefy-red ulcer".

Option B: Chlamydia trachomatis

  • Chlamydia trachomatis has serotypes of L1, L2 and L3.
  • It usually causes lymphogranuloma venereum.

Option C: Neisseria gonorrhoea

  • Neisseria gonorrhoea usually causes gonorrhoea.
  • It usually presents as urethritis or cervicitis.

Option D: Hemophilus ducreyi

  • Hemophilus ducreyi causes chancroid.
  • Chancroid is a painful genital ulcer.

questions.text: The skeletal muscle morphology comprises many structural proteins, and their interaction brings about skeletal muscle contraction. Which of the following is the constituent of the marked area in the electron microscopic muscle picture?
questions.solution:
Option B: Actinin

  • Actin and myosin are the contractile proteins of the skeletal muscle.
  • In addition to myosin and actin, other structural proteins important in skeletal muscle function include actinin, titin, and desmin.
  • These proteins are important in maintaining the structure of the skeletal muscle fibers and allowing contractile function.
  • Actinin binds actin to the Z-lines.
  • Titin is the largest known protein that connects the Z-lines to the M-lines and provides scaffolding for the sarcomere. It contains two folded domains that provide the muscle with its elasticity. At first, when the muscle is stretched, there is relatively little resistance as the domains unfold, but with further stretch, there is a rapid increase in resistance that protects the structure of the sarcomere.
  • Desmin adds structure to the Z-lines in part by binding the Z-lines to the plasma membrane. It is a muscle-specific type III intermediate filament that integrates the Z disk and sarcolemma and is encoded by the DES gene.
  • The marked area is the Z line. Actin is bound to the Z-lines by α-actinin, and CapZ proteins anchor the thin filaments to the Z-lines.
  • Actinin is a microfilament protein. α-Actinin is necessary to attach actin filaments to the Z-lines in skeletal muscle cells and the dense bodies in smooth muscle cells. The functional protein is an anti-parallel dimer, which cross-links the thin filaments in adjacent sarcomeres.

Option A: Titin

  • Titin is attached to the Z-line, and it aligns the thick filament in the sarcomere.
  • It keeps the myosin and actin filaments in place. Also, it provides the maintenance between the myosin and actin filaments to allow the functioning of the sarcomere.
  • One end of the titin molecule is attached to the Z disk, acting as a spring and changing length as the sarcomere contracts and relaxes. The other part of the titin molecule tethers it to the thick myosin filaments.

Option C: Nebulin

  • Nebulin is an actin-binding protein that is localized to the thin filament of the sarcomeres in skeletal muscle.

Option D: Dystrophin

  • Dystrophin is attached to the ends of thin filaments (toward the center of the sarcomere); it extends from the thin filament to the sarcolemma.
  • Dystrophin is attached to the ends of thin filaments (toward the center of the sarcomere); it extends from the thin filament to the sarcolemma

questions.text: A practical lab is arranged for students to make them learn about muscle contraction. Frogs after dissection are used as specimens. Electrodes are connected to the exposed muscle of the frog leg to induce muscle twitch. Students find out that the latent period of muscle cramps is 10 ms, the contraction period is 40 ms, and the relaxation time is 50 ms. What would be the tetanizing frequency?
questions.solution:
Option A: 25 Hz

  • The summation of the muscle force caused by an increase in the firing rate is named a tetanic contraction (tetanus), and the minimum stimulation frequency necessary to evoke unfused/fused tetanus is related to the contraction time (CT) and relaxation time (RT) of the cramp.
  • For tetanus to occur, the stimulus must repeatedly fall in the contraction phase, which will cause the accumulation of Ca++ in the myoplasm leading to sustained contraction.
  • Tetanizing frequency = 1 ÷ time of contraction phase (in a sec)
  • Contraction period = 40ms
  • Tetanizing frequency = 1/40ms = 1000/40s = 25 Hz

questions.text: A 38-year-old male visits the clinic complaining of progressively enlarging discolored whitish patches near both ankles for the last five months. He has a history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis. On examination, hypopigmented patches are present near both ankles with surrounding normal skin. The rest of the body is spared. Which of the following has no documented role in managing this patient's underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has a progressive appearance of hypopigmented patches near both ankles with surrounding normal skin and a history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis (autoimmune disorder), most likely suffers from vitiligo.

  • Characterized by autoimmune destruction of melanocytes resulting in depigmented lesions appearing all over the body.
  • It can be triggered by stress or a skin injury such as burns.
  • Presents as irregular, well-demarcated, depigmented patches surrounded by normal skin.
  • Leukotrichia, the presence of depigmented hair, indicates a poor prognosis.

Option B: Topical tretinoin

  • Tropical tretinoin is not helpful for the treatment of vitiligo
  • Topical retinoids like tretinoin are used in acne.

Option A: Topical clobetasol

  • Topical steroids like clobetasol and betamethasone are used for the treatment of vitiligo.

Option C: Topical tacrolimus

  • Tacrolimus is a Calcineurin inhibitor that is helpful in the treatment of vitiligo.

Option D: Topical methoxsalen

  • Topical methoxsalen is Psoralen used for managing vitiligo.
  • In Phototherapy
    • PUVA: Psoralen (applied topically or taken orally) followed by UVA exposure.
    • PUVASOL: Psoralen (applied topically or taken orally) followed by sunlight exposure.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient had Parkinson's disease diagnosed. He was examined by a neurologist and was started on a combination of carbidopa and levodopa medication. Although the prescribing physician noted no improvement in his parkinsonian symptoms, the medication was continued. The patient developed memory problems a year later, and Alzheimer's disease was diagnosed. Recently, the patient began experiencing frequent visual hallucinations. The provisional diagnosis of Lewy body dementia was made, and the patient was given donepezil 5 mg at bedtime, and levodopa was stopped. He showed improvement. All of the following can be seen in this patient, except
questions.solution:
Option C: Autonomic dysfunction

  • The above given is a case of Lewy body dementia.
  • Lewy body dementia gives both cognitive and motor symptoms.
  • And usually comes within one year.
  • 10 to 20% of cases
  • It is the second most common neurodegenerative disorder
  • More common in male
  • Symptoms are extra-pyramidal motor symptoms like rigors and bradykinesia.
  • Visual hallucination and increased sensation to neuroleptic sensation.
  • MRI is diagnostic and shows atrophy of substantia innominata and mesopontine grey matter.
  • Cerebral atrophy.
  • Treatment is symptomatic, supportive, behavioral, physical, and pharmacotherapy.

Revised criteria for the clinical diagnosis of

Lewy body dementia:

1. Fluctuating cognition

2. Recurrent Visual hallucination

3. REM sleep behavior disorder

4. Cardinal features of Parkinsonism (one or more)

It can be mistaken for Parkinsonism, and autonomic dysfunction is less common than the above findings in LBD.

Option A: Recurrent visual hallucination

  • It is the false perception of sight.
  • The most common type of hallucination is in a patient with delirium and dementia.
  • Visual hallucination and increased sensation to neuroleptic sensation is the characteristic of Lewy body dementia.

Option B: Spontaneous motor features

  • It generates muscle contraction in the form of muscle stitches.
  • These muscle stitches produce muscle forces.
  • It describes the regular and repeated movement's pace.
  • Lewy body dementia gives both cognitive and motor symptoms.

Option D: Fluctuating cognition

  • It is characterized by cognitive impairment with alternating periods and pronounced variations in attention and alertness.
  • It is present in Parkinson's disease and Alzheimer’s disease.
  • Fluctuating cognition is the characteristic of Lewy body dementia.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presented to the hospital with profuse watery diarrhoea, vomiting, stomach pain, leg cramps and irritability. The physician is suspecting cholera as the diagnosis. Which of the following is an inappropriate statement regarding the given condition?

choices.text: Azithromycin is first like drug for adults
It is a notifiable disease locally, nationally, and internationally

questions.solution:
Option C: Azithromycin is first like drug for adults

  • For adult patients, doxycycline is the first like drug for adults
  • Cholera is caused by Vibrio cholera - ELTOR (hybrid) - the most common subtype in India now.
  • Route of transmission - FECO-ORAL ROUTE
Groups Antibiotic of choice for cholera
Adults Doxycycline (hence option-C is wrong)
Children Azithromycin
Pregnancy Azithromycin
Chemoprophylaxis Tetracycline

Other options

Option A: Incubation period is 1-2 days

  • The incubation period varies from a few hours to five days, but often one to two days.

Option B: Rice – watery diarrhea

  • Diarrhea is the primary symptom of cholera. 
  • The symptoms begin suddenly and include intense, painless, watery diarrhea followed by vomiting u Up to 40 stools could be passed by the patient each day. The stools might appear as "rice water."

Option D: It is a notifiable disease locally, nationally, and internationally

  • Cholera is a notifiable disease locally, nationally, and internationally.

questions.text: A study comparing cases with non-cases of breast cancer found that 75/100 cases used calcium supplements compared with 25/100 of the non-cases. What is the cross-product ratio of this study?
questions.solution:
Option A: 9

  • The cross-product ratio (also known as the odds ratio) is a measure used in epidemiology to assess the association between exposure and outcome in a case-control study. In this case, you have the following information:
    • Number of cases exposed (used calcium supplements): 75
    • Number of cases not exposed: 100 - 75 = 25
    • Number of non-cases exposed: 25
    • Number of non-cases not exposed: 100 - 25 = 75
  • Odds ratio = ad/bc
  Breast Cancer Cases Non-cases
Used Ca supplements 75 (a) 25 (b)
Did not use Ca supplements 25 (c) 75 (d)
  100 100
  • Odds ratio = ad/bc = 75*75/25*25 = 9
  • So, the cross-product ratio (odds ratio) for this study is 9. This indicates that cases are 9 times more likely to have used calcium supplements compared to non-cases, suggesting a potential association between calcium supplement use and breast cancer in this study population.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the clinic to evaluate the back pain and pain in her hands. She has a regular menstrual cycle and does not take any medication. She also complained of occasional abdominal pain. On examination, no swelling, neurologic features, or visible deformities are noted. She denies any fever or morning stiffness. Serum calcium is elevated in the laboratory analysis. An X-ray of the hands shows the following findings. Which of the following finding is not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Punched out lesion of the skull

  • Punched lesion of the skull is not seen in hyperparathyroidism. It's a feature of Multiple myeloma
  • Multiple myeloma: Lytic tumor
  • Feature of MM: Bone pain + High E.S.R. + Hypercalcemia

X-ray Features of Hyperparathyroidism:

  • Osteoporosis (sometimes including vertebral collapse) and areas of cortical
  •  erosion
  • Hyperparathyroidism 'brown tumors': atypical cyst-like lesions of long bones
  • Sub-periosteal cortical resorption of the middle phalanges, The classical and almost pathognomonic feature as in this case.
  • Don't confuse it with enchondroma because middle age and female gender point more towards hyperparathyroidism.
  • Parathyroid hormone and serum calcium levels measurement is required to confirm the diagnosis

Option A: Osteopenia

  • The given X-ray depicts a Brown tumor, which is a characteristic feature of hyperparathyroidism
  • Osteopenia is a characteristic feature of hyperparathyroidism

Option B: Renal stones

  • In hyperparathyroidism, excessive PTH levels cause Renal stone

Option D: Brown tumor

  • The above condition is hyperparathyroidism. Image showing Brown tumor
  • "Brown tumors": Sub-periosteal cortical resorption of the middle phalanges.

questions.text: A patient previously diagnosed with chronic congestive heart failure came in for a regular check-up. ECG taken revealed a short QTc, and given that the patient has had a history of kidney stones, you suspect it could be due to hypercalcemia. The serum electrolytes test indicates a calcium level of 12.5 mg/dL. Which diuretic among the following would you choose to manage this patient, considering the added requirement to alleviate hypercalcemia?
questions.solution:
Option A: Furosemide

  • Loop diuretics inhibit the luminal NA+/K+/2Cl- transporter in the thick ascending loop of Henle.
  • By inhibiting this transporter, the loop diuretics  reduce the reabsorption of NaCl and also diminish the lumen-positive potential that comes from K+ recycling. 
  • This positive potential normally drives divalent cation reabsorption in the thick ascending limb, and by reducing this potential, loop diuretics can cause an increase in Mg++ and Ca++ excretion.  

Option B: Spironolactone

  • Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that inhibits the action of aldosterone on principal and α-intercalated cells and decreases the excretion of K+ and H+ ions.
  • It has no role in calcium excretion.

Option C: Hydrochlorothiazide

  • Thiazides enhance calcium reabsorption; this enhancement has been postulated to result from effects in both the proximal and distal convoluted tubules.
  • In the proximal tubule, thiazide-induced volume depletion leads to enhanced Na+ and Ca++ reabsorption.
  • In distal convoluted tubule, lowering of intracellular Na+ by thiazide-induced blockade of Na+ entry enhances Na+/Ca++ exchange in the basolateral membrane and increases overall reabsorption of Ca++.

Option D: Mannitol

  • Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic. It has a major effect on the proximal tubule and the descending limb of Henle’s loop.
  • Through osmotic effects, they also oppose the action of anti-diuretic hormone (ADH) in the collecting tubule. 
  • The presence of a non-absorbable solute, such as mannitol, prevents the normal absorption of water by interposing a countervailing osmotic force.
  • As a result, urine volume increases.
  • The increase in urine flow decreases the contact time between fluid and the tubular epithelium, thus reducing Na+ as well as water reabsorption.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male presents to the outpatient department for a follow-up checkup. The patient is a known case of bronchial asthma. On examination, he appears healthy; his pulse is 76/min, respirations are 15/min, and his blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. While reviewing medications, it is noted that the patient is taking oral theophylline and inhaled fluticasone. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of action of theophylline?
questions.solution:
Option C: Phosphodiesterase inhibitor

  • This patient, who is suffering from bronchial asthma and is now presenting for follow-up, is on theophylline. Theophylline is a methylxanthine derivative. It is used as adjunctive therapy for maintaining asthma and COPD due to its anti-inflammatory and mild bronchodilatory effects. However, it is no longer recommended for use in acute asthma exacerbations. The mechanism of action of theophylline is phosphodiesterase inhibition which inhibits the degradation of cAMP. Consequently, the concentration of the cAMP increases resulting in bronchodilation.
  • The mechanism of action of theophylline is illustrated in the image below:

Option A: Mast cell stabilizer

  • Sodium cromoglycate is a mast cell stabilizer used for the prophylaxis of asthma. It is not the mechanism of action of theophylline.

Option B: Leukotriene antagonist

  • Montelukast and zafirlukast are leukotriene antagonist. However, Leukotriene antagonism is not the mechanism of action of theophylline.

Option D: Leukotriene synthesis inhibitor

  • Zileuton is a lipoxygenase inhibitor (LOX inhibitor). LOX inhibition is not the mechanism of action of theophylline.
  • The drugs used for asthma and their mechanism of action are summarized in the image below:

questions.text: For a 43-year-old woman with endometriosis and a family history of uterine fibroids and ischemic heart disease, which treatment option would not be considered due to its short-term use of 6 months to prepare for surgery?
questions.solution:
Option C: Degarelix

  • Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterine cavity.
  • Retrograde menstrual flow may result in endometriosis.
  • The signs and symptoms of endometriosis are pelvic pain, usually worse during periods, pain during sexual intercourse, urination, defecation, excessive bleeding, infertility, etc.
  • Pelvic examination, ultrasound, MRI, and laparoscopy may be used to diagnose the condition.
  • Untreated endometriosis may result in endometrial-like tissue that grows outside your uterus and can cause cysts, adhesions, and scar tissue.
  • Estradiol is the main hormone involved in the growth and persistence of endometrial tissue. It results in pain and inflammation associated with it. So, endometriosis is an estrogen-dependent disease. Decrease in estrogen levels of the
  • Multiple options are available for the management of endometriosis. They include NSAIDs, OCPs, progestin, GnRH analogs, etc. Surgery may also be needed in some cases.
  • GnRH Agonist Drugs include Leuprolide, nafarelin, goserelin, buserelin, etc. They all have flared-up reactions as adverse effects when given in a continuous form.
  • They act as GnRH agonists when used in the pulsatile form. When used in the continuous form, they first act as GnRH agonists and then as GnRH antagonists.
  • GnRH analogue can be used in the management of uterine fibroids, precocious puberty, endometriosis, prostate cancer, infertility,
  • Adverse effects of GnRH agonists include nausea, vomiting, erectile dysfunction, decreased libido, and hypogonadism.
  • GnRH antagonist such as Degarelix is not used in the management of endometriosis.
  • GnRH Antagonist Drugs include cetrorelix, ganirelix, abarelix, degarelix, etc.
  • Degarelix has no start flare up. It is used in prostate cancer. Adverse effects include liver toxicity and hot flares.

 

Option A: Leuprolide

  • Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist used in the management of endometriosis.
  • It works by downregulating the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. It leads to the suppression of ovulation and a decrease in blood estrogen levels.

 

Option B: Nafarelin

  • Nafarelin is a GnRH agonist used in the management of endometriosis.
  • It works by downregulating the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. It leads to the suppression of ovulation and a decrease in blood estrogen levels.

 

Option D: Buserelin

  • Buserelin is a GnRH agonist used in the management of endometriosis.
  • It works by downregulating the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis. It leads to the suppression of ovulation and a decrease in blood estrogen levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is a gender-specific adverse effect of valproate?
questions.solution:
Option A: PCOD

  • Side effects of valproate include
    • Vomiting
    • Alopecia
    • Hepatotoxicity
    • Pancreatitis
    • Cytochrome P-450 inhibition
    • Rash
    • Weight gain
    • Tremor
    • Neural tube defects
    • Epigastric pain
    • Polycystic ovarian disease is a gender-specific adverse effect of valproate.

Option B: Weight gain

  • Valproate causes weight gain.
  • Weight loss is a side effect of topiramate.

Option C: Alopecia

  • Hirsutism can be caused by valproic acid as a consequence of PCOD, independent hirsutism is caused by phenytoin.
  • Valproate causes alopecia.

Option D: Hepatotoxicity

  • Due to a metabolite of valproate. This metabolite is produced more if given with carbamazepine-like drugs. So they produce more hepatotoxicity

questions.text: A young male patient, aged 20 years, presents to OPD with recurrent oral pain and genital ulcers; he further states that the oral ulcers have healed without a scar but the genital ulcers healed with scars. He also complains of skin bumps over his trunk that appear as subcutaneous nodules. He also complained of headaches and blurred vision for 1 week. As he visited the doctor and underwent investigations, his HLA B51 was positive. Which criteria are in the revised guidelines to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ocular lesion

  • The given clinical condition shows the clinical features of Behcet's disease.
  • Behcet disease is a rare autoimmune disorder that causes inflammation in vessels all over the body; hence, various symptoms occur. 

  • Criteria for diagnosis of Behcet disease:
    • Ocular lesions
    • Genital aphthosis
    • Oral aphthosis
    • Skin lesions
    • Neurological manifestations

Treatment:

  • Minor eye injuries may be treated with the following: Ice packs help ​​​​reduce swelling and pain 
  • Flush chemicals and other irritants from your eyes for about 15 minutes with clean water.
  • Eye drops: Your provider may prescribe eye drops to aid in healing your eye.

Option B: Pathergy phenomenon

  • Pathergy reaction is the formation of non-healing skin lesions or ulcers due to minor injuries.
  • BD, Sweet's syndrome, inflammatory bowel disease, and spondyloarthropathies are common causes of this reaction.
  • The Pathergy test is optional, and the primary scoring system does not include Pathergy testing.
  • However, where Pathergy testing is conducted, one extra point may be assigned for a positive result.
  • The patient has to get 3 or more points to be diagnosed/classified as having Crohn's Disease.

Option C: Vasculitis

  • Vasculitis is defined as an inflammation of the blood vessels.
  • An infection or medication could cause this, but the cause is often unknown.
  • Vasculitis can range from a minor skin problem to a more serious illness that causes problems with organs such as the heart or kidneys.
  • The precise cause of vasculitis is unknown.
  • A person's ancestry influences some types. Others are the result of the immune system mistakenly attacking blood vessel cells.

Option D: Skin lesions

  • A skin lesion is any area of skin that differs from the surrounding skin in terms of colour, shape, size, and texture.
  • Skin lesions are very common and frequently appear due to localized skin damage, such as sunburns or contact dermatitis.
  • A skin lesion is a section of skin with abnormal growth or appearance compared to the surrounding skin.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man with hallucinations, abdominal pain, and weakness in upper extremities. He smokes a pack a day for two months.  The deep tendon reflexes are decreased in the upper extremities.. Normal vital signs and lab parameters except for urine color change. Which of the following statements is true regarding this patient's underlying condition?

choices.text: It is an autosomal recessive disease
This condition is exacerbated by progesterone
Photosensitivity can be seen in severe sun exposure

questions.solution:
Option B: This condition is exacerbated by progesterone

  • Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) is an autosomal dominant human disease characterized by acute abdominal pain and neurological symptoms, muscle weakness, and neuropsychiatric symptoms also, e.g., hallucinations, psychosis, etc.
  • There is a partial deficiency of porphobilinogen deaminase (PBGD).
  • The porphyrin precursors, porphobilinogen (PBG), and delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) accumulate in the body.
  • This condition is exacerbated by cytochrome inducers, e.g., some medications (progesterone), smoking, alcohol, fasting, surgery, etc.
  • Autonomic dysfunction, such as hypertension, tachycardia, and diaphoresis, is also seen.
  • The patient's urine color is red-tinged initially, but it becomes lighter on air or light exposure.
  • Diagnosis is made by measuring serum and blood levels of PBG, ALA, and porphyrins, which would be raised.
  • It is commonly treated by hemin, glucose, and beta-carotene.

Option A: It is an autosomal recessive disease

  • Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) is an autosomal dominant, not a recessive disease.
  • Autosomal dominant mean the disease will result even when one of the alleles of gene is mutated.

Option C: Photosensitivity can be seen in severe sun exposure

  • Skin lesions are not the findings in acute intermittent porphyria (AIP); these are the diagnostic points in porphyria cutanea tarda.
  • A block early in pathway of heme synthesis only cause neurological symptoms due to ALA and PBG accumulation which inhibits neurotransmitter GABA action.

 Option D: Hypertension can not be seen

  • Autonomic dysfunction is an important component of acute intermittent porphyria (AIP), such as hypertension, increased heart rate, and diaphoresis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presented to the physician’s office complaining of palpitations and dizziness for the past few weeks. She had no history of syncope and was taking medication for rate control. On physical examination, the pulse is 69 beats per minute, and the blood pressure is 85/69 mm Hg. Which of the following is the best drug for the rhythm disorder shown below?
questions.solution:
Option B: Amiodarone

Atrial flutter 4:1

  1. A re-entry circuit in the right atrium causes an atrial flutter, a kind of supraventricular tachycardia. The atrial rate is approximately 300 beats per minute (200-400).
  2. The 4:1 block shows inverted flutter waves in II, III and aVF at a rate of 260 beats per minute and a ventricular rate of 65 beats per minute. Upright flutter waves are seen in V1-V2 leads.
  3. Patients with atrial flutter present with palpitations, lightheadedness, fatigue and shortness of breath. There are episodes of hypotension, syncope and dizziness; on examination, there is tachycardia, crackles in lung fields and signs of heart failure in advanced cases.
  4. Beta-blockers should not be used in patients experiencing acute LVF. The video shows Atrial flutter with a 4:1 block with a normal heart rate. To stabilise the macro-reentrant circuit, for rhythm control, amiodarone is used. Other drugs used are sotalol, dofetilide, and disopyramide.
  5. Amiodarone acts on multiple channels and pathways:
  • Na channel blocker
  • K+ channel blocker
  • Ca+ channel blocker
  • β-blocker property

Option A: Esmolol

  • Esmolol is a second-generation (cardio-selective) β1 blocker
  • It is the shortest acting β Blocker. However, they are effective for rate control.

Option C: Vernakalant

  • An atrial-selective drug called vernakalant quickly shuts down potassium and sodium ion channels in all stages of the atrial action potential. It is commonly used for atrial fibrillation.

Option D: Lignocaine

  • DOC for digitalis-induced ventricular arrhythmia is Lignocaine. If it is not available, the alternate is Phenytoin.

questions.text:
ASSERTION: A decreased calcium level interferes with blood clotting in a healthy person.

REASON: Calcium is coagulation factor IV.

Which of the following conclusions about the assertion and the reason is true?

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement
Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement

questions.solution:
Option D: Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true/correct statement

A. A decreased calcium level interferes with blood clotting in a healthy person.

  • In vivo, a plasma Ca2+ level low enough to interfere with blood clotting is incompatible with life. Still, clotting can be prevented in vitro if Ca2+ is removed from the blood by adding substances such as oxalates, which form insoluble salts with Ca2+, or chelating agents, which bind Ca2+. In vivo, fatal tetany would occur before the clotting reaction would be compromised.

B. Calcium is factor IV.

  • It is a correct statement. Calcium is factor IV of the clotting cascade.

Option A: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion

  • The assertion is the incorrect statement: In vivo, a plasma Ca2+ level low enough to interfere with blood clotting is incompatible with life, but clotting can be prevented in vitro if Ca2+ is removed from the blood by the addition of substances such as oxalates, which form insoluble salts with Ca2+, or chelating agents, which bind Ca2+. In vivo, fatal tetany would occur before the clotting reaction would be compromised.
  • The reason is a correct statement. Calcium is factor IV of the clotting cascade.

Option B: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion

  • The assertion is the incorrect statement: In vivo, a plasma Ca2+ level low enough to interfere with blood clotting is incompatible with life, but clotting can be prevented in vitro if Ca2+ is removed from the blood by the addition of substances such as oxalates, which form insoluble salts with Ca2+, or chelating agents, which bind Ca2+. In vivo, fatal tetany would occur before the clotting reaction would be compromised.
  • The reason is a correct statement. Calcium is factor IV of the clotting cascade.

Option C: Assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reasons is independently a false/incorrect statement

  • The assertion is the incorrect statement: In vivo, a plasma Ca2+ level low enough to interfere with blood clotting is incompatible with life, but clotting can be prevented in vitro if Ca2+ is removed from the blood by the addition of substances such as oxalates, which form insoluble salts with Ca2+, or chelating agents, which bind Ca2+. In vivo, fatal tetany would occur before the clotting reaction would be compromised.
  • The reason is a correct statement. Calcium is factor IV of the clotting cascade.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of severe lower back pain for 2 days. The pain began after she tried to move some heavy objects off the floor. The patient identifies the pain as 7 out of 10 in intensity. The patient also reports that she has had intermittent diarrhoea, bloating, and a 12-kg weight loss for the past 3 years. Menarche occurred at the age of 12 years, and her menstrual cycle is irregular. She is inconsistent with her diet. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She appears pale. She is 153 cm (5 ft) tall and weighs 40 kg (88 lb); her BMI is 17 kg/m2. Examination of the back shows spinal tenderness at the L1 vertebral level. There is proximal muscle weakness in the lower limbs. The rest of the review of the system is unremarkable. Laboratory studies show elevated alkaline phosphate, low calcium, and low phosphate. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Vitamin D deficiency

  • This patient with intermittent diarrhoea, bloating, and weight loss has celiac disease (CD). Intestinal malabsorption (e.g., due to CD) can result in fat-soluble vitamin deficiency (particularly vitamin D). Vitamin D deficiency may cause osteomalacia.
  • Osteomalacia is characterised by impaired mineralisation of the osteoid.
  • The clinical presentation of osteomalacia includes bone pain and tenderness, pathological fractures, difficulty walking, myopathy, and symptoms of hypocalcemia.
  • Individuals with CD are also at increased risk of developing osteoporosis.
  • Additional causes of vitamin D deficiency include:
  • Insufficient sun exposure
  • Low dietary intake of vitamin D
  •  Treatment with anticonvulsants such as phenytoin, liver cirrhosis
  •  Chronic kidney disease
  • Vitamin D supplementation and treatment of the underlying causes are the options for treatment.

Option A: Paget's disease

  • Paget's disease of bone (PDB, or osteitis deformans) is characterised by increased bone turnover.
  • It causes the normal lamellar bone to be replaced by weak woven bone.
  • It generally affects individuals in their 50s.
  • The Clinical manifestation includes localised pain and bony deformities (such as bowing of long bones).
  • The serum levels of calcium and phosphate will be normal with a raised serum concentration of alkaline phosphatase.
  • Treatment is mainly supportive and involves bisphosphonates to inhibit osteoclastic function.

Option B: Osteoporosis

  • Osteoporosis is a skeletal condition that usually affects the elderly during the postmenopausal period. It is characterised by the loss of bone mineral density leading to decreased bone strength and an increased frequency of pathological fractures. Furthermore, the serum levels of calcium, phosphate, and alkaline phosphatase will be expected.

Option C: Primary Hyperparathyroidism

  • Hyperparathyroidism (HPT) is characterised by abnormally high parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels in the blood due to overactivity of the parathyroid glands. Primary HPT is usually caused by parathyroid adenomas (or, in rare cases, by parathyroid carcinomas). Further, it is characterised by an elevated parathyroid hormone, calcium levels, and increased bone turnover.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man presents to the physician complaining of a 3-week history of intractable hiccups and shortness of breath on exertion. He also has a 1-month history of left shoulder pain. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Physical examination shows decreased breath sounds at the left lung base. An X-ray of the chest shows a 3-cm perihilar mass and elevation of the left hemidiaphragm. These symptoms of the patient are most likely caused by injury to which of the following structure?
questions.solution:
Option B: Phrenic nerve

  • A mediastinal lung tumor could compress the phrenic nerve, a diagnosis of high clinical suspicion in this patient, given his smoking history and the perihilar mass is seen on imaging.
  • Each phrenic nerve provides motor and sensory supply to the ipsilateral hemidiaphragm and to the fibrous pericardium and the mediastinal and diaphragmatic pleura.
  • Pericarditis pain is often referred to as the shoulder due to common innervation via the phrenic nerve.

Phrenic nerve:

  • The phrenic nerve arises in the neck from the anterior rami of C3, C4, and C5.
  • The right phrenic nerve descends in the thorax along the right side of the brachiocephalic vein and the superior vena cava.
  • The left phrenic nerve descends in the thorax along the left side of the left subclavian artery.
  • The phrenic nerve possesses both efferent and afferent fibers.
  • The efferent fibers are the sole motor supply to the muscle of the diaphragm.
  • The afferent fibers carry sensation to the CNS from the peritoneum covering the central region the under the surface of the diaphragm.

Option A: Esophagus

  • Because the symptoms mentioned in this case are most likely caused due to the compression of the phrenic nerve.

Option C: Vagus nerve

  • It regulate heart rate,respiratory rate, digestion, vasomotor activity ,cough reflex, sneezing, swallowing, vomting.
  • Because the symptoms mentioned in this case are most likely caused due to the compression of the phrenic nerve.

Option D: Gastric artery branches

  • There are 2 gastric arteries right and left gastric artery
  • Right gastric artery arise from proper hepatic artery
  • Left gastric artery arise directly from celiac trunk
  • Because the symptoms mentioned in this case are most likely caused due to the compression of the phrenic nerve.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea and cyclic abdominal pain but no menstruation. Physical examination shows normal secondary sexual characteristics and external genitalia, but speculum examination is challenging due to a shallow vaginal canal. Ultrasound reveals an absent uterus and aplasia of the upper vagina. Which embryonic structures contribute to the development of the lower vagina?
questions.solution:
Option C: Sinovaginal bulb

  • In the clinical scenario above, the girl has presented with Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome.
  • It is distinguished by the congenital absence of a uterus and upper vagina, also described as Mullerian aplasia.
  • Symptoms include primary amenorrhea with normal development of secondary sexual characteristics.
  • Physical examination reveals the complete or partial absence of the cervix, uterus and vagina. The ovaries are, however, intact.
  • The fibromuscular wall of the vagina grows from the encompassing mesenchyme.
  • Contact of the uterovaginal primordium with the urogenital sinus, forming the sinus tubercle, induces the formation of paired endodermal outgrowths, the sinovaginal bulbs.
  • They extend from the urogenital sinus to the caudal end of the uterovaginal primordium.
  • The sinovaginal bulbs fuse to form a vaginal plate.
  • The distance between the urogenital sinus and the uterus increases by the proliferation at the cranial end of the plate.
  • The vaginal outgrowth is entirely canalized by the 5th week.

The expansions of the vagina around the end of the uterus, known as the vaginal fornices, are of paramesonephric origin. Therefore, the vagina has a dual origin, with the upper portion derived from the uterine canal and the lower portion derived from the urogenital sinus.

Option A: Mesonephric duct

  • The mesonephric ducts (Wolffian ducts) have an important part in the development of the male reproductive system.
  • The proximal part of each mesonephric duct forms a highly convoluted epididymis under the influence of testosterone.
  • Distal to the epididymis, the mesonephric duct acquires a thick investment of smooth muscle and becomes the ductus deferens.
  • Mesonephric ducts are also responsible for forming the ureter, renal pelvis with their collecting tubules, ejaculatory duct and seminal gland in males.

Option B: Paramesonephric duct

  • They develop because of the absence of Mullerian inhibiting substance.
  • They form most of the female genital tract.
  • The uterine tubes develop from the infused cranial parts of these ducts
  • The caudal fused portions of these ducts form the uterovaginal primordium, which gives rise to the uterus and the superior part of the vagina.

Option D: Mesoderm of Mullerian duct

  • The Mullerian duct differentiates into the female reproductive tract, including the fallopian tube, uterus, cervix and upper vagina.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe sudden chest pain and shortness of breath. His ECG shows an S1Q3T3 pattern, suggestive of thromboembolism. The preferred thrombolytic regimen for the treatment of pulmonary thromboembolism, 100 mg of tPA administered as a continuous peripheral intravenous infusion over 2 hours, is started. Thrombolysis can be done for up to how many days?
questions.solution:
Option C: 14 days

  • For the treatment of pulmonary thromboembolism, the thrombolytic regimen of choice is 100 milligrams of tissue plasminogen activator given as a peripheral continuous intravenous infusion over the course of two hours.
  • Thrombolysis can be performed up to 14 days after the first diagnosis. However, it should be performed as soon as possible.
  • Alteplase, also known as tissue plasminogen activator, is a potent thrombolytic drug that is used to treat acute thromboembolism. Indications for the use of alteplase that have been approved by the FDA include the treatment of pulmonary embolism, myocardial infarction with ST-segment elevation (STEMI), ischemic stroke (when administered within three hours of the onset of symptoms), and the re-establishment of patency in occluded intravenous (IV) catheters.
  • The link between arginine and valine in plasminogen is hydrolyzed by alteplase as it performs its function within the endogenous fibrinolytic cascade to facilitate the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin. After being triggered, plasmin breaks down fibrin and fibrinogen, so facilitating the breakdown of the blood clot and the subsequent restoration of normal blood flow.

Option A: 7 days

  • Thrombolysis, using tPA, can be done for up to 14 days.

Option B: 9 days

  • Thrombolysis, using tPA, can be done for up to 14 days.

Option D: 18 days

  • Thrombolysis, using tPA, can be done for up to 14 days.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presented with recurrent episodes of pain and bloating of the upper abdomen for 1½ years and stools that were difficult to flush for 6 months. The patient had suffered from an attack of acute pancreatitis 5 years before. The abdominal examination revealed mild tenderness in the epigastrium with no rebound tenderness, palpable lump, or swelling. His fasting blood glucose is 180 mg/dL. Serum amylase and lipase levels were high. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas

questions.solution:
Option A: Chronic pancreatitis

  • This patient, with episodes of epigastric pain for the last 1 year and the last 6 months, has steatorrhea, and his fasting blood glucose raised points towards chronic pancreatitis with exocrine and endocrine insufficiency
  • Chronic pancreatitis:
    • The most common cause of chronic pancreatitis: Alcohol
    • The histologic hallmark of chronic pancreatitis - persistent inflammation and irreversible fibrosis associated with atrophy of the pancreatic parenchyma
    • Associated with irreversible exocrine and endocrine insufficiency
    • Primary manifestation - Pain
