    • At least 90% of the gland needs to be dysfunctional for malabsorption symptoms to occur
    • Exocrine insufficiency occurs in 80% to 90% of patients with long-standing chronic pancreatitis
    • Diabetes mellitus - is seen in 40% to 80% of patients
    • Jaundice or cholangitis - due to fibrosis of the common bile duct
    • Diagnosis
      • Findings in C.T. abdomen
        • Dilated pancreatic duct (68%)
        • Parenchymal atrophy (54%)
        • Pancreatic calcification (50%)
      • ERCP - Gold standard for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis. But now, it is used only for therapeutic purposes
      • Shows chain of lakes appearance of the main pancreatic duct with intermittent points of obstruction in a dilated pancreatic duct
      • Rosemont criteria - Criteria to diagnose chronic pancreatitis by endoscopic ultrasound
      • Investigation of choice - MRCP
    • Treatment
      • Lifestyle modification
      • Medical management
        • To palliate symptoms as the disease is irreversible
        • Analgesics ( NSAIDs are the first line of treatment)
        • Enzyme replacement therapy
        • Celiac neurolysis
        • Primary modality for treating symptomatic pancreatic duct obstruction - ERCP- dilation and polyethene stent placement
        • Patient with pain and pancreatic duct dilation secondary to stones - Endoscopic stone extraction
        • Large impacted stones - Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy followed by therapeutic ERCP
        • Surgery Reserved for otherwise unmanageable symptomatic chronic pancreatitis

Option B: Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas

  • Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas does not present with epigastric pain. It will present late in its course when it starts to compress the bile duct and cause progressive, painless jaundice(obstructive jaundice)

Option C: Recurrent acute pancreatitis

  • If this had been recurrent acute pancreatitis, the patient would have had severe pain in the epigastric, unlike in this patient, who only had mild tenderness. So many episodes of recurrent acute pancreatitis would have caused serious complications in this patient, like perforation and pseudocyst by now which are not present currently in this patient with no rebound tenderness

Option D: Myocardial infarction

  • Myocardial infarction can present with epigastric pain in patients, but this patient with endocrine and exocrine insufficiency and pain for the last 1 year with amylase and lipase increase will suggest chronic pancreatitis

questions.text: A patient presented in OPD with the symptoms of ankle and toe swelling, shortness of breath, numbness and tingling of the limb. A spleen biopsy is taken. Pathology of the spleen is given below. Identify which of the following is responsible for the given condition.
questions.solution:
Option C: Focal amyloidosis

  • The given image depicts the Sago spleen.
  • A spleen is affected by amyloid degeneration and in which the amyloid is deposited in the Malpighian corpuscles, which appear in cross-sections as grey translucent bodies resembling grains of sago.
  • Amyloidosis of the spleen is seen in two forms:-
  1. The sago spleen in which amyloid deposits are limited to the follicles
  2. Moreover, the lardaceous spleen in which amyloid is deposited in the walls of the splenic sinusoids and spares the follicles.
  • Amyloidosis may affect the liver and the spleen. Amyloid involvement in the spleen increases the risk of spontaneous rupture of that organ. Some degree of hepatic involvement is common in AL amyloidosis.

Option A: Alcoholic hepatitis

  • Alcoholic hepatitis is inflammation of the liver caused by drinking alcohol.
  • Alcoholic hepatitis is most likely to occur in people who drink heavily over many years.
  • However, the relationship between drinking and alcoholic hepatitis is complex.
  • Symptoms
    • Loss of appetite.
    • Nausea and vomiting.
    • Abdominal tenderness.
    • Fever, often low grade.
  • A doctor may order a liver biopsy to confirm a diagnosis of alcoholic hepatitis. A liver biopsy requires your doctor to remove a tissue sample from the liver.

Option B: Chronic active hepatitis

  • Chronic active hepatitis describes any progressive inflammatory process within the liver.
  • It is a histopathologic diagnosis in which there is evidence of sustained, aggressive, chronic liver disease.
  • This is known as a chronic infection. A vaccine can prevent hepatitis B, but there is no cure if you have the condition.
  • If infected, taking certain precautions can help prevent the spreading virus to others.
  • Symptoms of Chronic Hepatitis
    • An enlarged spleen
    • Small spiderlike blood vessels visible in the skin (called spider angiomas)
    • Redness of the palms
    • Accumulation of fluid within the abdomen (ascites)

Option D: Diffuse amyloidosis

  • Amyloidosis is a condition characterized by infiltration and extracellular deposition of homogeneous, eosinophilic proteinaceous fibrils in a beta-pleated sheet configuration.
  • It classically has an apple-green birefringence when stained with Congo red and viewed under polarized light.
  • Amyloidosis is a disorder caused by misfolding of autologous protein and its extracellular deposition as fibrils, resulting in vital organ dysfunction and, eventually, death.
  • There is no cure for amyloidosis, but treatment and lifestyle modifications can help ease your symptoms and prevent further complications.

questions.text: A 3 yrs old child presented with profound Sensorineural deafness, not responding to hearing aids with intact auditory nerve function. Which of the following procedure is preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
• In a given case, a 3-year-old child with profound SNHL and auditory nerve is intact so it is basically a cochlear hearing loss where the cochlea is not working.
  • COCHLEAR IMPLANT implant an electrode in Scala Tympani (nearest to VIII th nerve).
  • We enter Scala Tympani through cochleostomy near round window or some times through round window.
  • Cochlear implants are auditory implantable prostheses that electrically stimulate the spiral ganglion cells of the cochlear nerve directly in circumstances when the cochlear hair cells themselves do not function effectively to give adequate speech intelligibility. The external components of the cochlear implant i.e. transmitter coil (rounded structure held to the skin with a small magnet), the microphone and the speech processor (worn on the ear).
  • For this patient we can’t apply hearing aids because it is not responding to it.
  • Bone Anchored Hearing Aids use in case of EAC atresia. Titanium screw has osseointegration property.
  • The auditory brainstem implant (ABI) is indicated in severe to profound hearing loss when congenital or acquired abnormalities of the cochlea or auditory nerve (or sometimes both) preclude cochlear implantation (CI). The congenital group (invariably infants and children) includes those with dysplastic or aplastic cochleas and/or auditory nerves while the acquired group predominantly comprises neurofibromatosis type 2 (usually adults) and occasionally acquired cochlear diseases such as otosclerosis or post-meningitic cochlear ossification.
    • Implantation on the brain stem.
    • Cochlear nucleus is in the 4th ventricle.
    • 4th ventricle is entered through the foramen of Lushka.

Learning Objective

  • COCHLEAR IMPLANT PARTS

1. External Body Worn Part

Components

  • Microphone → Receives sound.
  • Speech processor → Converts sound to Electromagnetic waves.
  • Transmitter → Transfers EMW across the layers of skin.

2. Implantable Part

Components

  • Receiver Stimulator
    • Stimulates electrode array
  • Electrode array

3. Contraindications

  • MICHEL’S APLASIA
  • 8TH NERVE APLASIA
  • 8TH NERVE TUMOR

questions.text: At rest, myosin heads are bound with adenosine diphosphate (said to be in a "cocked" position) to the thin filament that does not have Calcium (Ca2+) bound to the troponin-tropomyosin complex. Ca2+ bound to the troponin-tropomyosin complex induces a conformational change in the thin filament, allowing myosin heads to cross-bridge with thin filament actin. Which of the following triggers the detachment of the myosin head from the actin filament?

choices.text: Entry of Ca++ into the sarcoplasmic reticulum
Hydrolysis of ATP to ADP and Pi

questions.solution:
Option C: Binding of ATP to head

  • ATP binding causes myosin to release actin, allowing actin and myosin to detach from each other.
  • Hence, the Myosin head separates from actin when ATP is attached to the myosin head.
  • So, the correct answer is When the Binding of ATP to the head.

Option A: Change in troponin C configuration

  • The binding of Ca2+ and troponin C produces a sequence of conformational changes in the troponin-tropomyosin complex that exposes the specific myosin-binding site on actin.

Option B: Entry of Ca2+ into the sarcoplasmic reticulum

  • The sarcoplasmic reticulum releases calcium ions that various enzymes require during muscle contraction.
  • The myosin heads perform the task of attachment and detachment, extending from the heads on the myosin filaments to the sites on actin filaments.

Option D: Hydrolysis of ATP to ADP and Pi

  • Myosin has another binding site for ATP at which enzymatic activity hydrolyzes ATP to ADP, releasing an inorganic phosphate molecule and energy.
  • ATP binding causes myosin to release actin, allowing actin and myosin to detach from each other.
  • After this happens, the newly bound ATP is converted to ADP and inorganic phosphate, Pi.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents to the dermatology OPD with a complaint of skin lesions affecting his trunk, arms, and legs for the last two weeks. He was diagnosed with HIV infection three years back, and his medication compliance has been poor. On examination, dome-shaped, umbilicated papules with a dimple at the center are found over the trunk and extremities. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Molluscum Contagiosum

  • Molluscum contagiosum is characterized by skin-colored, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication.
  • The lesions are generally not painful but may itch or become irritated.
  • Caused by a DNA poxvirus called the molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV).
  • Typically occurs in immunocompromised individuals such as AIDS patients.
  • The diagnosis is made clinically.
  • On H & E stain:
    • Cup-shaped indentation of the epidermis into the dermis.
    • Within the indentation region, the epidermis appears thickened (acanthosis).
    • Henderson-Paterson bodies are intracytoplasmic, eosinophilic, granular inclusions within the keratinocytes of the basal, spinous, and granular layers of the epidermis.

Option A: Keratoacanthoma

  • It is a low-grade cutaneous tumor most commonly affecting the sun-exposed areas of the body.
  • It presents as a dome-shaped nodule with a central crater.
  • A Central hyperkeratotic crater surrounded by squamous epithelium would be seen in histopathology.

Option B: Hand, foot, and mouth disease

  • It is mediated by a coxsackie A virus infection.
  • It presents with fever, constitutional symptoms, and maculopapular vesicles on the hands and feet.
  • Oral ulcers are also found.

Option C: Herpes zoster

  • It presents as vesicular lesions distributed along a dermatome, mostly in the elderly and immunocompromised patients.
  • It is associated with the reactivation of the dormant varicella-zoster virus.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Malathion is used as ULV during epidemics
Reasoning (R): ULV fogging has residual effect

choices.text: A and R are True statements AND R is the correct explanation of A
A and R are True statements BUT R is not the correct explanation of A
A is True BUT R is False
Both A and R are False

questions.solution:
Option C: A is True BUT R is False

  • Malathion is used as ULV during epidemics and is very effective in the control of Aedes aegypti during epidemics.
  • ULV fogging has no residual effect.

Dosage of Malathion:

  • 98% Malathion in 1 to 2 ounce/ acre.
  • No diluent in ultralow volume (ULV).
  • But ULV fogging has no residual effect.
  • New equipment for ultra-low volume (ULV) space spraying is now using residual insecticides as a space spray.
    • In this equipment fanthion and malathion is being used.
  • Lingering insecticides are active for a long time after being sprayed, they have a residual effect (Residual spray).
    • Malathion, DDT, Lindane, and propoxur are some of the most often used residual insecticides.

Option A/ B/ D: A and R are True statements AND R is the correct explanation of A / A and R are True statements BUT R is not the correct explanation of A / Both A and R are False

  • These all are incorrect choices.

Learning Objective

  • Malathion is used as ULV during epidemics and is very effective in the control of Aedes aegypti during epidemics.
    • ULV fogging has no residual effect.
  • Lingering insecticides are active for a long time after being sprayed, they have a residual effect (Residual spray).
    • Malathion, DDT, Lindane, and propoxur are some of the most often used residual insecticides.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old father of three children has moderate psoriasis. He tells you that his mother had a similar condition 5 years ago, and it was successfully treated with topical agents and methotrexate at a very moderate dose. Today, he comes to the office with increasing symptoms that have started bothering him. There is a lesion on his left hand shown below:



The physician is considering adding a biological agent because he is very uncomfortable with his skin condition. Which of the following is the probable sign shown in the given image?
questions.solution:
Option D: Auspitz sign

  • This patient presented with the aggravating symptoms of psoriasis and is showing a lesion on his hand in the picture, which is more likely an auspitz sign.
  • This sign shows the pinpoint bleeding beneath the skin surface after scratching the psoriatic scales.
  • This sign is never a specific or sensitive marker of psoriasis.
  • It is also seen in other scaly lesions of different diseases like darier disease or actinic keratoses.

Option A: Koebner phenomenon

  • Koebner phenomenon is the formation of a new lesion on the otherwise healthy skin after trauma, unlike this small bleeding.
  • This is also called isomorphic response and is most often seen in psoriasis.

Option B: Nikolsky sign

  • Nikolsky sign is the separation of the uppermost layers of the skin from the lower layers when rubbed. It is seen in pemphigus Vulgaris, steven johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis, and burns. 

Option C: Albright's dimple sign

  • Albright's dimple sign is seen in Albright's hereditary osteodystrophy. 
  • There is the presence of a dimple over the knuckle of the typically affected fourth metacarpal, which the clenching of the fist can enhance. 
  • Seen in young women with short stature and disproportionate shortening of limbs.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the eye outpatient department with a loss of vision in his left eye that began yesterday morning and has been worsening. He describes the feeling as a curtain that was coming over his affected eye and is now affecting his central vision. A week ago, the patient noticed flashing lights on the left side of his vision and floaters. The patient has no diplopia, pain, halos, or other complaints. He reports having cataract surgery in his left eye 2 weeks ago. Fundoscopy is done, and the findings are shown below. What sign is present in the given figure?
questions.solution:
Option A: Tobacco dusting

  • This is a case of retinal detachment. The sign shown is tobacco dusting or Schaffer sign.
  • It results due to the presence of vitreous pigments in the anterior vitreous.
  • Retinal detachment refers to the separation of retinal pigment epithelium from the neurosensory retina.

Clinical presentation:

  • Paroxysmal symptoms: flashes and floaters.
  • Sudden, painless loss of vision
  • The sudden appearance of a veil/curtain over the affected area

Risk factors:

  • Age: 40-60 years
  • Males (3:2 male to female ratio)
  • Myopia
  • Pseudophakia or aphakia
  • Trauma

Evaluation:

  • No finding on external examination.
  • Marcus Gunn pupil is seen in extensive RD.
  • Intraocular pressure may be reduced to an extent.
  • Red reflex: altered on distant direct Fundoscopy, appears greyish.
  • Fundoscopy

Funduscopic findings of retinal detachment:

    • Positive Shafer’s sign (‘Tobacco dust’ / pigment cells in the vitreous).
    • Retinal breaks
    • Retinal thinning is found in old retinal detachment resulting from atrophy.

Complications:

  • Vitreous hemorrhage:  generally small and resolves spontaneously.

Treatment:

  • Photocoagulation, diathermy or cryocoagulation is done to seal breaks.
  • Drainage of SRF is done in some cases.
  • Scleral buckling, pneumatic retinopexy, and other procedures such as pars plana vitrectomy, endolaser photocoagulation and internal tamponade are done to maintain chorioretinal apposition.

Option B: Mutton fat keratic precipitates

  • It is a finding that suggests a chronic granulomatous inflammatory process.
  • It is found in anterior uveitis due to tuberculosis, sarcoidosis and other chronic granulomatous diseases.
  • They are yellow-white, greasy precipitates of inflammatory cells.

Option C: Hyphema

  • Hyphema is the blood present in the anterior chamber.
  • It is commonly post-traumatic.
  • It is visualized on external examination and presents as painful blurring of vision and red eye.

Option D: Koeppe nodules

  • Koeppe nodules are inflammatory cell precipitates which lie at the pupillary margin.
  • They are seen in non-granulomatous as well as granulomatous uveitis.
  • They can easily be visualized using the slit-lamp examination.

questions.text: A histopathology research fellow wants to study the different neurological diseases and their association with the protein defect or deposition. Which of the following neurological disease is associated with defective proteins?

choices.text: Alzheimer's disease is associated with α-synuclein
Parkinson’s disease is associated with androgen receptors
Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD) is associated with Kuru plaques
Spinal bulbar muscular atrophy (SBMA) is associated with Aβ plaques

questions.solution:
Option C: Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD) is associated with Kuru plaques

  • Kuru plaque is a pathognomonic feature in the brain of patients with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.
  • Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is the most common spongiform encephalopathy.
  • It is usually sporadic and rarely can arise due to exposure to prion-infected human tissue (e.g., human growth hormone or corneal transplant).
  • It presents as rapidly progressive dementia associated with ataxia (cerebellar involvement) and startle myoclonus.
  • Periodic sharp waves are seen on electroencephalography (EEG)
  • It results in death, usually in < 1 year.

Option A: Alzheimer's disease is associated with α-synuclein

  • Alzheimer's disease is associated with Aβ plaques.
  • Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia.
  • Morphological features include cerebral atrophy with narrowing of the gyri, widening of sulci, and dilation of the ventricles.
  • Neuritic plaques are extracellular core comprised of Aβ amyloid with entangled neuritic processes.
  • Aβ amyloid is derived from amyloid precursor protein (APP) which normally undergoes alpha cleavage; beta cleavage results in Aβ amyloid.
  • Neurofibrillary tangles are intracellular aggregates of fibres composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein.
  • Loss of cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option B: Parkinson’s disease is associated with androgen receptors

  • Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is associated with α-synuclein
  • Parkinson's disease is characterised by a degenerative loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra of the basal ganglia.
  • In Parkinson's disease, histology reveals loss of pigmented neurons in the substantia nigra and round, eosinophilic inclusions of an α-synuclein protein (Lewy bodies) in affected neurons.
  • Clinical features are tremors, rigidity, akinesia/bradykinesia, and postural instability.
  • Dementia is a common feature of late disease.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Spinal bulbar muscular atrophy (SBMA) is associated with Aβ plaques

  • Spinal bulbar muscular atrophy (SBMA) is associated with androgen receptors.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text:
Consider the following two statements

Assertion (A): Triage is done on the basis of chances of survival

Reason (B): Triage yields the best results when carried out at the site of the disaster

The appropriate answer should be marked using the following key

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true / correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true / correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
Assertion is independently a true / correct statement, but the Reasons is independently a false/incorrect statement
Assertion is independently a false / incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true / correct statement
Both Assertion and Reasons are independently false / incorrect statements

questions.solution:
Option B: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion

Assertion (A): Triage is done on the basis of chances of survival

  • Consists of rapidly classifying the injured on the basis of the severity of their injuries and on the likelihood of their survival with prompt medical intervention.

Reason (B): Triage yields the best results when carried out at the site of disaster

  • Triage yields the best results when carried out at the site of the disaster.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman gives birth to a boy who has decreased movements of the body along with difficulty in breathing. Physical examination reveals the decreased tone of the muscles along with tongue fasciculations. The physician suspects a diagnosis. Which of the following genetic process is affected in this suspected disorder?

choices.text: Addition of 7-methylguanosine cap at the 5’-end of the messenger RNA

questions.solution:
Option A: Splicing of precursor messenger RNA

  • RNA polymerase II synthesizes precursor messenger RNA (pre-mRNA) from the DNA that contains exons as well as introns.
  • In the pre-mRNA, exons contain the genetic material that is required for the synthesis of proteins, while introns play an important role in the expression of the gene but do not contain the genetic material required for protein synthesis.
  • Introns in the pre-mRNA are spliced out inside the nucleus leading to the formation of mature mRNA that is transported to the cytoplasm for translation.
  • Small nuclear ribonucleoproteins (snRNP) play an important role in the splicing of introns. Five snRNPs (U1, U2, U3, U4, and U6) assemble to form a spliceosome that interacts with pre-mRNA to excise the intron, as demonstrated in the figure below:

  • In spinal muscular atrophy, splicing of precursor messenger RNA is affected due to defective small nuclear ribonucleoproteins (snRNP), leading to the degeneration of the anterior horns of the spinal cord. It results in symmetric weakness of muscles.

Option B: Translation of messenger RNA

  • Pre-mRNA is converted to mature mRNA by splicing, which is then transported to the cytoplasm to be translated into the protein.

Option C: Addition of 7-methylguanosine cap at the 5’-end of the messenger RNA

  • In eukaryotic cells, ribosomes recognize most eukaryotic mRNAs by binding to the 7-methylguanosine cap at their 5' terminus and start the process of translation.

Option D: Addition of poly-A tail

  • A poly-A tail is added to the 3’-end of the mRNA. It plays a role in transporting mRNA out of the nucleus and protecting mRNA from enzymatic degradation in the cytoplasm.

questions.text: A 26-year-old young female patient presented with symptoms related to anaemia. Peripheral blood smear showed hypersegmented neutrophils, and bone marrow aspirate smear showed giant myelocytes. Which of the following is the likely aetiology?
questions.solution:
Option D:  Folic acid deficiency

  • Both the findings mentioned above are features of megaloblastic anaemia.
  • Folic acid deficiency is one of the causes of megaloblastic anaemia.
  • Certain peripheral blood findings are common to all forms of megaloblastic anaemia:
    • Macrocytic red cells, which may lack central pallor
    • Macro-ovalocytes
    • Low reticulocyte count
    • Neutrophils are also larger than normal and show nuclear hypersegmentation, having 5 or more nuclear lobules instead of the normal 3-4
  • The marrow is hypercellular, with megaloblastic changes detected at all stages of erythroid development.
  • As DNA synthesis is impaired in all proliferating cells, granulocytic precursors also display dysmaturation in giant metamyelocytes and band forms.

Option A:  Sideroblastic anaemia

  • Sideroblastic anaemia is a kind of anaemia caused by improper iron use during erythropoiesis.
  • There are several types of sideroblastic anaemia, all of which are distinguished by the presence of ring sideroblasts in the bone marrow.
  • Ring sideroblasts are erythroid precursors with non-heme iron deposits in mitochondria that form a ring-like distribution around the nucleus.
  • The iron-formed ring covers at least one-third of the nucleus rim.
  • Sideroblastic anaemia can induce both microcytic and macrocytic anaemia, depending on the type of mutation that causes it. Patients with sideroblastic anaemia have normal to high iron levels, unlike iron deficiency anaemia, which has depleted iron reserves.

Option B:  Iron deficiency anaemia

  • Anaemia is haemoglobin levels less than two standard deviations below the mean for the patient's age and gender.
  • Iron is required for the formation of the haemoglobin molecule.
  • Iron deficiency is the most common cause of anaemia worldwide, resulting in microcytic and hypochromic red cells on the peripheral smear.

Option C:  Thalassemia

  • Thalassemias are a diverse set of hereditary illnesses caused by reduced production of haemoglobin's alpha or beta chains (Hb).
  • If the body does not produce enough of one or both of these proteins, red blood cells may not form correctly and cannot carry enough oxygen, resulting in anaemia that begins in childhood and lasts throughout life.
  • Thalassemia is a hereditary condition, which means that at least one of the parents must be a carrier. It is caused by a genetic mutation or the deletion of key gene fragments.

questions.text: A three-year-old child is brought to your clinic by his mother with complaints of fever, blood in her urine and abdominal pain. Physical examination reveals a palpable mass in the child's abdomen. Further investigations are performed, and a diagnosis of Wilms tumour is made. Which of the following is not a marker of Wilms tumour?
questions.solution:
Option C: TTF 1

  • Wilms tumour is the most common renal cancer in children.
  • It usually occurs in children aged 2-5.
  • It is also called nephroblastoma.
  • Symptoms of Wilms tumour include:
    • Painless, palpable abdominal mass
    • Abdominal pain
    • Fever
    • Nausea and vomiting
    • Hematuria
  • Wilms tumour is associated with multiple syndromes:
    • WAGR syndrome
    • Denys-Drash syndrome
    • Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome
  • Wilms tumour is associated with various markers:
    • Desmin
    • Vimentin
    • Cytokeratin
  • TTF-1 (thyroid transcription factor) is a marker for:
    • Lung cancer
    • Thyroid cancer
    • Adenocarcinoma
    • Small cell carcinoma of the lung

 

 

Option A: Desmin

  • Desmin is a marker for Wilms tumour.
  • It is a marker for muscle cell tumours.

 

Option B: Vimentin

  • Vimentin is a marker for Wilms tumour.
  • It is a marker for mesenchymal cell tumours.

 

Option D: Cytokeratin

  • Cytokeratin is a marker for Wilms tumour.
  • It is a marker for epithelial cell tumours.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used to treat pseudomembranous enterocolitis and is also a component of anti-H. Pylori triple-drug regimen?
questions.solution:
Option C: Metronidazole

  • Metronidazole exerts activity against most anaerobic bacteria and several protozoa.
  • Metronidazole can function as an electron sink, and because it does so, its 5-nitro group is reduced
  • Reduced metronidazole disrupts replication and transcription and inhibits DNA repair.
  • Clinical uses:
    • Metronidazole inhibits E. histolytica, G. lamblia, T. vaginalis, Blastocystis hominis, B. coli, and the helminth Dracunculus medinensis.
    • It is also bactericidal for obligate anaerobic gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria except for Actinomyces species.
    • It is not active against aerobes or facultative anaerobes.
    • It is a part of the regimen for treating both pseudomembrane colitis and eradicating H.pylori infection
  • Adverse effects:
    • Nausea, vomiting, cramps, diarrhoea, and a metallic taste.
    • The urine is often dark or red-brown.
    • Since metronidazole is a weak inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase, alcohol ingestion should be avoided during treatment.
    • Metronidazole interferes with the metabolism of warfarin and may potentiate its anticoagulant activity.
    • Phenobarbital and corticosteroids lower metronidazole plasma levels by increasing their metabolism, whereas cimetidine raises levels by impairing metronidazole metabolism.

Option A: Amoxicillin

  • Amoxicillin is used for H. pylori infection
  • However, it is avoided in pseudomembranous colitis because it is the culprit drug causing this disease.

Option B: Vancomycin

  • Vancomycin is used against pseudomembranous colitis.

Option D: Clotrimazole

  • Clotrimazole is an antifungal drug mostly used for skin infections caused by fungi.
  • It is given neither H. pylori eradication nor pseudomembranous colitis

questions.text: A 24-year-old south Indian patient with a history of taking baths in ponds presented with local pruritus, coryza with sneezing, rhinorrhea, and postnasal discharge (drip) with cough. The patient is admitted, and a unilateral nasal polypis appreciated on local examination. The biopsy of the nasal polypis carried out and reveals spherules with endospores. Which of the following is true about the diagnosis of the given patient?

choices.text: Can be cultured on Sabouraud’s dextrose Agar

questions.solution:
Option B: Fungal spherules in biopsy

  • Based on signs, symptoms, examination and biopsy patient is suffering from rhinosporidiosis.

  • It is also classified as an aquatic protozoan.

  • Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic inflammatory disease most prevalent in India and Sri Lanka.

  • Its manifestations are mostly nasal, though extra nasal ones in the head and neck region are not usual.

  • Lesion bleeds on touch.

  • Polyp biopsy → shows spherule with endospores.

  • Rhinosporidium seeberi causes it.

  • Rhinosporidiosis is characterised by reddish polypoidal masses which are hyperplastic and friable, and sometimes it may be sessile.

  • It presents with Bilateral Nasal polyps (the most common presentation).

 

 

 

Type of presentation

Number

1. Only nasal presentation

26

2. Laryngopharyngeal presentation

2

3. Lacrimal sac presentation

1

4. Oropharyngeal presentation

6

 

  • Treatment: Polypectomy/Diathermy excision

 

Option A: Can be cultured on Sbouraud’s dextrose Agar

  • Rhinosporidiosis cannot be cultured on savoured dextrose agar.

  • Rhinosporidiosis is characterised by reddish polypoidal masses which are hyperplastic and friable, and sometimes it may be sessile.

  • Polypbiopsy → shows spherule with endospores.

 

Option C: Does not bleed to touch

  • Rhinosporidiosis is characterised by a reddish polypoidal mass, which is hyperplastic and friable and sometimes it may be sessile.

  • Lesion bleeds on touch.

 

Option D: Treatment is antibiotics

  • Their common presentation is nasal polyps.

  • Treatment: Polypectomy/Diathermy excision.

questions.text: A 29-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with rectal bleeding, vague abdominal discomfort, nocturnal loose stools, stunted growth, fatigue, weakness, shortness of breath, and dizziness for 15 days. On general physical examination, there was pale and yellowish skin, cold hands and feet, and tachycardia. Sigmoidoscopy was performed, which showed "coconut cake rectum". On stool examination, the egg shown in the image below was seen. Identify the causative organism.
questions.solution:
Option B: Trichuris trichiura

 

 

Trichuriasis

The causative organism is Trichuris trichiura, also known as the “Human whipworm”. 

  • Habitat is the large intestine, caecum, and appendix.

  • The definitive and the only host in its life cycle is the man.

  • It has a thin thread-like anterior end, and the posterior end is broadened.

  • Resembles a whip.

  • The thread-like anterior end is anchored in the mucosa of the large intestines.

 

 

Egg:

  • Barrel-shaped, bile stained, Mucus plugs at each pole and unsegmented ovum.

Diagnosis 

  • Stool examination:  a typical barrel-shaped eggs. Occasionally an adult worm may appear in the stool. 

  • Sigmoidoscopy: In serious infection, sigmoidoscopy may show the white bodies of the worm hanging from the inflamed mucosa- the so-called “Coconut cake rectum”.

Causes

  • Symptoms of anaemia (fatigue, weakness, shortness of breath, and dizziness sometimes).

  • Vague abdominal discomfort

  • Nocturnal loose stools

  • Dysentery can occur in patients with greater than 200 worms.

  • Rectal prolapse

  • Failure to thrive

Complications

  • Iron deficiency anaemia

  • Rectal prolapse in children 

  • Growth retardation

Option A: Ascaris

  • Ascaris lumbricoides causes ascariasis.

  • Most infections are asymptomatic. Ascaris pneumonia with fever, cough, and eosinophilia can occur with a heavy larval burden. Abdominal pain and even obstruction can result from the presence of adult worms in the intestine.

  • Diagnosis is usually made microscopically by detecting eggs (eggs with rugosity) in the stools. The egg is oval with an irregular surface. Occasionally, the patient sees adult worms in the stools.

  • Albendazole, mebendazole, and ivermectin are effective.

Option C:  Hymenolepis nana

  • Hymenolepis nana is also called the dwarf tapeworm because of its small size. It is also different from other tapeworms because the eggs are directly infectious to humans without the need for an intermediate animal host. 

  • Diagnosis is made by finding eggs in faeces (eggs have spicules with polar filaments).

  • Treat with Praziquantel.

Option D: Ancylostoma Duodenale

  • Humans are infected when filariform larvae in moist soil penetrate the skin, usually of the feet or legs.

  • They are carried by the blood to the alveoli and up the bronchi and trachea and then are swallowed. They develop into adults in the small intestine, attaching to the wall with either cutting plates (Necator) or teeth (Ancylostoma).

  • The major damage is due to the loss of blood at the site of attachment in the small intestine. 

  • Diagnosis is made microscopically by observing the eggs in the stools (eggs with a thin transparent shell having 4-8 blastomeres, non-bile stained). Eosinophilia is typical.

  • The drug of choice is either albendazole or mebendazole

questions.text: Ideal contraceptive, correctly matched is:

choices.text: 35y old smoker educated woman (Temporary spacing): Combined OCPs

questions.solution:
Option B: Teenage girl: Male condoms

  • Male condoms must be used by teenage girls who have been incised to use partners because they are simple to use, prevent pregnancy, STDs, and HIV have a low failure rate.

Option A: Newly married couple: Copper T

  • Mostly it depends on the preferences of the partner. Typically, newlyweds choose for OCP over copper T.

Option C: 35y old smoker educated woman (Temporary spacing): Combined OCPs

  • 35years well educated women can use diaphragm. because that beneficial to this women.

Learning Objective

  • Condoms are a barrier method of contraception.
  • Enzyme inducer like phenytoin will not alter its mechanism.
  • Condoms provide production against sexually transmitted disease.

questions.text: A 43-year-old female underwent elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The gallbladder is sent for histopathological diagnosis. Given below is a specimen of the gallbladder. What is your likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Polyps in the gallbladder

  • The image given above is suggestive of a polypoid lesion of the gallbladder
  • Gallbladder polyps may be found in approximately 5% of patients who undergo ultrasonography and consists of pseudo tumours and adenomas.
  • Pseudotumors are further divided into adenomyomatosis and cholesterol polyps and have no malignant potential. 
  • True adenomatous polyps occur in 0.3-0.5% of the population. The risk of malignant transformation increases with the increasing size of the polyp.
  • Cholesterol polyps appear as pedunculated echogenic lesions of the gallbladder, are usually smaller than 1 cm, and are frequently multiple.
  • Adenomyomatosis is a sessile lesion commonly in the fundus with characteristic microcysts within the lesion and is frequently larger than 1 cm.
  • Adenomas are benign growths in the wall of the gallbladder that may be difficult to differentiate from adenocarcinoma preoperatively because the only difference is that of transmural invasion, which can be challenging to detect by ultrasonography.

Option A: Diverticulosis of gallbladder

  • Gallbladder diverticulum is an unusual congenital disease that has the appearance of a hernia-like protrusion of the normal gallbladder wall.
  • This order may not be diagnosed until surgically resected because it has no clinical significance unless there are associated diseases.

Option B: Porcelain gallbladder

  • It is characterized by dense circumferential calcification of the gallbladder wall.
  • 90% are associated with gallstones
  • It is a rare premalignant condition that is associated with an approximately 10% risk of gallbladder carcinoma.
  • Diagnosed incidentally on X-Ray or CT but is more commonly seen on CT. In ultrasound, it will appear as a curvilinear echogenic focus along the entire gallbladder wall with posterior shadowing.
  • Cholecystectomy is the treatment of choice in patients with porcelain gallbladder, even if asymptomatic (due to the high incidence of development of carcinoma gallbladder)

Option C: Strawberry gallbladder

  • Deposition of cholesterol ester and triglycerides in macrophages in the gall bladder lamina propria, either locally or as polyps. It gives the classic studded macroscopic appearance of a strawberry gallbladder.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presented with complaints of dysphagia, regurgitation, and chest pain. She also described recurring bouts of pneumonia and heartburn. Manometry revealed an abnormality in the peristaltic movement of the esophagus and LES relaxation. Which of the following statements delineates the motility disorders of the esophagus?

choices.text: Best understood motility disorder of the Esophagus is Achalasia
Most common hypermotility disorder of the Esophagus is diffuse esophageal spasm
Components of Triple A-syndrome or Allgrove disease are Achalasia, alopecia and ACTH- Adrenal resistant insufficiency
For hypertensive LES, esophagectomy is the operation of choice

questions.solution:
Option A: Best understood motility disorder of the Esophagus is Achalasia

  • ​​​​​​​Most common  motility disorder of esophagus is Achalasia cardia
  • Achalasia is a primary esophageal motility disorder characterized by the absence of esophageal peristalsis and impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) in response to swallowing.
  • The LES is hypertensive in about 50% of patients. These abnormalities cause a functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction (GEJ).

Option B: Most common hypermotility disorder of the Esophagus is diffuse esophageal spasm

  • The most common hypermotility disorder of the Esophagus is the Nutcracker esophagus.
  • The nutcracker esophagus is an abnormality in which swallowing contractions are too powerful. In up to half of patients, this condition is caused by gastroesophageal reflux.
  • The exact cause of the nutcracker esophagus is unknown. However, it seems to be related to an issue with the muscle function and thickness of the Esophagus. For some people, the spasms only happen when they eat cold or hot foods.

Option C: Components of Triple A-syndrome or Allgrove disease are Achalasia, alopecia, and ACTH- Adrenal resistant insufficiency

  • Allgrove syndrome or 3A syndrome is characterized by a triad of adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH) resistant adrenal insufficiency, alacrima, and Achalasia, along with progressive neurological impairment with or without mild mental retardation.

Option D: For hypertensive LES, esophagectomy is the operation of choice

  • For hypertensive LES, laparoscopic Heller's cardiomyotomy is the operation of choice.
  • Laparoscopic Heller myotomy is a minimally invasive procedure that opens the tight lower esophageal sphincter (the valve between the Esophagus and the stomach) by performing a myotomy to relieve the dysphagia.

questions.text: Which of the following is the investigation of choice for intermittent low-grade intestinal obstruction?
questions.solution:
Option C: Enteroclysis

  • Enteroclysis is the investigation of choice for diagnosis of low-grade intermittent small bowel obstruction.
  • IOC for diagnosis of Small bowel obstruction is Abdominal X-ray.
  • Enteroclysis:
    • Enteroclysis is a gastrointestinal technique designed to improve the small bowel's evaluation.
    • The conventional fluoroscopic technique is not widely used since it is somewhat invasive, time and labour-intensive, and not particularly pleasant for the patient.
    • The exam also requires a degree of skill to perform, and often the information can be gathered through other techniques.
    • In experienced hands, however, it is the best radiographic technique for evaluating the small bowel mucosa.

Option A: X-ray

  • Erect abdominal films are no longer routinely obtained, and the radiological diagnosis is based on a passive abdominal film
  • An erect film may subsequently be requested when further doubt exists.

Option B: USG

  • USG is used to diagnose intestinal hepatobiliary pathologies.
  • For intermittent intestinal obstruction, enteroclysis is preferred.

Option D: Barium meal follow-through

  • Barium small-bowel follow-through are used to diagnose small intestine disorders, such as ulcers, tumours, and inflammatory bowel disease.

questions.text: A 55-year female presents to the urology outpatient department with complaints of frequency, urgency, dysuria, gross hematuria with the passage of clots, and right flank pain for one month. The patient also had a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. She is a known diabetic and has been on oral hypoglycemics for the last 16 years. A cystoscopy of the patient showed multiple nodular brush-like lesions with easy bleeding in the bladder, especially around the right vesicoureteric junction. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder

questions.solution:
Option D: Malakoplakia

  • This is a case of malakoplakia in which the patient presents with complaints of frequency, urgency, dysuria, gross hematuria and right flank pain for one month. The patient is a known diabetic. The cystoscopy showed multiple nodular brush-like lesions with easy bleeding in the bladder.
  • The histopathological examination revealed the presence of abundant histiocytes with slightly eosinophilic granular cytoplasm with many intracellular and extracellular basophilic inclusions, which are a feature of Michaelis- Gutmann bodies. The inclusions stained positive with the periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) reagent and alcian blue.
  • All these findings are suggestive of malakoplakia.
  • Malakoplakia is an infection of the bladder.
  • It manifests as plaques or nodules made of large histiocytes (Von Hansemann cells) with laminar inclusion bodies (Michaelis-Gutmann bodies) from around bacterial fragments (E. coli), which act as a nidus.
  • It is believed to result from the inadequate killing of bacteria macrophages or monocytes that exhibits defective phagolysosomal activity.
  • Risk factors:
  • Immunosuppression (Steroids, transplantation).
  • Diabetes, lymphoma and rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Treatment:
  • The preferred antibiotic is trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and fluoroquinolones.

Option A: Urothelial carcinoma

  • Urothelial carcinoma is a malignant tumour of the urinary tract originating from the mucosa of the urinary tract.
  • It is the most common type of bladder cancer.
  • It is usually asymptomatic or is associated with painless hematuria.

Option B: Polypoid cystitis

  • Polypoid cystitis is a reversible inflammatory exophytic lesion of the mucosa of the bladder.
  • Histologically, it shows mildly hyperplastic urothelium.

Option C: Squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder

  • Squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder can occur in multiple areas of the bladder, but the lateral wall and trigone are the most common sites.
  • On cystoscopy, it appears as nodular and has a plaque-like, irregular surface.

questions.text: A 38-year old male underwent a laparoscopic right-sided hemicolectomy because of colon carcinoma. The surgery went successful. After one day of persistent painful penile erection, the patient notified the treating physician. On close inspection, painful engorgement of the penis in the absence of sexual arousal was observed. Which of the following statement is correct about this condition?

choices.text: Low flow priapism occurs secondary to perineal trauma
Low flow priapism can lead to compartment syndrome

questions.solution:
Option B: Low flow priapism can lead to compartment syndrome

  • The sign like persistent painful penile erections mentioned in the question point towards the diagnosis of priapism.
  • Priapism:
    • Priapism is the persistent and painful penile erection in the absence of sexual excitement or desire, and it may persist after sexual excitement.
    • The minimum duration of a painful erection is 4 hours.
    • It is a medical emergency, and delay in treatment leads to Cavernosal fibrosis and impotence.
    • It should be treated within 6 hours to prevent other complications.
    • Priapism is of 2 types: High flow and Low flow

 

High flow

 

 Low flow (MC)

 
  • Non- Ischemic

 

Causes

  • Penile Trauma
  • Perineal trauma
  • Due to the formation of arterial sinusoidal shunts.
  • Ischemic

 

Causes

  • Sickle cell anemia
  • Leukemia
  • Fat emboli
  • Spinal cord lesion
  • Malignant Penile inflammation
  • Trazodone Injection
  • Clinical presentation
    • In children(5-10years) with sickle cell disease- painful erection during nights
    • In adults-iatrogenic
  • Diagnosis
    • Mainly clinical, but doppler is helpful in the diagnosis
  • Treatment
    • If the patient comes within 4-6 hours, a ketamine injection is given (> 50% of cases improve).
    • If the condition does not improve after that, aspiration and saline irrigation is done.
    • When the condition is not improved even after saline irrigation, hyaluronidase injection is injected.
    • For high-flow priapism, selective internal pudendal angiography is followed by embolization of the feeding vessel.

Option A: Low flow priapism occurs secondary to perineal trauma

  • Low flow priapism does not occur secondary to perineal trauma.
  • High-flow Priapism occurs secondary to perineal or penile trauma.

Option C: Diagnosed mainly by panoramic radiography

  • It is diagnosed mainly by color Doppler.
  • Panoramic radiography is done for dental procedures.

Option D: Whipple procedure is done

  • Whipple procedure is not done in priapism.
  • Whipple procedure is a complex surgery done to remove the head of the pancreas.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male presents to the emergency department with complaints of fever, malaise, severe pain, swelling in the genital region, and smell of the affected region. The physical examination shows the blackish discoloration of the scrotal skin, which is described in the image below. There is a gas that can be seen on scrotal ultrasound. Which of the following should be excised during surgery?

choices.text: Skin, subcutaneous tissue and corpora cavernosa
Skin, subcutaneous tissue, corpora cavernosa & testis

questions.solution:
Option B: Skin & subcutaneous tissue

  • The Image shows blackish discolouration of scrotal skin and some part of penile skin: Fournier's gangrene.
  • Aka idiopathic scrotal gangrene.

Fournier's gangrene

  • Fournier's gangrene is a necrotising fasciitis of the male genitalia and perineum (secondary to infection by aerobic and anaerobic bacteria), affecting predominantly middle-aged and older men with pre-existing co-morbidities. It involves the skin and subcutaneous tissues. It is rare for the infection to involve the testicles or deep tissues of the penis because of the tunica vaginalis and  Buck fascia, respectively, so these structures can be preserved. Corpora cavernosa lies under the Buck’s fascia.
  • It is a urological emergency that often presents with swelling, pain and erythema of the genital region, which may progress to discolouration and frank necrosis accompanied by systemic features such as fever and rigour.
  • The presence of crepitus is virtually diagnostic.
  • It is usually a polymicrobial infection with microaerobes, anaerobes and gram-positive and gram-negative organisms. It spreads along Dartos, Scarpas and Colles' fascia.
  • Risk factors for development include peripheral vascular disease, diabetes mellitus, malnutrition, alcoholism and other immunocompromised states.
  • Given the potential for rapid spread and tissue destruction, early diagnosis and urgent surgical drainage with aggressive debridement of the necrotic tissue is an essential component of management, along with the broad-spectrum antibiotic cover.
  • It is rare for the infection to involve the testicles or deep tissues of the penis because of the tunica vaginalis and Buck fascia, respectively, so these structures should be preserved.
  • It is uncommon for the urethra to be involved, although a defined urinary tract source may be evident such as urethral stricture with perforation and local infection.
  • Mortality is high and related to the level of existing co-morbidity.

Option A: Skin

  • There is necrosis of skin and subcutaneous tissue.
  • Only the excision of skin is not useful for the management, so the subcutaneous tissue should also be excised.

Option C: Skin, subcutaneous tissue and corpora cavernosa

  • Fournier's gangrene involves the skin and subcutaneous tissues.
  • It is rare to involve corpora cavernosa so there is no need to excise corpora cavernosa.

Option D: Skin, subcutaneous tissue, corpora cavernosa & testis

  • It is rare for the infection to involve the testicles or deep tissues of the penis because of the tunica vaginalis and  Buck fascia.
  • So these structures can be preserved.
  • Corpora cavernosa lies under the Buck’s fascia.

questions.text: A 37-year-old primigravida woman presents to the obstetric clinic for the initial screening in her first trimester. She has a history of hypertension and is adherent to her medications. The physician advised her triple screening for aneuploidies because of her advanced maternal age. Which of the following is not a component of the triple marker screening?
questions.solution:
Option D: Acetylcholinesterase

  • Acetylcholinesterase is not a component of triple screening in pregnancy.
  • Neural tube defects (NTDs) occur in the fetus in the first trimester due to failure of primary neuralation.
  • The most sensitive marker of NTDs is amniotic fluid alpha-fetoprotein. The amniotic fluid acetylcholinesterase can help confirm the diagnosis of NTDs.
  • While doing an amniocentesis, if the amnionic fluid AFP level is elevated, an assay for acetylcholinesterase is done.
  • The presence of elevated levels of acetylcholinesterase enzyme in the amniotic fluid is diagnostic of a neural tube defect.
  • A triple screening test consists of:
    • Maternal serum beta-hCG
    • Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
    • Maternal serum unconjugated estriol (uE3)

Option A: Serum beta hCG

  • Serum beta-hCG is a component of triple screening in pregnancy.

Option B: Serum unconjugated estriol (uE3)

  • Serum unconjugated estriol is a component of triple screening in pregnancy.

Option C: Serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)

  • Serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is a component of triple screening in pregnancy.

questions.text: A neonate is brought to a nearby hospital by her parents due to severe difficulty in breathing and a sunken abdomen. On examination, breath sounds are decreased on the left side. The baby is intubated and the cardiac impulse shifted to the right immediately after placing the endotracheal tube. An X-ray image is given below. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Confirms the position of the endotracheal tube by repeating X-ray chest
Remove the tube and reattempt intubation

questions.solution:
Option B: Remove the tube and reattempt intubation

  • From the clinical scenario above, there is a suspicion that oesophagal intubation is maximum as cardiac impulse shifted right after intubation.
  • Oesophageal intubation is the incorrect placement of an endotracheal tube in the oesophagus.
  • Its consequences can be damaging within seconds to minutes, with the seriousness of its outcome depending mainly on the timely diagnosis.
  • So the next step in management is: Remove the endotracheal tube and reattempt intubation.
  • Additional clues of oesophagal intubation:
    • Absent bilateral chest expansion
    • Poor compliance with ventilation
    • Sound of gas regurgitated from the oesophagus
    • Abdominal distension
    • Absent normal breath sounds over lung fields

Option A: Confirms the position of the endotracheal tube by repeating X-ray chest

  • Although it’s part of the reassessment.
  • But a very immediate and essential step in management after cardiac shift removal is particular as it is in the oesophagus.

Option C: Nasogastric tube insertion

  • Here is no other step other than its removal and reattempt.
  • Nasogastric insertion is possible, but it must first be removed and reattempted.

Option D: Chest X-ray

  • A chest x-ray is not the cure but the diagnostic technique.
  • It will not be helpful to reassure the patient’s condition.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents to the OPD with complaints of dyspnea on exertion and abdominal discomfort. She also mentions a history of undergoing multiple radiation therapy for breast malignancy about 12yrs ago. PET scan and all the other tests for metastasis are negative. On examination, JVP rises with inspiration, and along with that, increased liver span and pedal oedema are noted. Low voltage ECG is seen along with Square root wave sign in doppler ECHO. Based on details, the diagnosis of RCM is made. Which of the following is incorrect about the disease?
questions.solution:
Option D: Increased LV diastolic dimension

  • Increased LV diastolic dimension is the presentation of DCM, not RCM.
  • A disease of the myocardium known as restrictive cardiomyopathy is defined by restrictive filling and reduced diastolic volume of either or both ventricles, with normal or near-normal systolic function. This condition can affect one or both of the heart's ventricles.
  • It is distinguished by diastolic failure in conjunction with restrictive ventricular physiology, but systolic function frequently continues to be normal in patients with this condition.
  • Even though the ventricular filling is hindered during diastole, which results in atrial enlargement, the volume of the ventricles and the wall thickness of the ventricles are often normal.

Findings on the CVS examination:

  • The S1 and S2 heart sounds are normal, and the S2 split is also normal.
  • Loud and early S3.
  • There is almost never any evidence of a fourth heart sound known as S4.
  • Regurgitation of the mitral and tricuspid valves is the cause of murmurs.
  • Decreased LV diastolic dimension is seen in RCM.

Option A: Increased atrial size

  • In RCM, ventricle walls are stiff and filling pressure in ventricles is elevated, leading to an increase in atrial size.

Option B: Normal LV wall thickness

  • In RCM, left ventricular wall thickness would either be decreased or normal but can never increase.
  • Increased wall thickness is present in HOCM

Option C: Reduced ejection fraction

  • Due to fibrosis, ejection fraction will reduce.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male comes to the clinic with complaints of swelling of the face and both ankles. He also mentions having weakness and fatigue. His examination reveals bilateral pitting pedal oedema and mild basilar crepitations. His pulse is 78 beats/min, and his blood pressure is 116/80 mmHg. 24-hr urine collection is done, which shows a protein content of 5g/day. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Renal Amyloidosis

  • This patient with fluid lost in the third space (Pedal and Pulmonary Oedema[basilar crepitations]) and nephrotic range proteinuria ( >3.5g/day) is most likely suffering from nephrotic syndrome.
  • Renal amyloidosis is caused by the deposition of amyloid protein in glomeruli leading to mesangial expansion. This mesangial expansion causes the loss of proteins through the glomerular membrane leading to massive proteinuria.
  • The patient presents with weakness, fatigue, swelling and shortness of breath (pulmonary oedema). Blood pressure in early disease is normal, as in this patient.
  • Treatment involves tackling each symptom individually; protein restriction and ACEIs for proteinuria, fluid restriction and diuretics for oedema, anticoagulation for the hypercoagulable state, etc.

Option A: Renal Polyarteritis Nodosa

  • Polyarteritis nodosa is a systemic vasculitis causing ischemia in different parts of the vessels. This leads to part of the vessels undergoing fibrosis, causing the formation of aneurysms. (Beads on a String Appearance)
  • These aneurysms decrease the blood supply to organs by disrupting blood flow.
  • When blood flow to the kidney is disrupted, the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) is activated, causing high renin hypertension.
  • Our patient has normal blood pressure making this diagnosis less likely.

Option B: Renal Artery Stenosis

  • Renal artery stenosis has multiple causes; the most common is atherosclerosis in older individuals and fibromuscular dysplasia in young females.
  • It causes the narrowing of the arteries, decreasing the blood supply to the kidneys, which decreases GFR.
  • Decreased GFR activates RAAS causing high renin hypertension.
  • Our patient has normal blood pressure making this diagnosis less likely.

Option D: Hypertensive Arteriolar Nephrosclerosis

  • Hypertensive arteriolar nephrosclerosis is a progressive disease caused by chronic hypertension. Over time, due to continuous pressure and injury to the small vessels in the kidneys, the vessels thicken, causing the narrowing of afferent arterioles.
  • This decreases blood flow to the kidneys, causing glomerular ischemia. This eventually progresses to end-stage renal disease.
  • Our patient has normal blood pressure and no features suggesting overt kidney shutdown, making this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: Investigation of choice in COPD?
questions.solution:
Option B: Spirometry

  • The main test for COPD is spirometry.
  • Spirometry can detect COPD before symptoms are recognized.
  • Spirometry is a type of lung function test that measures how much air you breathe out.

Other options

Option A: Chest X ray

  • This option is incorrect.

Option C: CT Chest

  • This option is incorrect.

Option D: MRI

  • This option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male has had hard-to-control hypertension for 2 years. His blood pressure is 170/105 mmHg, pulse 90 beats/min, and respirations 16 breaths/min. The cardiopulmonary exam is normal. Pedal pulses are intact and there is no oedema or misdistribution of fat. Laboratory evaluation shows potassium of 2.7 mEq/L, BUN 20 mg/dL, creatinine 1.2 mg/dL, bicarbonate 33 mg/dL, and fasting glucose 98 mg/dL. He is already taking clonidine, hydrochlorothiazide, verapamil, and lisinopril, but his blood pressure has not been controlled. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Conn Syndrome

  • Presentation: K+↓↓
  • RFT= Normal
  • HCO3(22-26) here ↑↑ , so alkalosis is present.
  • This patient is suffering from high blood pressure that has remained uncontrolled despite extensive intake of anti-hypertensive drugs.
  • Furthermore, decreased levels of potassium and high sodium levels further indicate that a cause of these symptoms is excessive production of aldosterone.
  • Hyperaldosteronism causes the absorption of sodium and excretion of potassium and H+, ultimately leading to all the symptoms.
  • Therefore, Hypokalemic alkalosis with HTN is present in Conn syndrome (hyperaldosteronism)

Option B: Renal Vascular Hypertension

  • In renal vasculature hypertension, there are ↓RFTs. The BUN and Creatinine are deranged and increased. While they are normal in this patient.

Option C: Cushing Syndrome

  • Cushing Syndrome presents with weight gain in patients with hypertension, as cortisol can also stimulate aldosterone receptors. Other symptoms of Cushing syndrome, including weight gain, abdominal striae, insulin resistance, and hyperglycemia, should also be present.

Option D: Carcinoid Syndrome

  • Carcinoid syndrome doesn’t lead to hypertension. The metabolites produced may cause bronchospasm and Histamine/Serotonin release, which will cause vasodilation leading to hypotension.

questions.text: A young female is admitted to your hospital for acute liver failure. She was diagnosed with viral hepatitis, and her symptoms have worsened. She now shows significant confusion and gross disorientation. She is drowsy but responds to voice and pain stimuli. If this is a case of metabolic encephalopathy, which one of the following manifestations would be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Anomic aphasia

  • Acute liver failure is the sudden loss of liver functionality, causing the accumulation of toxins in the body.
  • Metabolic encephalopathy is a neurological disorder caused by systemic illness, diabetes, liver disease, renal failure and heart failure.
  • Hepatic encephalopathy is a type of metabolic encephalopathy.
  • Damage by ammonia or urea intoxication contributes to anomic aphasia, which is difficulty in naming objects.

Option A: Motor aphasia

  • Motor aphasia is caused by damage to Broca’s area.

Option B: Sensory aphasia

  • Sensory aphasia is caused by damage to Wernicke’s area.

Option C: Conduction aphasia

  • Conduction aphasia is caused by damage to the arcus fasciculus.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with a severe backache for 10 days. She has tried over-the-counter NSAIDs, but her condition did not improve. She also complains of urinary incontinence and dribbling for the last week. There is no associated fever or weight loss. She has a history of intervertebral disc prolapse, which is being managed conservatively. Examination reveals decreased sensation and muscle strength in the left lower limb. The anal and genital area has a loss of sensations as well. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Cauda equina syndrome

  • This patient’s signs and symptoms are suggestive of cauda equina syndrome.
  • Cauda equina syndrome presents with lower back pain, paresthesias, and bowel/ bladder involvement due to compression of nerve roots.
  • The most common cause is intervertebral disc prolapse.
  • Other common causes include:
    • Spinal tumors
    • Spinal infections
    • Spinal stenosis
    • Spinal injuries (Gunshot wounds)
    • Postoperative complications
    • Spinal anaesthesia
  • It presents with asymmetrical loss of the motor / sensory system and bowel/bladder incontinence.
  • Decreased rectal tone
  • Pain in back and lower limbs (sciatica)
  • It may cause urinary retention and perineal numbness (saddle anesthesia).
  • It can cause erectile dysfunction.

Option A: Pott's spine

  • Pott’s spine does not present with a prolapsed disc.
  • It is chronic tuberculosis of the spine causing loss of spinal curvature.

Option B: Multiple myeloma

  • Multiple myeloma presents with a history of hypercalcemia, high ESR, and multiple bone involvement. (CRAB)

Option D: Bone metastasis

  • Bone metastasis may present with cachexia or weight loss.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female presents to the clinic to evaluate her eating habits. She states that there are episodes when she eats a lot. This is followed by using laxatives. She has been experiencing this behavior for the past many months. She also complains of an irregular menstrual cycle. Her medical history is consistent with anxiety disorders. Her only medication includes sertraline. Considering the most likely diagnosis, which of the following is not true regarding her most probable diagnosis?

choices.text: Invariable weight loss with an endocrine disorder
Occurrence of both binge eating and inappropriate compensatory behaviors

questions.solution:
Option A: Invariable weight loss with an endocrine disorder

Bulimia nervosa:

  • Characterized by episodes of binge eating followed by inappropriate ways of stopping weight gain - Purging (self-induced vomiting
  • Weight is normal, but there is fear of gaining weight
  • Hypokalemic and Hypochloremic alkalosis

Option B: Occurrence of both binge eating and inappropriate compensatory

  • Both binge eating and inappropriate compensatory is a features of bulimia nervosa.

Option C: Recurrent episodes of binge eating

  • Recurrent episodes of binge eating are a feature of bulimia nervosa

Option D: Recurrent self–induced vomiting

  • Recurrent self–induced vomiting is a feature of bulimia nervosa

questions.text: A patient from rural India presented to the hospital with discoloration in skin, loss of eyebrows and eyelashes, blister formation and rashes. The clinical diagnosis of leprosy was made by the physician. In the management of leprosy, the Lepromin test is most useful for?
questions.solution:
Option B: Prognosis

  • In the management of leprosy, the Lepromin test is most useful for estimating the prognosis in case of leprosy of all types.
  • Lepromin test is strongly positive in Tuberculoid leprosy.
  • Uses of Lepromin test:
    • Evaluation of CMI status
    • Aid to confirm the classification
    • Estimation of prognosis

Learning Objective

Tests for Detecting Immunity in Leprosy

Tests of Cell Mediated ImmunityQ Tests of Humoral ImmunityQ
Lepromin test FLA - ABS Test
Lymphocyte transformation test Monoclonal antibodies test
Leucocyte migration inhibition test ELISA tests
Radioimmuneassay

LEPROMIN TEST

  • The test is performed by injecting intradermally 0.1 ml of lepromin at inner aspect of the forearm of the individual.
  • Two types of positive reactions have been described:
    • Early reaction → Also known as FERNANDEZ reaction, read after 3 days.
    • Late reaction → Also known as MITSUDA reaction, read after 3 weeks.
  • Lepromin test is not a diagnostic test. The test has been generally accepted as a useful tool in evaluating the immune status (CMI) of leprosy patients.
  • The test is also of great value in estimating the prognosis in case of leprosy of all types.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the process of translation in a human stem cell. He is interested in the binding of transfer RNA to an amino acid. He finds that a transfer RNA that normally carries cysteine (tRNAcys) is mischarged with alanine (ala-tRNAcys). Assuming no correction occurs, what will be the fate of this mischarged transfer RNA during protein synthesis?

choices.text: It will be incorporated into a protein in response to an alanine codon
It will be incorporated into a protein in response to a cysteine codon
It will remain attached to the tRNA as it cannot be used for protein synthesis
It will be chemically converted to cysteine by cellular-enzymes

questions.solution:
Option B: It will be incorporated into a protein in response to a cysteine codon

Aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase

  • This enzyme attaches amino acid & tRNA.
  • This step is the only proofreading step in translation
  • If a wrong amino acid gets attached during this step, then it can be corrected, but if the correction does not occur in this step, then this wrong amino acid will be added to the protein.
  • A tRNAcys is usually recognized by the aminoacyl-tRNA synthetase for cysteine and charged with cysteine to produce cys-tRNAcys. This is called the charging of tRNA.
  • As per the question, alanine is incorporated tRNAcys to produce ala-tRNAcys. Such a tRNA is called a mischarged tRNA.
  • Ribosomal machinery can't detect the amino acid attached to the tRNA.
  • Interaction between the codon of mRNA and the anticodon of tRNA determines the amino acid incorporated in the polypeptide chain.
  • Anticodon of ala-tRNAcys interacts with codon of cysteine only. So alanine will be incorporated into the polypeptide in place of cysteine.

Option A: It will be incorporated into a protein in response to an alanine codon

  • Anticodon of ala-tRNAcys cannot recognize alanine codon. So, it will not bind to codon at all.

Option C: It will remain attached to the tRNA as it cannot be used for protein synthesis

  • Once the codon and anticodon match occur which will happen in this case, whatever amino acid is present on tRNA will be incorporated in to protein in this case alanine. 

Option D: It will be chemically converted to cysteine by cellular-enzymes

  • Incorporated alanine cannot be changed to cysteine. It will remain as alanine.
  • If the protein become nonfunctional due to its incorporation it will be degraded by protein degradation system

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of anorexia and weight loss. On ultrasound, there are bilateral ovarian malignant masses for which the gynecologist is planning for laparotomy. On exploration, the ovaries are symmetrically enlarged with firm and waxy consistency. Histopathology shows signet-ring cells. Which of the following investigation is warranted in this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Gastric endoscopy

  • Bilateral tumor masses with a firm to waxy consistency with signet cells on histopathology suggest the Krukenberg tumor.
  • Krukenberg tumor:
  • Krukenberg tumor is secondaries to the ovary. It is most commonly from the CA Stomach (usual adenocarcinoma of gastric pylorus). Other primary sites are breast cancer, appendix, colon, small intestine, rectum, gall bladder, and biliary tract.
  • Firm to solid waxy consistency is bilateral in 90% of cases.
  • Signet ring cells are seen.
  • Most often present in bilateral ovaries, consistent with metastatic nature.

 

Option A: CECT brain

  • CECT brain is not indicated as brain cancers extremely rarely metastasize to ovaries.

 

Option C: AFP

 

  • AFP is a tumor marker of yolk sac tumor, embryonal tumor, and teratoma and is not raised in the Krukenberg tumor.

 

Option D: CA 125

  • It is a false option.
  • CA 125 must always be done in case of ovarian tumors to rule out epithelial ovarian cancers, the most common cancers of the ovary, and are usually bilateral. In this case, however, since a biopsy is already done suggesting a Krukenberg tumor, tumor markers for other ovarian cancers are not required.

questions.text: What artery normally supplies the hippocampus and may cause anterograde amnesia due to ischemia?

choices.text: A medial striate artery from the middle cerebral artery
A lateral striate artery from the middle cerebral artery

questions.solution:
Option C: Anterior choroidal artery

  • There are various brain areas involved in anterograde amnesia. Research tells us that it's likely that the hippocampus and nearby subcortical regions are implicated.
  • The medial temporal lobe (MTL), basal forebrain, and fornix are important brain parts that may play a role in anterograde amnesia.
  • The MTL system consists of the brain's hippocampal, perirhinal, entorhinal, and Para hippocampal areas and is important for factual recall (declarative memory).
  • The MTL is not involved in non-declarative memory.

  • The internal carotid artery gives the anterior choroidal artery, which branches and forms the anterior hippocampal artery.
    • The posterior cerebral artery gives branches to the middle and posterior hippocampal artery.
  • Ischemia to the hippocampus causes anterograde amnesia.

Option A: A medial striate artery from middle cerebral artery

  • The internal capsule and basal ganglia are supplied by the lenticulostriate branches of the middle cerebral artery.
  • It is a branch of ACA, also known as the recurrent artery of Heubner.

Option B: A lateral striate artery from middle cerebral artery

  • It is a branch of MCA.
  • It also supplies the putamen.
  • Medial striate arteries and the Lateral striate arteries form the lenticulostriate arteries.

Option D: Anterior cerebral artery

  • ICA gives branches:
    • Anterior cerebral artery (major artery on medial cerebrum especially supplying paracentral lobule); controlling lower limb and part of pelvis and perineum.
    • Block causes urinary incontinence and lowers limb paralysis and sensory problem.

questions.text:
The lipid profile of a 47-year-old man is given below.


	
		
			Triglycerides
			200 mg/dL
		
		
			Total Cholesterol
			300 mg/dL
		
		
			HDL
			40 mg/dL
		
	


Calculate the LDL level in this patient.
questions.solution:
Option C: 220 mg/dL

  • This is the patient with anterior wall myocardial infarction and post thrombolytics; the patient is evaluated for serum lipid profile in order to manage hyperlipidemia.
  • No matter if it's MI or diabetes, or peripheral atrial disease, the management plan for hyperlipidemia remains the same.
  • Unknown LDL levels can be measured by using the equation:

Friedwald's equation:

  • Total Cholesterol = HDL+LDL+VLDL
  • Total Cholesterol = HDL+ LDL+ TG/5
  • (we do not measure VLDL, we measure TG)

LDL= Total cholesterol –HDL- TG/5 (mg/dl)

LDL= Total cholesterol – HDL – TG/2.2 (mmol/L)

So, LDL Cholesterol = 300 – 40 – 200/5 = 220 mg/dl
  • The ratio of TG to Cholesterol in VLDL particles is 5:1. which is the basis for this formula. Friedwald formula is almost accurate if test results are gained on fasting plasma and if the TG level does not cross ~200 mg/dL; by convention, it cannot be used if the TG level is >400 mg/dL.

Option A, B and D: Refer to explanation of C

questions.text: A 3-year-old male arrives at the emergency department complaining of right ear pain. His blood pressure is 100/70mmHg, and his pulse is 90/minute. Past medical history is significant for recurrent infections. Physical examination revealed that the discharge was coming from the ear canal. Labs show an absence of T -cells and immunoglobulins. A bone marrow transplant is being considered. What is the most likely diagnosis and indication for a bone marrow transplant?
questions.solution:
Option D: Hereditary immunodeficiency

  • The patient is suffering from immunodeficiency. 
  • Common symptoms are 
    • Recurrent infections 
    • Failure to thrive 
  • SCID is caused by autosomal or X-linked mutations. 
  • The most common cause is adenosine deaminase deficiency. 
  • The thymus is absent. 
  • Although hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is the mainstay of treatment, X-linked SCID can be treated with gene therapy. 
  • Hematopoietic stem cells are extracted from bone marrow or peripheral blood after being activated with hematopoietic growth factors. 
  • HSC transplants have two common complications 
    • Graft versus host disease (GVHD)
    • Immunodeficiency 
  • Graft versus host disease 
    • Donor T -cells attack the recipient antigens due to a mismatch. 
    • To avoid this, HSC transplants should be done between HLA-matched donors and recipients. 
    • Many organs are affected, including the skin, liver and intestine epithelia. 
    • Acute GVHD - occur within two weeks of transplantation.
    • Chronic GVHD - It may follow acute GVHD. Extensive skin injury is common in chronic conditions. 
  • Immunodeficiency 
    • It is a common complication of HSC transplantation. 
    • It may be due to myeloablation, a pre-treatment to prevent graft rejection. 
    • Patients are at increased risk of recurrent infections such as CMV. 

Option A: Thalassemia minor

  • Thalassemia minor is the less aggressive condition. 
  • Common characteristics are 
    • Anaemia 
    • Fatigue 
    • Target cells on blood smear 
    • Renal papillary necrosis 
    • Iron overload due to transfusions 

Option B: Autoimmune disease

  • Autoimmune disease is a condition where antibodies act against the body's antigens. 
  • The patient is suffering from SCID, which is a hereditary immunodeficiency. 

Option C: Multiple myeloma

  • Multiple myeloma is a carcinoma of plasma cells. 
  • Common symptoms are 
    • Back pain 
    • Hypercalcemia 
    • Infections 
    • Anaemia 
    • Bone pains

questions.text: Indian Newborn Action Plan (INAP) was launched in September 2014 for accelerating the reduction of preventable newborn deaths and stillbirths in the country. According to Indian newborn action plan (INAP), what is the target rate of Neonatal mortality for 2035?
questions.solution:
Option C: 9

  • According to the Indian newborn action plan (INAP), the target rate of Neonatal mortality for 2035 is 9.
  • Single digit implies <10, therefore 9 is the correct option.

Learning Objective

Indian Newborn Action Plan (INAP) goals:

  • To attain “Single Digit Neonatal Mortality Rate” and “Single Digit Stillbirth Rate” by 2030.
  • To achieve the same at all states individually by 2035.

Newborn Action Plan (INAP) - MANIFEST IAS" />

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to a gynecological OPD with a history of 7 weeks of amenorrhea and slight vaginal spotting. Her urine pregnancy test is positive. The crown-rump length (CRL) is 5 mm with a well-formed gestational sac with a calculated gestational age of 5+6 weeks on transvaginal sonography (TVS). However, the cardiac activity could not be seen. What of the following would be the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Perform an immediate dilation and curettage (D&C)

questions.solution:
Option A: Wait for another 1 week and repeat TVS
