  • For labelling the pregnancy as nonviable:
  • G-sac ≥ 25 mm size with no Yolk sac or fetal pole
  • CRL ≥ 7 mm with no cardiac activity
  • G-sac is seen but fetal pole or cardiac activity are not seen even after 2 weeks
  • G-sac and yolk sac are seen but fetal pole or cardiac activity are not seen even after 11 days
  • Yolk sac ≥ 7 mm and no fetal pole or cardiac activity seen

In this case, the CRL measured was 5 mm, and the gestational sac was seen; therefore, waiting for one to two weeks to repeat a USG to see for the appearance of cardiac activity is the next best step in the management of this patient.

Option B: Surgical or medical evacuation

  • We cannot declare it a nonviable pregnancy as CRL is 5mm, and the gestational sac is seen; therefore, no surgical or medical intervention is required at this point.

Option C: Wait for another 4 weeks

  • Waiting for 4 weeks can be done, however, one week is a more reasonable amount of time to assess viability, so that if the pregnancy is found to be non viable, timely termination can be offered.

Option D: Serum hCG levels

  • Serum HCG levels are more useful till gestational sac is not visualized, to determine whether pregnancy is intrauterine or ectopic. However, in this case falling serial HCG levels may suggest a failing pregnancy but confirmation would be made only after non visualization of heart beat after a week.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the ophthalmology department with the complaint of painless vision loss for the last month. The attending doctor examined the patient's eye and concluded that he had a defective retinal layer which was the cause of his painless vision loss; he drew a diagram below and pointed out that this layer was damaged. Identify the marked layer in the given histological section:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Inner plexiform layer:

  • The histologic section of the retina shows ten layers. The yellow arrow shows the Inner Plexiform layer

  • The inner plexiform layer of the retina comprises cells from the inner nuclear layer and retinal ganglion cells, which interlace their dendrites to form a thick reticulum of fibrils.
  • Occasionally, a few branched spongioblasts are lodged within this reticulum.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Outer plexiform layer:

  • The eye's retina contains a layer of neuronal synapses known as the outer plexiform layer (external plexiform layer).
  • It comprises an intricate web of synapses between the inner segments of photoreceptor cells from the outer nuclear layer with the dendrites of horizontal cells from the inner nuclear layer.

Option C - Inner limiting layer:

  • The pathophysiology of diseases affecting the vitreomacular interface can use the inner limiting membrane (ILM), the basement membrane of the Müller cells. It can serve as a scaffold for cellular proliferation.

Option D - Outer limiting layer:

  • One of the ten unique layers of the eye's retina is the external limiting membrane, sometimes known as the outer limiting membrane.
  • At the bases of the rods and cones, it possesses a network-like structure.

questions.text:
Calculate net filtration pressure with the following data:

PGC = 42 mm Hg

πGC = 12 mm Hg

PBs= 16 mm Hg

Assume that no proteins were filtered. Which of the following is most likely the answer?
questions.solution:
Option C: 14 mm Hg

  • Net filtration pressure is the balance between pressure favoring filtration and pressures opposing filtration. It is also known as effective filtration pressure or essential filtration pressure.
  • Net filtration pressure = (PGC - PBs) - (πGC - πBs).

As no protein is filtered in the Bowman's capsule, so πBs ix

                                         = (42 mm Hg - 16 mmHg) - (12 mm Hg  - 0 mmHg)

                                        = 14 mm Hg

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the following two curves (Blue and red) overall?

choices.text: Mean = Median, not equal to Mode
Mean = Mode, not equal to Median
Mean, Median and Mode are not equal

questions.solution:
Option B: Mean = Median, not equal to Mode

  • The red curve signifies the Normal distribution curve because it is bilaterally symmetrical and bell-shaped. Hence, the Median = Mean = Mode.
  • The blue curve can only be the curve of Mode as the Mean and Median cannot have two peaks. Therefore, it is a BIMODAL distribution.
  • Thus, Mean = Median, not equal to Mode.
  • Diseases showing bimodal distribution are Breast cancer & Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: What is the study design used for Consanguineous marriage and genetic abnormalities?
questions.solution:
Option D: Nested case-control study

  • A nested case-control study is used for Consanguineous marriage and genetic abnormalities.
  • Nested case-control is a hybrid design where a case-control study is nested in a cohort study.
  • It is predominantly a type of Cohort study (due to forward direction).
  • Usefulness is limited for studies involving ‘rare diseases AND whose diagnostic tests are very expensive’.

Option A: Twin study

  • Studies on identical or fraternal twins are referred to as twin studies. They seek to illuminate the significance of genetic and environmental factors in the development of characteristics, phenotypes, and diseases. Twin studies are regarded as a crucial tool in behavioral genetics and allied disciplines, ranging from biology to psychology.

Option B: Family study

  • Family studies are investigations into whether a condition or characteristic "runs in the family" in genetic epidemiology. In other words, they are investigations into whether there is a familial aggregation for the disease or characteristic, whereby a higher risk is associated with a family history.

 

Option C: Case-control study

  • In a Case-control study, both exposure, as well as an outcome, have occurred when the study has begun: First, we take the outcome into consideration, and then go back in time taking exposure into consideration; then compare exposure in both diseased (cases) and non-diseased (controls).

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is being evaluated for developmental delay and poor muscle control. The parents are concerned since the child has started to bite his lips and fingers. Laboratory investigations reveal high levels of serum uric acid. Which of the following specific reactions is not catalyzed in the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Guanine + 5′PRPP → GMP + PPi

  • The child exhibits the symptoms of Lesch–Nyhan syndrome, which are
    • Mental retardation
    • Self-mutilation
    • Impaired function of kidneys
  • Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is caused by a deficiency of the hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase enzyme.
  • The pattern of inheritance: X linked recessive
  • HGPRT converts the free bases hypoxanthine, or guanine, plus PRPP (5′-phosphoribosyl 1′-pyrophosphate) to the nucleotides IMP, or GMP, plus pyrophosphate (see fig).

Option A: Thymine + deoxyribose 1-phosphate → deoxythymidine + PPi

  • Conversion of Thymine into deoxythymidine is a step in the synthesis of nucleoside formation for DNA synthesis.

Option B: Adenine + 5′-PRPP → AMP + PPi

  • Adenine can be converted to AMP by enzyme adenine phosphoribosyltransferase (APRTase).
  • It is also an enzyme of purine salvage pathway.
  • When APRTase has reduced or nonexistent activity, adenine accumulates.

Option C: Uracil + ribose 1-phosphate → uridine +phosphate

  • Conversion of uracil into uridine is a step in the synthesis of nucleoside for RNA synthesis.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male with a history of multiple episodes of dysphagia and postprandial chest pain showed a ringed esophagus on a barium meal X-ray. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Eosinophilic esophagitis

  • This scenario indicates that the patient has eosinophilic esophagitis.
  • Eosinophilic esophagitis is a chronic disease of the immune system. In this disease, the eosinophils build up in the esophagus lining. It results in inflammation and damage.
  • The presentation of eosinophilic esophagitis is chest pain (often postprandial) and dysphagia. Dysphagia may occur with solids or liquids, but solid-food dysphagia is the most common.
  • It does not respond to proton pump inhibitors. A barium swallow should be the first test obtained in the patient with dysphagia. EE has a characterised finding often called the "ringed esophagus" or the "feline esophagus", as the esophagus rings are felt to look like the strips on a housecat.
  • Food allergies mainly trigger it, so dietary avoidance of allergic foods is advised. The second-line therapy includes inhaled or ingested corticosteroids.

Option B: Radiation esophagitis

  • Radiation esophagitis is a consequence of radiotherapy toxicity which causes inflammation or damage to the esophagus. It can be acute or chronic, depending on the radiographic exposure duration.
  • It is most common in patients receiving radiation cancer therapy for breast, lung, and other lymphomas. Treatment is most supportive with proper hydration and nutrition intake.

Option C: GERD

  • Gastro-esophageal reflux disease develops when the mucosa is exposed to gastric contents for a long time, which results in esophagitis and heartburn.
  • It can be diagnosed with manometry, barium swallow, and esophagoscopy. Mostly antacids and proton pump inhibitors are given for the treatment of this condition. But in some cases, surgical treatment is also required.

Option D: Carcinoma esophagus

  • It is esophageal cancer in which malignant cells are formed in the tissues of the esophagus. This carcinoma is most common in men and presents in old age.
  • Important risk factors include smoking, alcohol intake, and nitroso compounds. They can result in pain, dysphagia, weight loss, and fistula formation. Mostly they are managed surgically, but if widespread, radiotherapy and chemotherapy are also used.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics make teduglutide a favourable drug in a patient diagnosed with short bowel syndrome?

choices.text: It is used to speed up defecation

questions.solution:
Option B: It is a GLP-2 agonist

  • Glucagon-like peptide (GLP)-2 analogues are a class of medications that are used for the prevention or treatment of patients who require intravenous nutrition and fluids yet have been diagnosed with short bowel syndrome (SBS).
  • In reaction to the consumption of nutrients, enteroendocrine cells in the gastrointestinal tract secrete peptide hormones called glucagon-like peptides (GLP-1 and GLP-2) that each contain 33 amino acids.
  • These hormones play a role in the regulation of your appetite, particularly after you have eaten. Additionally, they contribute to an increase in the production of insulin. These hormones can be detected as early as ten minutes after a meal has been consumed. GLP-1 continues to be present in the body and circulates in the blood several hours after a meal has been consumed.
  • GLP-2 enhances the barrier function of the gut epithelium while also regulating stomach motility and gastric acid output. It also controls the transport of hexose into the small intestine.
  • A drug ending with "GLUTIDE" is a Glucagon-like peptide (GLP) receptor agonist.
  • GLP-1 agonist: Exenatide, Liraglutide
  • GLP-2 agonist: Teduglutide

Option A: It is Used to speed up defecation

  • It is used to increase gastric emptying time.

Option C: It is a pancreatic enzyme

  • It is a hormone, not a pancreatic enzyme.

Option D: It promotes insulin release

  • GLP-1 has a predominant role in promoting insulin release.

questions.text: An infant was born by cesarean delivery at 33 weeks of gestational age. At birth, the infant had generalized hemorrhagic purpura (a blueberry muffin rash) over the entire body, patent ductus arteriosus, cardiomegaly, thrombocytopenia, pneumonitis, anemia, and liver dysfunction. Which of the following is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C: Toga virus

  • The above-given clinical features are characteristics of Congenital Rubella Syndrome, which belongs to the family Togaviridae.
  • Family Togaviridae includes
    • Genus Alphavirus → Western Equine Encephalitis (WEE), Eastern Equine Encephalitis (EEE), Venezuelan Equine Encephalitis (VEE), and Chikungunya fever.
    • Genus Rubivirus → Rubella

Option A: Orthomyxovirus

  • Orthomyxovirus is the causative organism of influenza.
  • Type A influenza is the most common cause of epidemics and is the only cause of pandemics.
  • Type A influenza include
    • H3N2 is the most common subtype.
    • H1N1 (Swine flu)
    • H5N1 (Avian flu)
    • H7N9 (Avian flu) started in China in 2013.

Option B: Paramyxovirus

  • RNA paramyxovirus is the causative agent for Measles.
  • Incubation Period: 10-14 days
  • Source of Infection: Cases (carriers are not known to occur).
  • Mode of transmission: Air droplets (respiratory)
  • Period of Communicability: 4 days before and 5 days after the appearance of the rash (Rash: Retro-auricular origin).
  • Measles has no second attacks (lifelong immunity seen).
  • The secondary attack rate of Measles is 80%.
  • Measles shows a cyclical trend: Increase every 2-3 years.
  • The most common complication of measles in young children is Otitis media.

Option D: Arbovirus group B

  • Group B Arbovirus causes Japanese Encephalitis
  • Transmission: Rice paddy fields
  • Vector: Culex Triteniorhynchus, C. Vishnvii, C. Gelidus.
  • Amplified host: Pigs
  • Accidental host: Man

questions.text: A 28-year-old male sewerage worker presents to the physician with complaints of fever along with jaundice and conjunctivitis for 1 week. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. His blood sample was taken and sent to the lab. Lab findings are suggestive of kidney failure and elevated hepatic enzymes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer

Option B: Leptospirosis

  • This is a case of leptospirosis in which the patient presents with complaints of fever along with jaundice and conjunctivitis for 1 week.

Leptospirosis -

  • Caused by Leptospira interrogans

  • Leptospira is an actively motile spirochete

  • Mode of transmission: Zoonotic, by contact with water or moist soil contaminated with rat's urine or dead rats.

  • 3 R associated with leptospirosis - Rat urine, Rice (Paddy field worker), and Rainy water

  • Incubation period - 5-14 days.

  • Disseminated leptospirosis, also known as Weil's disease, is characterized by: High-grade fever (febrile illness) and conjunctivitis, jaundice, and haemorrhages (Ictero-hemorrhagic disease) and impairment of kidney functions.

Treatment:

  • Leptospirosis is treated with antibiotics, such as doxycycline or penicillin, which should be given early in the course of the disease.

  • Intravenous antibiotics (penicillin/ ceftriaxone/cefotaxime) may be required for persons with more severe symptoms.

Other Options

Option A: Malaria

  • Malaria is caused by plasmodium.

  • It is a life-threatening condition that, if untreated, can lead to the death of the person.

  • It is transmitted by an infected female anopheles.

Option C: Pertussis

  • Pertussis is also known as whooping cough.

  • It is a highly contagious disease of the lungs.

  • It is caused by Bordetella pertussis.

Option D: Typhoid

  • Typhoid fever is caused by salmonella typhi.

  • It is also known as enteric fever.

  • The clinical features of typhoid include fever, headache, abdominal pain, and constipation.

questions.text: You have a clinic set up in your hometown. A 42 year old male walks in and complains of generalized fatigue. On examination, almost everything seems to be normal except for his blood pressure, which was about 142/92 mmHg. Further probing revealed no comorbidities and an insignificant family history. Which of the following medications would you prefer as the first choice of treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
• According to ACC Guidelines and JNC 8 Guidelines → DOC for hypertension is Thiazides (preferred diuretic).
  • The other first line drugs for hypertension are-
    • ACE Inhibitors
    • Angiotensin receptor blockers
    • Calcium channel blockers
    • Triamterene and Spironolactone are K+ Sparing Diuretics → mainly used along with other diuretics to prevent hypokalemia.
    • Furosemide → is a loop diuretic → used for conditions like congestive heart failure.

questions.text: An accredited social health activist is a community health worker instituted by the government of India's Ministry of Health and Family Welfare as a part of the National Rural Health Mission. Which of the following is true about incentives given to ASHA workers in Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram?

choices.text: 400 INR to ASHA and 1000 INR to mother in rural area in high performing states
400 INR to ASHA and 1000 INR to mother in rural area in low performing states
400 INR to ASHA and 1000 INR to mother in urban area high performing states
400 INR to ASHA and 1000 INR to mother in urban area low performing states

questions.solution:
Option D: 400 INR to ASHA and 1000 INR to mother in urban area low performing states

  • In Low performing states JSSK provide 400 INR to ASHA and 1000 INR to mother in Urban area.

Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) Incentives

Under JSSK scheme:

  • Low performing states:
    • Low performing states JSSK provide 400 INR to ASHA and 1000 INR to mother in Urban area.
    • Low performing states JSSK provide 600 INR to ASHA and 1400 INR to mother in Rural area.
  • High performing States:
    • High performing states JSSK provide 400 INR to ASHA and 600 INR to mother in Urban area.
    • High performing states JSSK provide 600 INR to ASHA and 700 INR to mother in Rural area.

Learning Objective

Category Rural area Urban area
Mother’s ASHA Mother’s ASHA
LPS 1400 600 1000 400
HPS 700 600 600 400

questions.text: The forensic doctor is performing an autopsy of a baby who was allegedly killed by the father who was suspicious of the legitimacy of his birth. He performs a few tests to confirm that the baby was indeed alive at birth. He proceeds to do the Plocquet’s test to study the weight of the lungs of the baby. Respired lung weight as compared to body weight is?
questions.solution:
Option C: 1:35

  • Plocquet’s test: The ratio of weight of lung to weight of body almost doubled after respiration, from 1:70 before respiration to 1:35 after respiration.

questions.text: A 28 years female comes to the office complaining of shortness of breath, weakness and fatigue. She has no history of smoking or other illicit substance abuse. Her past medical or family history is insignificant. On physical examination, she is anaemic, and her vitals are normal; lab studies reveal Hb 8.0 gm/dL. After a proper evaluation, she is diagnosed with the alpha-thalassemia trait. Which of the following will be found in this patient's electrophoresis study?
questions.solution:
Option B: Normal HbF & normal HbA2

Haemoglobin electrophoresis:

  • Electrophoresis is a screening test for haemoglobinopathies.
  • The separation of haemoglobin molecules in an electric field, principally as a result of variations in total molecular charge, is the foundation of this test.
  • It detects any abnormal type of haemoglobin while measuring the haemoglobin level.

Hb type

Normal

Sickle cell anaemia

α thalassemia

β thalassemia

HbA

95%

Absent

  

Less

HbF

2%

Present

Normal

Increased

HbA2

3%

Present

Normal

Increased

 

  • In the α-thalassemia trait, the haemoglobin electrophoresis will show normal HbF and HbA2 levels.
  • In sickle cell anaemia absence of HbA means the disease severity is very high. But in the sickle cell trait, HBA is present.
  • The screening test for both α & β thalassemia is NESTROFT (Naked Eye Single Tube Red Cell Osmotic Fragility Test).
  • The investigation of choice for both α & β thalassemia is HPLC (High-performance liquid chromatography).

Option A: Increased HbF & normal HbA2

  • In the case of β thalassemia major, HbF markedly raises with a normal or slightly raised HbA2.

Option C: Normal HbF & decreased HbA2

  • In the α-thalassemia trait, the HbF level is normal, but HbA2 will also be normal.

Option D: Decreased HbF & normal HbA2

  • This finding will be found in a normal adult individual.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman known case of Hypertension presented with complaints of sudden onset headache, which she described as a characteristic thunderclap headache. There are no associated symptoms like watery eyes, photophobia, or phonophobia. Her GCS is 15/15, and she is vitally stable. On examination, her pupils are dilated bilaterally. These findings are most likely consistent with which of the following diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Acute aneurysmal haemorrhage

  • Thunderclap Headacheis the classic term for a headache associated with Subarachnoid haemorrhage.
  • Aneurysmal subarachnoid haemorrhage is a devastating neurological syndrome which occurs at a rate of 3–25 per 100,000 population.
  • Smoking and Hypertension are the most important risk factors for subarachnoid haemorrhage.
  • The rupture of cerebral aneurysms leads to rapid blood spread into the cerebrospinal fluid and increases intracranial pressure and severe headache.
  • Subarachnoid haemorrhage is associated with neurological (such as re‐bleeding and vasospasm) and systemic (such as myocardial injury and hyponatremia) complications that are causes of high mortality and morbidity.
  • A third cranial nerve palsy, particularly when associated with pupillary dilation, loss of ipsilateral light reflex, and focal pain above or behind the eye, may occur with an expanding aneurysm at the junction of the posterior communicating artery and the internal carotid artery.

Option A: Meningitis

  • Meningitis is a clinical syndrome characterized by inflammation of the meninges.
  • A history of fever and signs of neck rigidity may be present.
  • Lumbar puncture is the diagnostic modality.
  • In this case, the patient does not have a fever or signs of meningeal irritation.

Option B: Brain stem encephalitis

  • Bickerstaff's brainstem encephalitis is a rare post-infectious neurological disease characterized by the association of external ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, lower limb areflexia, extensor plantar response, and disturbance of consciousness (drowsiness, stupor, or coma).
  • No such symptoms are seen in this patient
  • There was no history of recent infection.

Option C: Ischemic Stroke

  • Ischemic stroke occurs when a vessel supplying blood to the brain is obstructed. It accounts for about 87 % of all strokes.
  • It is usually caused by a blood clot that blocks or plugs a blood vessel in the brain.
  • It keeps blood from flowing to the brain. Within minutes, brain cells begin to die.
  • Another cause is stenosis or narrowing of the artery.
  • It can happen because of atherosclerosis.
  • Symptoms of stroke include Sudden numbness or weakness of the face, arm, or leg (especially on one side of the body), Sudden confusion, trouble speaking or understanding speech, Sudden trouble seeing in one or both eyes, Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, loss of balance or coordination, Sudden severe headache with no known cause.
  • There are no such symptoms in this scenario

questions.text: A 49-year-old male patient presents with complaints of achy swollen joints, fatigue, skin rash, especially on the face, and difficulty in deep breathing. The senior resident doctor explains that it is related to immune competency and asks to study the complement pathway. Which of the following is involved in complement activation via an alternative pathway?
questions.solution:
Option C: C3

  • This case presents a patient who presents a picture of immune incompetency.

  • The complement system is a part of the immune system that helps to enhance the ability to kill pathogens more efficiently.

  • C3 is a significant component in complement activation via an alternative pathway. An alternative pathway is a system that kills pathogens and is part of innate immunity. It activates against snake venom, immunoglobulin A, viruses, and bacteria.

  • C3, under spontaneous hydrolysis, is converted into the C3(H2O) and combined with Bb of Factor B to form the C3 convertase that initiates the pathway.

Option A: C1

  • It is part of the complement system and protein in nature.

  • C1 is the major component in the activation of the classical pathway of the complement pathway.

Option B: C2

  • It is a protein of the human complement system encoded by the C2 gene.

  • Deficiency of the C2 is associated with a specific type of auto-immune disease.

Option D: C4

  • They also play an essential role in innate immunity, acting as one of the chief constituents. It works immediately by invading and eliminating pathogens.

  • C4 has an essential function in both the classic pathway and the lectin pathway of the complement system.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old patient presents to the clinic complaining of itching and ocular pain. The examination of his eye shows the following findings:



Which of the following is not a feature of the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Chalazion

  • The given image shows Arlt's line on the upper palpebral conjunctiva - a feature of trachoma.
  • It does not cause chalazion.

Chalazion:

  • A chalazion is a chronic granulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland.
  • Etiology:
    • It is probably due to chronic irritation caused by an organism of low virulence.
  • The glandular tissue is replaced by granulation tissue containing giant cells predominantly.
  • It is often multiple occurring in crops. 
  • It is more common in adults than in children. 
  • Seen in people with oily skin and ocular rosacea.
  • Symptoms
    1. There is no pain unless the chalazion is secondarily infected.
    2. There is disfigurement due to the presence of swelling in the lid.
    3. It may be single or multiple.
  • Signs
    1. A small non-tender hard swelling in the lid, slightly away from the lid margin, is seen.
    2. There are no signs of acute inflammation.
    3. On everting the lid, the conjunctiva over the swelling is red or purple. It is grey in later stages. It may be yellow when secondarily infected by pyogenic organisms.
  • Treatment:
    • It is incised and thoroughly scraped.
    • Injection of triamcinolone directly into the chalazion may cause complete resolution.

Option A: Corneal opacity

  • Trachoma can cause corneal opacity, which can lead to blindness.

Option C: Entropion

  • Entropion is the inward turning of the eyelashes, which can lead to conjunctivitis due to constant irritation.
  • It is a feature of trachoma.

Option D: Herbert's pits

  • In trachoma, regression of the follicles leads to depressed, round, thinned areas known clinically as Herbert's pits.

​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child is brought to the ophthalmology clinic by his mother with complaints of blurring of vision for one week. For a detailed examination of the eye, the doctor uses a short-acting medication which also has a cycloplegic effect. Which of the following drugs was used by the doctor in this case?
questions.solution:
Cyclopentolate is a short-acting topical medication that belongs to the class of anticholinergic drugs. It is commonly used in ophthalmology for its cycloplegic and mydriatic effects. Cycloplegia refers to the paralysis of the ciliary muscle, which helps to temporarily relax the focusing mechanism of the eye, providing a detailed examination of the refractive error and other ocular structures. Mydriasis refers to the dilation of the pupil, allowing better visualization of the posterior segment of the eye.

The incorrect options are:

1. Atropine oral: Atropine is an anticholinergic medication that can be used to induce cycloplegia and mydriasis, but it is typically administered as eye drops rather than orally for ophthalmic examinations.

2. Atropine eye ointment: Atropine eye ointment is another form of atropine administration that can induce cycloplegia and mydriasis. However, eye drops are more commonly used in clinical practice for their ease of administration and accurate dosing.

4. Phenylephrine eye drops: Phenylephrine is a sympathomimetic medication that causes pupillary dilation (mydriasis) by stimulating the dilator muscle of the iris. It does not have a cycloplegic effect. While phenylephrine eye drops may be used in certain eye examinations, such as for evaluating the anterior segment, they do not provide cycloplegia.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female labourer by occupation presents to the outpatient department with complaints of pain abdomen, nausea and restlessness for 4 hours. She gives the history of 2 episodes of hematuria. USG shows a 2×3 cm stone in the Right renal pelvis. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis. Which of the following is the best procedure for managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: PCNL

  • Percutaneous insertion of a nephroscope into the renal pelvis under ultrasonographic and/or fluoroscopic guidance to remove stones (minimally invasive)
  • It can be combined with lithotripsy
  • Used when stone size is more than 2.5cm

Option A: ESWL

  • Acoustic shockwaves are used to fragment stones (noninvasive)
  • Stones are localized using fluoroscopy or ultrasound.
  • It is preferred when the stones size is less than 2.5cm

Option C: Ureterorenoscopy

  • Transurethral endoscopic visualization of the upper urinary tract with a rigid or flexible endoscope used for stone extraction and intraurethral lithotripsy (minimally invasive)
  • Commonly combined with temporary uretheral stenting

Option D: Laparoscopic pyeloplasty

  • Laparoscopic pyeloplasty is a way to perform reconstructive surgery on a narrowing or scarring where the ureter (the tube that drains urine from the kidney to the bladder) attaches to the kidney through a minimally invasive procedure.

questions.text: A 35-year individual with a known case of HIV presents to the outpatient with complaints of blurry vision, sighting spots and floaters, and flashing lights. He also had a new found sensitivity to light and pain in the eyes. He underwent a Fundal examination which showed a Pizza appearance. Which of the following will be the commonest etiological agent in this case?
questions.solution:
Option A: Cytomegalovirus

  • Commonest ocular infection in HIV patients → CMV retinitis:
    • Bush - Fire appearance.
    • Pizza - Pie Appearance.
    • Sauce & Cheese Appearance.

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Retinitis:

  • CMV retinitis is the most commonly takes place opportunistic infection inner to the eye of patients with HIV.
  • HIV weakens the immune system of the patient, and then CMV infects the retina.
  • If not treated, CMV retinitis may cause the retina to pull away from the back of the eye.

This is called a retinal tear or retinal detachment, which can lead to blindness.

Ocular HIV:

  • Most common ocular manifestation → Cotton-wool spot or soft exudate, or HIV retinopathy.
  • Most common ocular infection → CMV retinitis.
  • Most common ocular tumor → Kaposi sarcoma > Lymphoma.

Option B: Toxoplasma gondii

  • Ocular toxoplasmosis is a disease caused by the infection with Toxoplasma gondii through congenital or acquired routes.
  • It causes myriad signs and symptoms.
  • It causes ocular redness, floaters, and decreased vision.

Option C: Cryptococcus neoformans

  • The actual invasion of the intraocular structures with Cryptococcus neoformans is an uncommon complication.
  • It causes Cryptococcus meningitis.

Option D: Histoplasma capsulatum

  • Ocular histoplasmosis syndrome (OHS) is an eye condition that can develop in people with a lung infection called histoplasmosis.
  • It aids in defining illness, but its ocular manifestations are less common.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman with P2L2 complains of heavy menstrual cycles with the passage of blood clots for 7 to 10 days each month for the past 1 year. She has only transient relief with medicines (the nature of medicines is unknown). On examination, the uterus is 18 cm in size. A USG shows an intramural fibroid size of 16 x 18 cm and an endometrial thickness of 4mm. Her Hb is 6.7 g/dL. What is the treatment of choice?

choices.text: Hb build-up and medical management with GnRH agonists/ mifepristone and follow-up.
Diagnostic and therapeutic D&C, if biopsy normal, myomectomy after blood transfusion

questions.solution:
Option C: Hb build-up and hysterectomy.

  • Hysterectomy is the definitive treatment of large fibroids. As a patient is aged and her family is also completed, surgery is the best option in this case. Hb build-up is necessary before surgery as low haemoglobin may lead to septic and distributive shock during surgery.
  • The patient has already tried medical treatment and failed; hysterectomy is a permanent solution to the symptomatic fibroid.
  • The treatment plan is mentioned below :

 

Option A: Hb build-up and medical management with GnRH agonists/ mifepristone and follow-up.

  • It is not a treatment option as the patient has already tried a medical treatment, which is not working for her.

Option B: Endometrial ablation.

  • Endometrial ablation is indicated for treating menorrhagia in premenopausal or perimenopausal women with normal endometrial cavities or thickened endometrium

Option D: Diagnostic and therapeutic D&C, myomectomy after blood transfusion, if biopsy normal.

  • D &C is done to determine the cause of abnormal or excessive uterine bleeding and would be therapeutic if the cause was endometrial hyperplasia
  • However myomectomy is not suitable here as the fibroid is extremely large and hysterectomy is also more suitable as her family is complete

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with PCOS undergoing fertility treatment with clomiphene citrate and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) injections complained of severe abdominal distension, nausea, vomiting, and difficulty breathing. On examination, she had moderate ascites, tachycardia, and hypotension. What is the likely cause of her current symptoms?

choices.text: Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a potential complication.
The symptoms are likely related to ectopic pregnancy.
The patient is at high risk for ovarian torsion.
The findings are consistent with a normal response to fertility treatments.

questions.solution:
Option A: Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome

  • Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS) is a medical complication unique to stimulatory infertility treatment; very rarely, it may present spontaneously.
  • Presents with the symptoms of fluid leakage in the body, such as abdominal distension, pain, nausea, vomiting, increased thirst, and bloating. Severe cases may present with pulmonary oedema, coagulopathy, and acute kidney failure.
  • In the above case scenario, there is a history of infertility and the use of clomiphene with gonadotrophin therapy with multiple follicular development.
  • OHSS may present in pregnancy and can occur with a more severe form in pregnancy, so a positive urine pregnancy test should not create confusion in the diagnosis of OHSS.
  • Early OHSS occurs 3-7 days following the HCG trigger and is associated with the administration of exogenous HCG.
  • The late-onset disease occurs 12-17 days after the HCG trigger. It results from endogenous HCG secretion during the pregnancy and tends to be more severe with multiple gestation.
  • Management is by monitoring the input and output of fluids. And also by intravascular fluid intake to replenish the volume and symptomatic treatment, like the tapping of the ascites and pleural effusion
  • It is normally a self-limiting condition.
  • Management of severe cases of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is done by admitting the patient for monitoring and following strict protocols to prevent secondary life-threatening complications.

Option B: Ruptured ovarian cyst

  • A ruptured ovarian cyst presents with acute abdominal pain and tenderness with abdominal distension; however, here, it is unlikely as there is no history of a pre-existing cyst. Also, the mention of a history of ovulation induction and trigger for follicular rupture makes OHSS more likely.

Option C: Ectopic pregnancy requiring β-HCG follow-up

  • Ectopic pregnancy presents with a history of amenorrhea associated with abdominal pain and spotting PV. It is, therefore, an important differential here. However, she has presented on the day of her missed period, and the USG suggests ascites. Thus, the background of the history of infertility treatment makes OHSS more likely here.​​​​​​​

Option D: Ectopic pregnancy requiring immediate surgery

  • Ectopic pregnancy requiring laparotomy implies a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, which presents with acute abdomen with pelvic tenderness on examination, and USG should reveal an adnexal mass, which is not the case here. A laparotomy would have been indicated if the patient was hemodynamically unstable or if USG suggested hemoperitoneum with the same clinical picture.

questions.text: Many young adults & children are admitted to emergency department with complaint of exacerbation of asthma on May 2nd which is a very hot day. There is no history of chronic bronchitis/ heart disease among these patients. Which of the following pollutant is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ozone

  • Highest levels of ozone pollution occurs during periods of sunny weather.
  • It can cause breathing problems, trigger asthma, reduce lung function and cause lung diseases.
  • Therefore, Option A is correct choice.

OZONE:

  • Given clinical scenario suggest towards the pollutant Ozone.
  • Ozone at ground level (not to be confused with the ozone layer in the upper atmosphere) is one of the major constituents of photochemical smog.
  • It is formed by the photochemical reaction of sunlight with pollutants such as nitrogen oxides from vehicle, industry emissions and volatile organic compounds (VOCs).
  • Highest levels of ozone pollution occurs during periods of sunny weather.
  • Excessive ozone in the air can have a marked effect on human health.
  • It can cause breathing problems, trigger asthma, reduce lung function and cause lung diseases.
  • Other important pollutants are carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, hydrogen sulphide, sulphur dioxide, sulphur trioxide, nitrogen oxides etc.

Option B/ C/ D: Carbon dioxide/ Nitrogen dioxide/ Sulphur oxide

  • Ozone pollution can cause breathing problems, trigger asthma, reduce lung function and cause lung diseases, therefore other option are unlikely.

Learning Objective

  • Ozone at ground level (not to be confused with the ozone layer in the upper atmosphere) is one of the major constituents of photochemical smog.
  • Highest levels of ozone pollution occurs during periods of sunny weather.
  • Excessive ozone in the air can have a marked effect on human health.
  • It can cause breathing problems, trigger asthma, reduce lung function and cause lung diseases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who works in a textile company visited the hospital for a routine health check-up. He prepares dyes for the company for the last 18 years. Which of the following investigation would you recommend for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Urine examination

  • Aniline dyes exposure: Bladder cancer.
  • In this case, the patient is exposed to dyes for a long duration and is at risk for developing bladder cancer.
  • So, urine tests should be done to see if there is any hematuria, which is the mc symptom of bladder cancer.

Option A: Pulmonary function tests

  • A full evaluation of the respiratory system, including a patient's medical history, physical examinations, and pulmonary function tests, is known as pulmonary function testing (PFT).
  • Finding out the extent of pulmonary dysfunction is the main goal of pulmonary function testing.
  • The results of pulmonary function tests can be used for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes, as well as to help clinicians learn more about patients with lung illness in general.
  • A pulmonologist, respiratory therapist, respiratory physiologist, physiotherapist, pulmonary function technician, or general practitioner typically administers PFTs.

Option B: Liver function tests

  • Hepatic panels, commonly known as liver function tests (LFTs or LFs), are collections of blood tests that reveal details about a patient's liver health.
  • These tests include bilirubin (direct and indirect), albumin, activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), prothrombin time (PT/INR), and others. In a patient with some degree of intact liver function, the liver transaminases aspartate transaminase (AST or SGOT) and alanine transaminase (ALT or SGPT) are helpful biomarkers of liver injury.
  • The majority of liver illnesses initially only manifest as minor symptoms, but they must be detected early.

Option D: Complete blood count

  • A combination of medical laboratory tests called a complete blood count (CBC), often called a full blood count (FBC), gives details about the cells in a person's blood.
  • The CBC shows the hemoglobin content, hematocrit, and counts of white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets (the volume percentage of red blood cells).

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, joint stiffness, aggressive behavior, and poor language skills; however, his vision is clear. Increased urinary excretion of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis among the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Option D: Degradation of glycosaminoglycans

  • Coarse facial features and accumulation of heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate in urine suggests mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS) which is due to accumulation of glycosaminoglycan (GAGs) due to absence of lysosomal enzyme in various tissues.
  • General Clinical features of MPS:
    • Coarse facial features -Depressed nasal bridge, frontal bossing
    • Copious nasal discharge
    • Short stature due to growth retardation
    • Clawing of hand
    • Protuberant abdomen – umbilical hernia,
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Corneal clouding
    • Skeletal abnormalities like Dysostosis multiplex due to defective bone formation and Bullet shaped middle phalanx

  

Option A: Mobilization of glycogen

  • The degradative pathway of glycogen is known as glycogenolysis, mobilizes the stored glycogen in the liver and skeletal muscle to release free glucose.
  • In skeletal muscle, glycogen undergoes glycogenolysis and is rapidly metabolized during exercise. In the liver, stored glycogen undergoes glycogenolysis to maintain blood sugar levels in the body.
  • Disorders of glycogen mobilization results in hypoglycemia and exercise intolerance.

Option B: Salvage purine bases

  • Purines resulting from the normal turnover of cellular nucleic acids are not broken down can be transformed into nucleoside triphosphates and used by the body. It is referred to as the salvage pathway for purines. This pathway is catalyzed by adenine phosphoribosyltransferase and hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT).
  • The deficiency of HGPRT results in Lesch Nyhan syndrome causing hyperuricemia.

Option C: Gluconeogenesis

  • It is an incorrect option, as the body synthesizes glucose in a special gluconeogenesis pathway, which requires mitochondrial and cytosolic enzymes. Gluconeogenic precursors include glycolysis and citric acid cycle intermediates, glycerol, lactate, and alpha-keto acids. This process occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Deficiency of the key gluconeogenic enzymes causes hypoglycemia and lactic acidosis.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is located within the superficial perineal pouch?
questions.solution:
Option C: Greater vestibular gland

  • The perineum lies beneath the pelvic floor. It can be divided into an anal triangle and a urogenital triangle.
  • The anal triangle contains the rectum and associated structures.
  • The urogenital triangle is further divided into two spaces, i.e., deep perineal space and a superficial perineal space.
  • The deep perineal space extends from the base of the pelvic floor to the perineal membrane.
  • The superficial perineal space extends from the base of the perineal membrane to the skin. The deep perineal space contains bulbourethral glands, a membranous part of the urethra, and deep transverse perineal muscles.
  • The superficial perineal space contains skeletal muscles, erectile tissues, branches of internal pudendal vessels, and greater vestibular glands.
  • So, the greater vestibular gland is in the superficial perineal space between the inferior fascia of the urogenital diaphragm and the membranous layer of superficial perineal fascia (Colles' fascia). And if the infection has infiltrated the space between the inferior fascia of the urogenital diaphragm and superficial perineal fascia, it would cause inflammation of the greater vestibular glands.

Option A: Membranous part of the male urethra

  • The membranous part of the urethra lies in the deep perineal space.
  • So, the infiltration of infection into the space between the inferior fascia of the urogenital diaphragm and superficial perineal fascia would not cause inflammation of the membranous part of the urethra.

Option B: Bulbourethral gland

  • The bulbourethral gland lies in the deep perineal space.
  • So, the infiltration of infection into the space between the inferior fascia of the urogenital diaphragm and superficial perineal fascia would not cause inflammation of the bulbourethral gland.

Option D: Deep transverse perineal muscles

  • The deep transverse perineal muscles lie in the deep perineal space.
  • So, the infiltration of infection into the space between the inferior fascia of the urogenital diaphragm and superficial perineal fascia would not cause inflammation of the deep transverse perineal muscles.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with numbness and tingling sensations on the lateral aspect of his left arm after a road traffic accident. Considering the damage to the axillary nerve, which type of axons appear to be spared with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Option C: Preganglionic sympathetic axons

  • The axillary nerve contains no preganglionic sympathetic general visceral efferent (GVE) fibres but postganglionic sympathetic GVE fibres.
  • So, the preganglionic sympathetic general visceral efferent (GVE) fibres will be spared in axillary nerve injury. It also contains general somatic afferent (GSA), general somatic efferent (GSE), and general visceral afferent (GVA) fibres.
  • The function of a nerve is to carry sensory and motor information. If the sensations go from the brain to the periphery, it is an efferent (motor) nerve. If it travels from the periphery to the brain, it is an afferent (sensory) nerve. Nerves that do both are mixed nerves.
  • Unlike spinal nerves, which are always mixed, cranial nerves can be purely motor, purely sensory or mixed.
  • The information is classified as special if it travels from our special senses (vision, smell, taste, hearing, and balance), while general describes the information to/from everywhere else.
  • The information a nerve carries is somatic if it travels to/from the skin and skeletal muscles or visceral if it travels to/from our internal organs.
  • So, to conclude, considering the possible directions and modalities, cranial nerves can be:
    • General somatic afferent (GSA)
    • General somatic efferent (GSE)
    • General visceral afferent (GVA)
    • General visceral efferent (GVE)
    • Special somatic afferent (SSA)
    • Special visceral afferent (SVA)
    • Special visceral efferent (SVE)

Option A: Postganglionic sympathetic axons

  • The axillary nerve contains no preganglionic sympathetic general visceral efferent (GVE) fibres but postganglionic sympathetic GVE fibres.

Option B: General somatic efferent axons

  • GSE (General Somatic Efferent) supplies all skeletal muscles except pharyngeal arch muscles. Also, supply eyeball (CN: 3, 4, 6) and tongue muscle (CN:12).
  • The axillary nerve contains general somatic efferent (GSE).

Option D: General somatic efferent axons

  • General somatic afferent (GSA) carries sensations such as touch, pain, temperature, proprioception etc.
  • These include three sensory nuclei of CN 5.
  • The axillary nerve contains general somatic afferent (GSA).

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with nausea, vomiting, fever, loss of appetite, and severe right lower quadrant abdominal pain for 6 hours. Diagnosis indicates acute appendicitis. During an appendectomy at McBurney's point, what structure is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ilio-hypogastric nerve

  • The iliohypogastric nerve runs medially and inferiorly between the internal oblique and transverse abdominal muscles near McBurney's point
  • It can be injured during an appendectomy
  • The McBurney point is at the junction of the lateral one-third of a line between the anterior superior iliac spine and umbilicus.
  • The ilioinguinal nerve can also be injured or entrapped along with the iliohypogastric nerve during the appendectomy
  • The diagnostic triad of nerve entrapment after operation comprises
    • (1) Typical burning or lancinating pain near the incision that radiates to the area supplied by the nerve,
    • (2) Clear evidence of the impaired sensory perception of the nerve, and
    • (3) Pain relieved by infiltration with anesthetic for local effects at the site where the two nerves leave the internal oblique muscle.
  • Surgical scar repair with resection of the compromised nerve is the most effective treatment. 

Option A: Deep circumflex femoral artery

  • It is a branch of the external iliac artery that runs along the pelvis on the medial side of the ala of the ilium at the iliac crest. It does not pass through the McBurney point, so it cannot be injured in appendectomy

Option B: Inferior epigastric artery

  • It is a branch of the external iliac artery. It is found on the anterior abdominal wall but does not pass through the McBurney point, so it cannot be injured in appendectomy

Option D: Genitofemoral nerve

  • The genitofemoral nerve supplies the cremasteric muscle and the skin on the scrotum and medial thigh. So it cannot be injured in an appendectomy

questions.text: 50 year old male, known case of diverticulosis of the colon presents with complaints of left lower quadrant pain and bloody stools. He was taken up for follow up testing. Doctor begins his workup with appropriate test of the sigmoid colon and operates, by recalling which of it’s specific feature:

choices.text: Has teniae coli and epiploic appendages
Receives parasympathetic fibers from the vagus nerve
Receives its blood from the superior mesenteric artery

questions.solution:
• The sigmoid colon has Teniae coli and epiploic appendages.
• The sigmoid colon receives blood from the inferior mesenteric artery, drains venous blood through the portal vein, has its own mesentery ( sigmoid mesocolon , so it is not a retroperitoneal organ).
• It receives parasympathetic preganglionic fibers from the pelvic splanchnic nerve..

questions.text: A 56-year-old male was undergoing surgery for squamous cell carcinoma of the neck. The surgeon notices profuse bleeding from the deep cervical artery during the surgery. Which of the following arteries must be ligated immediately to stop bleeding?
questions.solution:
Option A: Costo-cervical trunk

  • The subclavian arteries are among the major arteries of the head, neck and upper limbs. The left subclavian artery arises directly from the aortic arch, just distal to the origin of the left common carotid artery. The right subclavian artery and the right common carotid artery arising from the brachiocephalic trunk, a branch of the aortic arch. Although the left and the right subclavian arteries arise from different origins, they follow the same course in the neck region.
  • From the site of origin of subclavian arteries, they arch superolateral in the neck towards the axilla. They pass anterior to the middle scalene muscle and posterior to the anterior scalene muscle, which divides the arteries into 3 parts based on the relation with the anterior scalene muscle.
  • Pre-scalene part: The part before the medial border of the anterior scalene muscle. It gives off:-
  1. The vertebral artery supplies the upper part of the spinal cord, brainstem and cerebellum. It joins with the vertebral artery on the other side to form the basilar artery.
  2. The internal thoracic artery supplies the anterior thoracic wall and the breast.
  3. The thyrocervical trunk: The thyrocervical trunk gives off the suprascapular, transverse cervical and inferior thyroid artery. It supplies the larynx, pharynx, trachea, oesophagus, thyroid and parathyroid glands.
  • Retro-scalene part: The part behind the anterior scalene muscle. It gives off the costocervical trunk, which divides into the superior intercostal and deep cervical arteries. It is a short artery and supplies the deep muscles of the neck. Bleeding from the deep muscles of the neck can be controlled by ligating the costocervical trunk.
  • Post-scalene part: The part after the lateral border of the anterior scalene muscle. It gives off the dorsal scapular nerve, which supplies the upper back and shoulder muscle, including the trapezius, levator scapulae and rhomboids muscle.

Option B: Transverse cervical artery

  • The transverse cervical artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk. It is not ligated to control bleeding from the deep muscles of the neck, which are supplied by the deep cervical branch of the costocervical trunk.

Option C: Thyrocervical trunk

  • The thyrocervical trunk gives off suprascapular, transverse cervical and inferior thyroid arteries. It supplies the larynx, pharynx, trachea, oesophagus, thyroid and parathyroid glands.
  • To control bleeding from the deep muscles of the neck, the costocervical artery is ligated.

Option D: Inferior thyroid artery

  • The inferior thyroid artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk which supplies the larynx, pharynx, trachea, oesophagus, thyroid and parathyroid glands.
  • Ascending cervical artery is a branch of the inferior thyroid artery.
  • The deep muscles of the neck are supplied by the deep cervical artery, a branch of the costocervical artery. To control bleeding from the deep muscles of the neck, the costocervical artery is ligated.

questions.text: A man named Papa had been suspended from college because of missing many classes. His sister said that she had often seen him mumbling quietly to himself and at times he seemed to be talking to people who were not there. He would emerge from his room and ask his family to be quiet even when they were not making any noise. He was found to be a poorly groomed young man who seemed inattentive and preoccupied. His family said that they had never known him to use drugs or alcohol. He had been like this for the last 8 months and his condition is deteriorating gradually. Which of the following personality disorders is most prevalent among relatives of this patient?
questions.solution:
• Schizotypal personality disorder, which is characterized by odd and peculiar thinking and behavior, is more common among first-degree relatives of patients with schizophrenia.
  • Alternatively, there is an increase in the prevalence of schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders among relatives of patients with schizotypal personality disorder.
  • Several endophenotypes such as impairment in smooth pursuit eye movement or prepulse inhibition provide further evidence of the biological link between schizophrenia and schizotypal personality.
  • ICD-10 mentions Schizotypal disorder in Schizophrenia spectrum disorders with a code F21.
  • How to remember :Schizo"typ"al is a "typ(e)" of Schizophrenia continuum

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presented to the medical outpatient department with a complaint o fever, sore throat, and malaise. On throat examination, reddened enlarged tonsils are seen, and the pharynx is inflamed. There is splenomegaly on abdominal examination. The patient also complains of extreme fatigue. What is the best test for confirmation of a causative agent?
questions.solution:
Option B: IgM heterophile antibodies

  • In the above-given case, the symptoms of the inflamed pharynx, splenomegaly, enlarged tonsils, and fever is suggestive of infectious mononucleosis.
  • It is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus or Human herpes virus-4 (HHV-4).
  • It is transmitted via body secretion, especially saliva.
  • It causes fever, malaise, sore throat, anorexia, and myalgias.
  • On examination of bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy (mostly posterior chain), splenomegaly is present.
  • On blood smear, absolute lymphocytosis is seen.
  • The monospot test is used to detect heterophile antibodies.
  • In the acute phase, IgM heterophile antibody is present, and it falls after recovery.
  • Complications include secondary bacterial pharyngitis and splenic rupture.

Option A: A positive Tzanck smear

  • Tzanck giant cells are multinucleated cells.
  • These are seen in the following conditions: Pemphigus Vulgaris, herpes simplex type 1, varicella-zoster virus, and cytomegalovirus.

Option C: Koilocytotic cells

  • These are epithelial cells that have a hyperchromatic nucleus.
  • They are mostly present in HPV-infected epithelial cells. RT

Option D: RT-PCR for Enterovirus

  • This test is used to detect enterovirus in cerebrospinal fluid.
  • Quantitative PCR can also be used for the detection of viral presence.

questions.text: A 30-year-old infertile patient presents with chronic lower abdominal pain, congestive dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia. She has regular cycles and today is the 25th day of her period. On vaginal examination, there is pelvic tenderness and nodularity in the posterior fornix. The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Option B: Endometriosis

This option is correct because a patient with endometriosis may present with infertility, chronic pelvic pain, congestive dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia.

Presentation of endometriosis:

  • Infertility
  • Pain: dysmenorrhea (congestive type secondary dysmenorrhea), dyspareunia (in lesions over POD), or chronic pelvic pain
  • Pelvic mass
  • Menstrual abnormalities
  • GI symptoms: pain, nausea, vomiting, bloating, distension
  • Specific symptoms of extra pelvic endometriosis

Examination findings of endometriosis

  • Per speculum: bluish spots in the posterior fornix
  • Per vaginum: pelvic tenderness, nodularity in POD, fixed retroverted uterus, adnexal mass
  • Per rectal: nodularity in POD and uterosacral

Note: An important differential here would be PID which may present similar history and findings. However, a nodular POD is more suggestive of endometriosis.

Also, we must remember that almost 30% of infertile women have endometriosis!

Option A: Ruptured ectopic pregnancy

This option is false because a ruptured ectopic pregnancy presents a history of amenorrhea/ early pregnancy with acute abdomen pain; here, pain is chronic and is associated with dysmenorrhea.

Option C: Cervical carcinoma

This option is false because cervical cancer presents with abnormal vaginal bleeding, vaginal discharge, and cancer cachexia.

Option D: Pelvic congestion syndrome

Chronic pain, congestive dysmenorrhea, and pelvic tenderness may all be seen in pelvic congestion, but the history of infertility and nodularity in POD point more towards endometriosis.

Pelvic congestion syndrome is likely when there is

  • Emotional stress
  • A larger mean ovarian vein diameter
  • Compression of the left renal vein at the origin of the superior mesenteric artery (“nutcracker syndrome”)
  • Diagnosis: Transuterine venography or MRI are the primary methods for diagnosis
  • Treatment is hormonal suppression with Low-estrogen, progestin-dominant continuous OCs, high-dose progestins, and GnRH analogs often provide pain relief.
  • Other methods are ovarian vein embolization or hysterectomy and salpingo-oophorectomy

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented to the emergency with a complaint of chest pain associated with swallowing a piece of meat. He reports similar episodes over the past 3 years. However, today's episode was the most severe. He does not give a history of regurgitation other than these episodes or heartburn symptoms. There is no difficulty in liquid intake, and he has not had any weight loss. A probable diagnosis in this case is?
questions.solution:
Option A: Schatzki ring

 

  • B ring is a thin membranous narrow part present at the squamocolumnar mucosal junction.
  • Present in about 10-15% of people & mostly asymptomatic

Schatzki rings

  • When lumen diameter is <13mm
  • Associated with Episodic Solid food dysphagia (Classical symptom)
  • The typical age of presentation is >40 years
  • This intermittent food impaction is also known as “Steakhouse syndrome”, As meat is a typical initiator.
  • Treatment:- Dilation of the oesophagus

 

Option B: Adenocarcinoma of the oesophagus

  • In the late stages, it includes solid and liquid dysphagia.
  • Adenocarcinoma begins in the cells of mucus-secreting glands in the oesophagus.
  • Adenocarcinoma occurs most often in the lower portion of the oesophagus. Adenocarcinoma is the most common form of oesophagal cancer in the United States and primarily affects white men.
  • Oesophageal cancer is often in an advanced stage when it is diagnosed. At later stages, oesophagal cancer can be treated but rarely can be cured. Taking part in one of the clinical trials being done to improve treatment should be considered.

 

Option C: Achalasia

  • Involves both solid and liquid dysphagia + regurgitation
  • Achalasia treatment focuses on relaxing or stretching open the lower oesophagal sphincter so that food and liquid can move more quickly through the digestive tract.
  • Specific treatment depends on age, health condition and the severity of the achalasia.
  • The exact cause of achalasia is poorly understood. Researchers suspect it may be caused by a loss of nerve cells in the oesophagus.
  • There are theories about what causes this, but viral infection or autoimmune responses have been suspected.

 

Option D: Plummer-Vinson syndrome

  • It also involves oesophagal webs, which occur in the proximal part of the oesophagus.
  • Associated with iron deficiency anaemia
  • More common in middle-aged female
  • Plummer-Vinson syndrome is a condition that can occur in people with long-term (chronic) iron deficiency anaemia.
  • People with this condition have problems swallowing due to small, thin growths of tissue that partially block the upper food pipe (oesophagus).

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with a fever at 19 weeks of pregnancy. She tests positive for COVID-19 on PCR. She desires to know the effects of the disease on her baby. The risk of which of the following complications is increased in a case of pregnancy with COVID-19?
questions.solution:
Option A: Preterm birth

  • COVID-19 is a disease of the respiratory system that affects the lungs. The patient often complains of having a cough, fever, and shortness of breath when they come in. The consolidations in the patient's lungs result in a decrease in the patient's oxygen saturation.
  • Even though there is currently no proper treatment for the sickness, most people recover from it after the virus has had a chance to incubate in their bodies for a period of 14 days.
  • COVID-19 in pregnancy is associated with an increased risk of preterm birth. It is mostly iatrogenic and done in view of maternal or fetal compromise. Also, there are increased chances of cesarean delivery.
  • The appearance of the Delta variant was linked to an even higher risk of severe outcomes for pregnant people. These outcomes included an increase in the number of deaths, an increase in the number of ICU admissions, an increase in the number of required medical interventions such as invasive ventilation and ECMO, and an increase in the number of medical interventions overall.
  • There is no increased risk of congenital malformation, neonatal death, and pre-eclampsia.

 

Option B: Pre-eclampsia

  • Pre-eclampsia is not a complication of COVID-19 during pregnancy.

Option C: Fetal malformations

  • COVID-19 in pregnancy does not result in fetal malformations.

Option D: Neonatal death

  • Neonatal death is not a complication associated with COVID-19 in pregnancy.

questions.text:
In a physiology class, you are being taught about feedback mechanisms. The professor describes the importance of feedback mechanisms and various types of feedback mechanisms. Which among the following are examples of positive feedback mechanisms?

1. Oxytocin in parturition

2. Action potential of neuron from RMP to the action potential

3. LH surge leading to ovulation

4. Platelet plug/clot formation
questions.solution:
Option D: 1,2,3 and 4

1. Oxytocin in parturition

  • Oxytocin secretion from the posterior pituitary gland is increased during parturition, stimulated by uterine contractions that forcefully expel the fetuses.
  • Since oxytocin stimulates further contractions of the uterus, which is exquisitely sensitive to oxytocin at the end of pregnancy, a positive feedback loop is activated.

2. Action potential from RMP to the threshold

  • To begin an action potential, the membrane potential must change from the resting potential of approximately -70mV to the threshold voltage of -55mV.
  • Once the cell reaches the threshold, voltage-gated sodium channels open, and an action potential will be initiated.

3. LH surge leading to ovulation

  • Positive feedback triggers the anterior pituitary to release more FSH and LH. More FSH and LH cause the ovary to produce more estrogen. The ensuing LH surge is responsible for ovulation.

4. Platelet plug/clot formation

  • The formation of clots is also an example of the positive feedback loop. After the platelet plug, many enzymes activate, causing more blood clotting, thus preventing leakage.

questions.text: A 53-year-old female presents to the clinic for a regular health checkup. A routine abdominal radiograph is performed, which shows a porcelain gall bladder. Cholecystectomy is advised. Which of the following is the nerve supply to the gall bladder?
questions.solution:
Option A: Vagus nerve

  • Pain sensory fibers to the gall bladder are through Vagus, sympathetic and phrenic nerves.
  • Thus, gall bladder pain may be referred to through the Vagus to the stomach (epigastrium).
  • Through the sympathetic nerves to the inferior angle of the right scapula.
  • The thoracic 7 spinal cord segment's lateral horn gives sympathetic fibers to the celiac ganglion through the greater splanchnic nerve.
  • The T7 segment receives pain fibers from the skin over the inferior angle of the scapula.
  • So visceral pain is referred to as the somatic area.
  • Through the phrenic nerve to the right shoulder (C4 gives fibers to the phrenic nerve and supraclavicular nerves).

Option B: Trigeminal nerve

  • Pain sensory fibers to the gall bladder are through Vagus, sympathetic and phrenic nerves.
  • The trigeminal nerve carries sensations to the facial area.

Option C: Musculocutaneous nerve

  • Pain sensory fibers to the gall bladder are through Vagus, sympathetic and phrenic nerves
  • The musculocutaneous nerve innervates the three muscles of the anterior compartment of the arm: the coracobrachialis, biceps brachii, and brachialis.

Option D: Facial nerve

  • Pain sensory fibers to the gall bladder are through Vagus, sympathetic and phrenic nerves
  • The facial nerve does not innervate the gastrointestinal tract.

questions.text: A primigravida presented in labor at term pregnancy. An emergency LSCS had to be performed due to fetal distress. During the cesarean section, placenta delivery was followed by heavy bleeding from the placental bed. In order, the obstetrician injected oxytocin, injection methergine, rectal misoprostol, and intramyometrial prostodin. However, the bleeding did not stop. A few compression sutures over the uterus were taken, which also did not stop the bleeding completely, and the uterus remained atonic. Which is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Two-layer closure of the uterine incision

questions.solution:
Explanation:

Option B: Uterine artery ligation

  • This is a case of atonic PPH, where medical management has failed.
  • Compression sutures appropriately followed this.
  • The next step in the management of atonic PPH is stepwise uterine devascularization.


Surgical methods for management of atonic PPH in a cesarean section

  1. Compression sutures : B lynch sutures, Hayman sutures, cho sutures
  2. Stepwise devascularization: unilateral followed by bilateral uterine artery ligation, ovarian artery ligation, internal iliac artery ligation(usually after hysterectomy resistant haemorrhage)
  3. Hysterectomy

Internal artery ligation: using a snug ligature, we reduce the pulse pressure (therefore, the pressure of the artery reduces and becomes approximately equal to the vein causing sluggish flow, which induces thrombosis.

Branches of the anterior division of the internal iliac artery Branches of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery
  • Uterine
  
  • Obturator·
  
  • Superior vesical·
  
  • Inferior vesical·
  • Superior gluteal·
  • Internal pudendal·
  • Ilio-lumbar·
  • Inferior gluteal·
  • Lateral sacral
  • Inferior gluteal·
  
  • Vulval·
  
  • Clitoral
  

 

Option A: Two-layer closure of the uterine incision

  • The main step is to ligate the artery rather than the uterine incision after bleeding is not controlled with compression sutures

Option C: Hysterectomy

  • This is often the last resort to control bleeding.
  • Usually performed after bleeding is not controlled after uterine artery ligation and internal iliac ligation

Option D: Uterine massage

  • Uterine massage is the first line of management of the uterine atony.
  • However, if bleeding is not controlled, it is necessary to control bleeding with artery ligation.

questions.text: A 29-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal clinic at 26 weeks of gestation for a routine antenatal visit. On examination, her BP is 154/ 92 mmHg, and her PR is 88/min. Systemic and abdominal examinations are normal. Her previous BP records have been normal. Her weight gain in the last 2 weeks is 2 kgs. Her blood tests show Hb 12 gm%, TLC 8400/cu.mm, platelet count 200,000/mL, RBS is 116 mg/dL, serum Bilirubin: 0.6 mg/dL, and serum creatinine 0.8 mg/dL. Her 24-hour urine protein is 345 mg/day. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Preeclampsia

  • This patient presenting with high blood pressure at 26 weeks of gestation and proteinuria likely has preeclampsia.
  • Preeclampsia occurs when blood pressure increases to 140/90 mm Hg after 20 weeks of gestation and proteinuria is present (300 mg in 24 h or 1+ protein or greater on dipstick).

Option A: Chronic Hypertension

  • The given patient had normal BP throughout the gestational period. So, she does not have chronic hypertension. Chronic hypertension is defined as BP >140/90 mm Hg before pregnancy or diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestation, or hypertension first diagnosed after 20 weeks of gestation and persistent after 12 weeks postpartum.

Option C: Eclampsia

  • It is characterized by seizures and features of preeclampsia. The given patient has no seizures.

Option D: Preeclampsia superimposed on chronic hypertension

  • The given patient had normal BP throughout the gestational period. So, she does not have chronic hypertension. She has preeclampsia without chronic hypertension.

questions.text: A primigravida presents at 26 weeks with a painless ulcer on her labia. On examination, the ulcer appears raised with a firm border, reddish in color, non-tender, and smooth ulcer base without any significant pus. There are also associated lymph nodes that are not indurated or tender. Minimal exudate expressed from the ulcer on dark field microscopy shows motile spirochetes. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Option D: Benzathine penicillin

  • A single painless ulcer, as described, is suggestive of a primary chancre pathognomic of primary syphilis. Motile treponema pallidum may be seen on dark field microscopy of exudate.

Management of syphilis in pregnancy

  • Aim is to eradicate maternal infection and prevent and treat fetal infection
  • Drug of choice: Benzathine Penicillin G
  • In early syphilis (primary, secondary, latent syphilis of less than 1-year duration): a single dose of 2.4 million units of IM is recommended, and some recommend a second dose a week later.
  • In late syphilis (> 1-year duration): three weekly doses of 2.4 million units IM

 

 

Option A: No treatment till delivery

  • There is available treatment without causing harm to the fetus.
  • Benzathine penicillin is the drug of choice for syphilis
  • No treatment can otherwise cause serious complications.

 

Option B: Tetracycline

  • Tetracyclines, including doxycycline, are effective but contraindicated in pregnancy due to fetal effects of deciduous teeth discolouration

Tetracyclines are contraindicated in pregnancy because of the risk of

  1. hepatotoxicity in the mother
  2.  the potential for permanent discolouration of teeth in the fetus (yellow or brown in appearance)
  3.  impairment of fetal long bone growth.

 

Option C: Erythromycin + azithromycin

  • Erythromycin and azithromycin may be curative for the mother, but due to limited transplacental passage, prevention of fetal infection is ineffective
  • Azithromycin is compatible with breastfeeding from the RID perspective since it measured and simulated RID is low, and it has been used in higher doses for the treatment of infections in infants.
  • Drug of choice for Syphillis is Benzathine penicillin

questions.text: A 30-year-old male comes to the physician for a routine health examination. The patient is an office worker, so he does less exercise. The patient is worried that the lack of exercise might decrease his health. He has no history of any chronic illness. The patient is vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. Which of the following is a healthy cardiac reserve in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: 300 to 400%

  • The maximum percentage that the cardiac output can increase above normal is called the cardiac reserve.
  • In a healthy adult, the cardiac reserve is about 300 to 400%.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient comes to the hospital with a history of jaundice, abdominal pain and fever. His MRCP reveals the following findings. Which type of choledochal cyst is this?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option A: Ia

  • The image shown is of choledochal cyst type Ia as it shows fusiform dilation of the CBD
  • Choleductal cyst is a congenital anomaly  of the bile duct extra or intrahepatic
  • The different types of choledochal cysts are given.

Type I

→

M/C type of choledochal cysts

la

  

Fusiform dilatation of CBD

lb

  

Saccular/focal

lc

  

Extrahepatic

Type II

  

Diverticulum

Type III

  

Choledochocele
   

Type III is the only choledochal cyst which can be managed through an endoscopic route

Type IV

  

Multifocal dilatation strictures

IV a

  

Intrahepatic + extrahepatic ducts involved (trick: a→ all)

IV b

  

Extrahepatic ducts involved

IV c or type V

  

Intrahepatic duct involved ↓

  • Rx is:
  • Resection of cyst
  • Hepatico-jejunostomy
  • Treatment is important because they carry the risk of cholangiocarcinoma
  • TYPE V (Caroli disease)

  • Treatment- liver transplant

 

Option B: II

  • True diverticulum from the extrahepatic bile duct is type II

Option C: IV a

  • Cysts involving both intra and extrahepatic ducts, but in the  Mrcp image above, there is only fusiform dilation of the CBD and not the intrahepatic duct

Option D: V

  • In type V Caroli's disease, only the intrahepatic ducts are dilated, containing cysts in them

questions.text: A 26-year-old young female comes to the emergency department physician with the complaint of pain that happens only whenever she takes a plane flight. The pain is severe, and it only happens in her left ear. The patient is referred to an ENT consultant physician, and the doctor wants to perform a physical examination for the functioning of the eustachian tube. The following are non-physiological tests to check the function of the eustachian tube except?
questions.solution:
Option D: Toynbee test

  • The above-given case is the complaint of earache on plane flights.
  • The tympanic membrane of the patient is intact, so there can be physiological causes.
  • Tests to check the function of the eustachian tube.
  • Designed for those who can't perform the valsalva maneuver.
  • Physiological test:
    • Ask the patient to close the nose and swallow a small amount of liquid.
    • Negative pressure is created in the nasopharynx.
    • The eustachian tube opens up due to the action of tensor veli palatini.
    • Air is sucked out of the middle ear.
    • TM is retracted.
    • Movement can be seen by an examiner with an otoscope.
  • Patients with perforation of the tympanic membrane can give the same presentation, but the diagnostic test for the eustachian membrane is different.
    • Radiological test.
    • Saccharine or methylene blue test.
    • CT scan.
    • Sonotubometry.

 

Active/Physiological test Passive/Non-physiological test

Toynbee test

Tympanometry

Valsalva maneuver

Politzer test

Eustachian tube catheterization

Option A: Valsalva maneuver

  • Principle- positive pressure in the nasopharynx causes air to enter the eustachian tube and reach the middle ear, which causes a popup sound due to the bulging of the tympanic membrane.

Option B: Politzer test

Option C: Eustachian tube catheterization

  • This test is done in children who are unable to perform the Valsalva test.
  • In this test, the olive-shaped tip of the Politzer’s bag is introduced into the patient’s nostril on the side of which the tubal function is desired to be tested.
  • The other nostril is closed, and the bag is compressed while, at the same time, the patient swallows (he can be given sips of water) or says, "ik, ik, ik." By means of an auscultation tube connecting the patient's ear under test to that of the examiner, a hissing sound is heard if the tube is patent.
  • Compressed air can also be used instead of Politzer’s bag. The test is also used therapeutically to ventilate the middle ear.
  • In this test, the nose is first anesthetized by a topical spray of lignocaine, and then a eustachian tube catheter, the tip of which is bent, is passed along the floor of the nose till it reaches the nasopharynx.
  • Here it is rotated 90° medially and gradually pulled back till it engages on the posterior border of the nasal septum.
  • It is then rotated 180° laterally so that the tip lies against the tubal opening. A Politzer’s bag is now connected to the catheter and air insufflated.
  • Entry of air into the middle ear is verified by an auscultation tube. The procedure of catheterization should be gentle as it is known to cause complications such as:
    • Injury to eustachian tube opening, which causes scarring later.
    • Bleeding from the nose.
    • Transmission of nasal and nasopharyngeal infection into the middle ear, causing otitis media.
    •  Rupture of the atrophic area of the tympanic membrane if too much pressure is used.

questions.text: Raju, a 45 year old male, has recently undergone corneal transplantation. After the corneal transplant, the risk of the development of corneal infection increases. Which of the following infections is more common following corneal transplantation?
questions.solution:
Option A: Staph epidermidis

  • Pneumococcus and Staphylococcus aureus have been found to be the commonest microorganisms in the developed world, whereas Staph epidermidis is the commonest in developing countries for causing infectious keratitis after corneal transplantations.
  • Staphylococcus epidermidis is a coagulase-negative, gram-positive cocci bacteria that form clusters. It is also a catalase-positive and facultative anaerobe. They are the most common coagulase-negative Staphylococcus species that live on human skin.
  • Staph. epidermidis is an important pathogen in immunocompromised patients and patients who develop nosocomial bacteremia; treatment usually consists of antimicrobial therapy and removal of indwelling catheters or devices.
  • Eighty per cent of bacterial corneal ulcers are caused by Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae and Pseudomonas species. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most frequent and the most pathogenic ocular pathogen, which can cause corneal perforation in just 72 hours.

Option B: Streptococcus

  • Streptococcus is also responsible for causing post keratoplasty keratitis, but it is not the most common cause.

Option C: Klebsiella

  • Klebsiella is not the most common cause of post-keratoplasty keratitis.​​​​​​​

Option D: Pseudomonas

  • Pseudomonas is also responsible for causing post keratoplasty keratitis, but it is not the most common cause.
